hom.sense: The ninth letter of the alphabet; called caAlN: it is one of the letters termed majohuwrap [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, and not with the breath only]: and of the letters termed livawiy-ap [or gingival], which are v and c and Z; wherefore it is substituted for v in talaEocama for talaEovama; and it is said to be substituted for the unpointed d in faXar-ico bihimo, [as some read] in the Ḳur [viii. 59, for faXar-ido bhm]. (TA.)
[As a numeral, it denotes Seven hundred.]

caA is said by Aboo-ʼAlee to be originally caIo; the I, though quiescent, being changed into A: (M:) or it is originally cayaI or cawaI; the final radical letter being elided: some say that the original medial radical letter is I because it has been heard to be pronounced with imáleh [and so it is now pronounced in Egypt]; but others say that it is w, and this is the more agreeable with analogy. (Mṣb.) It is a noun of indication, [properly meaning This, but sometimes, when repeated, better rendered that,] relating to an object of the masc. gender, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) such as is near: (I’Aḳ p. 36:) or it relates to what is distant [accord. to some, and therefore should always be rendered that]; and hecaA, [which see in what follows,] to what is near: (Ḳ in art. haA: [but the former is generally held to relate to what is near, like the latter:]) or it is a noun denoting anything indicated that is seen by the speaker and the person addressed: the noun in it is ca, or c alone: and it is a noun of which the signification is vague and unknown until it is explained by what follows it, as when you say caA Alr-ajulu [This man], and caA Alfarasa [This horse]: and the nom. and accus. and gen. are all alike: (T:) the fem. is ciI (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, but omitted in the CK) and ciho, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, but omitted in the CK,) the latter used in the case of a pause, (Ṣ,) with a quiescent h, which is a substitute for the I, not a sign of the fem. gender, (Ṣ, M,) as it is in TaloHaho and Hamozaho, in which it is changed into p when followed by a conjunctive alif, for in this case the h in cih remains unchanged [but is meksoorah, as it is also in other cases of connexion with a following word]; and one says also chiI; (M;) and taA and tiho: (Ṣ and Ḳ, &c. in art. tA:) for the dual you say caAni and taAni; (M;) caAni is the dual form of caA (T, Ṣ) [and taAni is that of taA used in the place of ciI]; i. e., you indicate the masc. dual by caAni in the nom. case, and cayoni in the accus. and gen.; and the fem. dual you indicate by taAni in the nom. case, and tayoni in the accus. and gen.: (I’Aḳ p. 36:) the pl. is OulaMCi [or OulaMCi] (T, Ṣ, and I’Aḳ ib.) in the dial. of the people of El-Ḥijáz, (I’Aḳ,) and OuwlaI [or OulaI] (T, I’Aḳ) in the dial. of Temeem; each both masc. and fem. (I’Aḳ ib. [See art. AlI.]) You say, caA Oaxuwka [This is thy brother]: and ciI Ouxotuka [This is thy sister]: (T:) and laAMtiyka fiI ciI Als-anapi [I will not come to thee in this year]; like as you say fI hecihi Als-anapi and fI heciI Als-anapi; not fI caA Als-anapi, because cA is always masc. (Aṣ, T.) And you say, caAni OaxawaAka [These two are thy two brothers]: and taAni OuxotaAka [These two are thy two sisters]. (T.) And OuwlaMCi Uixowatuka [These are thy brothers]: and OuwlaMCi OaxawaAtuka [These are thy sisters]: thus making no difference between the masc. and the fem. in the pl. (T.)

The haA that is used to give notice, to a person addressed, of something about to be said to him, is prefixed to caA [and to ciI, &c.], (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and is a particle without any meaning but inception: (T:) thus you say hecaA, (T, Ṣ, M,) and some say hecaAA, adding another A; (Ks, T;) fem. heciI, (T, Ṣ, M,) and [more commonly] heciho in the case of a pause, (M,) and hecihi in other cases, (T, Ṣ,) and haAtaA, and some say hecaAti, but this is unusual and disapproved: (T:) dual hecaAni for the masc., and haAtaAni for the fem.; (T;) said by IJ to be not properly duals, but nouns formed to denote duals; (M;) and many of the Arabs say hecaAn-i; (T;) some, also, make hecaAni indecl., like the sing. caA, reading [in the Ḳur xx. 66] Uin-a hecaAni lasaAHiraAni [Verily these two are enchanters], and it has been said that this is of the dial. of Belhárith [or Benu-l-Hárith] Ibn-Kaab; but others make it decl., reading Uin-a hecaAyoni lasaAHiraAni: (Ṣ, TA: [see, however, what has been said respecting this phrase voce Uin-a:]) the pl. is heWulaA in the dial. of Temeem, with a quiescent A; and heWulaMCi in the dial. of the people of El-Ḥijáz, with medd and hemz and khafd; and heWulaMCK in the dial. of Benoo- 'Okeyl, with medd and hemz and tenween. (AZ, T.) The Arabs also say, laA haA Qll-ehi caA, introducing the name of God between haA and caA; meaning No, by God; this is [my oath, or] that by which I swear. (T.) In the following verse, of Jemeel,
waOataI SawaAHibuhaA faqulona hecaA Ql-aciI
manaHa Almawad-apa gayoranaA wajafaAnaA
[it is said that] hacaA is for OacaA, (M,) i. e., h is here substituted for the interrogative hemzeh (Ṣ * and Ḳ in art. hA) [so that the meaning is, And her female companions came, and said, Is this he who gave love to other than us, and treated us unkindly?]: or, as some assert, hacaA is here used for hecaA, the A being suppressed for the sake of the measure. (El-Bedr El-Karáfee, TA in art. hA.)

One says also caAka, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) affixing to caA the k of allocution, [q. v., meaning That,] relating to an object that is distant, (T,*, Ṣ, and I’Aḳ p. 36,) or, accord. to general opinion, to that which occupies a middle place between the near and the distant, (I’Aḳ pp. 36 and 37,) and this k has no place in desinential syntax; (Ṣ, and I’Aḳ p. 36;) it does not occupy the place of a gen. nor of an accus., but is only affixed to cA to denote the distance of cA from the person addressed: (T:) for the fem. you say tiyka (T, Ṣ) and taAka; (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. tA, q. v.;) but not ciyka, for this is wrong, (T, Ṣ,) and is used only by the vulgar: (T:) for the dual you say caAnika (T, Ṣ) and cayonika, as in the phrases jaMCaniI caAnika Alr-ajulaAni [Those two men came to me] and raOayotu cayonuka Alr-ajulayoni, [I saw those two men]; (Ṣ;) and some say caAn-ika, with teshdeed, (T, Ṣ,) [accord. to J] for the purpose of corroboration, and to add to the letters of the noun, (Ṣ,) but [accord. to others] this is dual of celika, [which see in what follows,] the second n being a substitute for the l; (T on the authority of Zj and others;) and some say taAn-ika also, with teshdeed, (T, Ṣ,) as well as taAnika: (T in this art., and Ṣ and Ḳ in art. tA, but there omitted in some copies of the Ṣ:) the pl. is [OuwlaAka and] OuwleYika. (T, Ṣ.) haA is also prefixed to caAka; so that you say, hecaAka zayodN [That is Zeyd]: (Ṣ, TA:) and in like manner, for the fem., you say haAtiyka and haAtaAka: (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. tA:) but it is not prefixed [to the dual nor] to OuwleYika. (Ṣ.)

You also add l in caAka, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) as a corroborative; (TA;) so that you say celika, [meaning That,] (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) relating to an object that is distant, by common consent; (I’Aḳ pp. 36 and 37;) or hemzeh, saying caAYika, (Ḳ,)
but some say that this is a mispronunciation: (TA in art. cwI:) for the fem. you say tiloka and taAlika: the dual of celika is caAn-ika, mentioned above; and that of the fem. is vaAn-ika: (T: [and in the Ḳ in art. tA, taAlika is also mentioned as a dual, as well as a sing.:]) and the pl. is OuwlaAlika. (Ṣ and M and Ḳ voce OuwlaI or OulaI or OulaA. [See art. AlI.]) haA is not prefixed to celika (Ṣ) nor to tiloka [nor to OuwlaAlika] because, as IB says, the l denotes the remoteness of that which is indicated and the hA denotes its nearness, so that the two are incompatible. (TA in art. tA.)

In the saying in the Ḳur [ii. 256, the Verse of the Throne], mano caA Al-aciI yaXofaEu Einodahu Uil-aA biUiconihi, (T, TA,) accord. to Th and Mbr, (TA,) hecaA is syn. with cA [so that the meaning is, Who is this that shall intercede with Him but by his permission?]: (T, TA:) or it may be here redundant [so that the meaning is, Who is he that, &c.?]. (Kull.)

It is sometimes syn. with Aal-aciI. (T, Ṣ, M.) So in the saying, maA caA raOayota [What is it that thou sawest?]; to which one may answer, mataAEN HasanN [A goodly commodity]. (Sb, Ṣ.) And so in the Ḳur [ii. 216], wayasoOaluwnaka maA maA caA yunofiquwna [And they ask thee what amount of their property is it that they shall expend in alms]; (T, M, TA;) accord. to those who make the reply to be in the nom. case; for this shows that mA is [virtually] in the nom. case as an inchoative, and cA is its enunciative, and ynfqwn is the complement of cA; and that mA and cA are not to be regarded as one word: [or] this is the preferable way of explanation in the opinion of Sb, though he allowed the other way, [that of regarding mA and cA as one word, together constituting an inchoative, and ynfqwn as its enunciative, (see Ḥam p. 521,)] with [the reply in] the nom. case: (M:) and hecaA, also, is used in the same sense: (TA:) so too cA in maA caA huwa and mano caA huwa may be considered as syn. with AlcI; but it is preferable to regard it as redundant. (Kull.)

It is [said to be] redundant also in other instances: for ex., in the trad. of Jereer, as related by Aboo-ʼAmr Ez-Záhid, who says that it is so in this instance: yaToluEu Ealayokumo rajulN mino ciI yamanK EalaI wajohihi masoHapN mino ciI mulokK [There will come to you a man from El-Yemen, having upon his face an indication of dominion]. (TA. [But this evidently belongs to art. cuw; in which see a similar ex. (OatayonaA caA yamanK). See also other exs. there.])
[kacaA lit. means Like this: and hence, thus: as also hekacaA.]
[It is also often used as one word, and, as such, is made the complement of a prefixed noun; as in sanapa kacaA and fiI sanapi kacaA In such a year. See also art. kacaA: and see the letter k.]

hecaA is sometimes used to express contempt, and mean estimation; as in the saying of ʼÁïsheh respecting ʼAbd-Allah Ibn-ʼAmr Ibn-ʼAbbás, yaA EajabFA liQboni EamorKw hecaA [O wonder (meaning how I wonder) at Ibn-ʼAmr, this fellow!]. (Kitáb el-Miftáh, cited in De Sacy's “Gram. Ar.,” 2nd ed., i. 442.) [yaA hecaA often occurs as addressed to one who is held in mean estimation: it is like the Greek ὦ οὗτος, and virtually like the vulgar Arabic expression yaA Oanota, and the Latin heus tu; agreeably with which it may be rendered O thou; meaning O thou fellow; an appellation denoting mean estimation being understood: in the contrary case, one says yaA fataI. See also, in what follows, a usage of caAka and celika.]

[hecaA in a letter and the like is introduced when the writer breaks off, turning to a new subject; and means “This is all that I had to say on the subject to which, it relates:” what follows it is commenced with the conjunction wa.]

One says, layosa bicaAka [and layosa bicelika], meaning It is not approved: for, [like as a person held in mean estimation is indicated by hecaA, which denotes a thing that is near, so,] on account of its high degree of estimation, a thing that is approved is indicated by that whereby one indicates a thing that is remote. (Kull voce lys.) [See also what next follows {1}.]

celika AlkitaAbu in the Ḳur ii. 1 is said by Zj to mean hecaA AlkitaAbu [This book]: but others say that clk is here used because the book is remote [from others] in respect of highness and greatness of rank. (TA.)
kacelika [lit. Like that, often means so, or in like manner: and]
Let that suffice [thee or] you. (TA in art. cEr, from a trad.)

The dim. of caA is cay-aA: (T, Ṣ, M:) you form no dim. of the fem. ciI, using in its stead that of taA, (Ṣ,) which is tay-aA: (T:) the dim. of the dual [caAni] is cay-aAni: (Ṣ:) and that of [the pl.] OuwlaMCi [and OuwlaI] is Ouwlay-aMCi [and Ouwlay-aA]: (T:)
that of hecaA is cay-aA, like that of caA; [and you may say hecay-aA also; for] that of heWulaMCi is heWulay-aMCi: (T:)
that of caAka is cay-aAka: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) and that of taAka is tay-aAka: (Ḳ in art. tA:)

that of celika is cay-aAlika: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) and that of tiloka is tay-aAlika. (Ṣ.) A rájiz says,
Oawo taHolifiI birab-ika AlEaliI-i
Uin-iI Oabuw cay-aAliki AlS-abiI-i
[Or thou shalt swear by thy Lord, the High, that I am the father of that little child]: (Ṣ, TA:) he was an Arab who came from a journey, and found that his wife had given birth to a boy whom he disacknowledged. (TA.)
caA is also the accus. case of cuw, q. v.

1. cuYiba He (a man, M) was frightened by the wolf; (M, Ḳ;) as also caYiba, aor. _a {yacoOabu}; and caWuba, aor. _u {yacoOubu}: (Ḳ:) or he (a man) was assailed, fallen upon, come upon, or overtaken, by the wolf. (Ibn-Buzurj, T.) And [hence, in the opinion of ISd, as he says in the M,] ‡ He was frightened by anything; (M, Ḳ;) and so AcOb↓, (AA, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. UicoMbN; (TA;) said of a man. (Ṣ.) [Hence also,] caOabahu, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yacoOabu}, (Ḳ,) [inf. n. caOobN,] ‡ He frightened him [like as does a wolf]: (M, A, Ḳ, TA:) and caOabatohu Aljin-u (A, TA) and tcO-bthu↓, as also tcE-bthu, (T, TA,) ‡ The jinn, or genii, frightened him. (T, A, TA.) [And hence, app.,] caOabotuhu Alr-iyHu ‡ The wind came to him from every side, like the wolf; when guarded against from one direction, coming from another direction: (A:) and tcMCbti↓ Ailr-iyHu, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and tcO-bt↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) ‡ The wind varied, (T, Ṣ, M,) or came now from one direction and now from another direction, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) so says Aṣ, (Ṣ,) feebly: (M, Ḳ:) accord. to Aṣ, from Alc-iYobu, (Ṣ,) [i. e.] it is likened to the wolf, (M,) because his motions are of the like description: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to some, Alc-iYobu is derived from tcMCbt↓ AlryH meaning the wind blew from every direction; because the wolf comes from every direction. (MF, TA.)
Also, (i. e. cuYiba) He (a man) had his sheep, or goats, fallen upon by the wolf. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And caWuba, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yacoOubu}, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. caMbapN; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and caYiba; (M, A, Ḳ;) and tcO-b↓; (M, Ḳ;) ‡ He (a man, T, Ṣ, M) was, or became, bad, wicked, deceitful, or crafty, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) like the wolf, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) or as though he became a wolf. (T.)

And caOaba, aor. _a {yacoOabu}, ‡ He acted like the wolf; when guarded against from one direction, coming from another direction. (TA.) [And probably † He howled like the wolf; for,] accord. to Kr, (M,) caOobN signifies the uttering a loud, or vehement, cry or sound. (M, Ḳ.)
And † He hastened, or was quick, in pace, or journeying; (Ḳ;) as also AcOb↓. (TA.)

caOabahu, [aor. _a {yacoOabu},] inf. n. caOobN, also signifies He despised him; and so caOamahu: (T:) or he drove him away, and despised him: (ISk, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or he drove him away, (Lḥ, M, TA,) and beat him; (Lḥ, TA;) and so caOamahu: (M, TA:) [or he blamed, or dispraised, him; like caOamahu; for,] accord. to Kr, (M,) caOobN signifies the act of blaming, or dispraising. (M, Ḳ.)
And He drove him, or urged him on: (Ḳ:) or caOaba AlUibila, inf. n. caOobN, he drove, or urged on, the camels. (Ṣ, M.)
He collected it; (T, Ḳ;) namely, a thing. (T.)

He made it even; syn. saw-aAhu. (CK: omitted in other copies of the Ḳ and in the TA.) One says of the woman who makes even (tusaw-iI) her vehicle, [meaning the part of her camel-vehicle upon which she sits,] maA OaHosana maA caOabatohu [How well has she made it even!] (T.)
He made it; namely, a [camel's saddle such as is called] qatab (Ḳ) and [such as is called] a raHol (TA.)
cuYiba said of a horse, He was, or became, affected with the disease termed ciYobap. (T, Mgh.)
2: see 1, last sentence but one.
cO-b Alr-aHola, (inf. n. tacoYiybN, Ḳ,) He made, to the rHl [or camel's saddle], what is termed a ciYobap, (M, Ḳ,) or ciYob. (TA.) [See also mucaO-abN.]

entry.sense: 4. OacoOabati AlOaroDu (A, TA) The land abounded with wolves. (TA.)
See also 1, in three places.
5: see 6, in two places:
and see also 1, in three places.

hom.sense: 6. tcMCb liln-Aqapi (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and tcO-b↓ lahaA (M, Ḳ) † He disguised himself like a wolf to the she-camel, and, by so frightening her, made her to incline to, or affect, her young one: (Ṣ:) or he cloaked, or disguised, himself to the she-camel, making himself to seem like a wolf, in order to cause her to affect a young one that was not her own [by moving her with pity by the supposed danger of the latter]. (M, Ḳ)
See also 1, in two places.

tcMCb XayoYFA and tcO-bhu↓ † He did a thing by turns; syn. tadaAwalahu: (M, Ḳ, TA: [in the CK, erroneously, tanAwalahu:]) from Alc-iYobu [the wolf], which, when guarded against from one direction, comes from another direction. (M, TA.)

entry.sense: 10. AstcOb Aln-aqadu The nqd [or ugly sheep] became like wolves: a prov., applied to low, mean, or ignominious, persons, when they obtain ascendancy. (T, Ḳ.)
garobN caOobN † A large bucket with which one goes to and fro; thought by Aṣ to be from tacaAWubu Alr-iyHi: (M:) or in much [or quick] motion, ascending and descending. (M, Ḳ.)

ciYobN, also pronounced ciybN, without C, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) originally with C, (T, Ṣ,) The wolf, wild dog, or dog of the desert; kalobu Albar-i: (M, A, Ḳ:) applied to the male and the female; (Mṣb;) and sometimes, also, (Mṣb,) the female is called ciYobapN: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. (of pauc., Ṣ, Mṣb) OacoWubN, and (of mult., Ṣ, Mṣb) ciYaAbN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which may also be pronounced ciyaAbN, with I, because of the kesreh, (Mṣb,) and cuWbaAnN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and ciYobaAnN. (TA.)
You say, Alc-iYobu yukan-aI OabaA jaEodapa [The wolf is surnamed Aboo-Jaadeh]: i. e. its surname is good, but its actions are foul. (TA. [See art. jEd; and see also Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 449.])
And Alc-iYobu yaOocuw AlgazaAla [The wolf lies in wait for the young gazelle]: a prov. alluding to perfidy. (TA.)
And huwa ciYobN fiI val-apK ‡ [He is a wolf among a flock of sheep]. (A.)

And ciYobapu miEozFI waZaliymN fiI Alxubori [A she-wolf among the goats, and a heostrich when tried]: i. e., in his evil nature he is like a [she-] wolf that attacks a herd of goats; and when tried, like a he-ostrich, which, if one say to it “Fly,” says “I am a camel,” and when one says to it “Carry a burden,” says “I am a bird:” a prov. applied to a crafty and deceitful person. (TA.)

And Oakalahumo AlD-abuEu waAlc-iYobu [The hyena and the wolf devoured them]; meaning ‡ dearth, or drought: and OaSaAbatohumo sanapN DabuEN waciYobN, meaning ‡ A year that was one of dearth, or drought, befell them. (A.)

ciYobuhu laA yaXobaEu [His wolf will not be satiated], a phrase used by a poet, means † his tongue [will not be satisfied]; i. e. he devours the reputation of another like as the wolf devours flesh. (M.)
ciYobu yuwsufa [The wolf of Joseph] is a prov. applied to him who is charged with the crime of another. (TA.)

cuWobaAnu AlEarabi, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) also pronounced cuwbaAn, without C, (TA,) [The wolves of the Arabs,] means ‡ the thieves, (M, Ḳ,) or sharpers, (A,) and paupers, (A, Ḳ,) of the Arabs; (M, A, Ḳ;) or the paupers of the Arabs, who practise thieving: (T, Ṣ:) because they act like wolves. (TA.)

ciYaAbu AlgaDaA The wolves of the ghadà, that frequent the trees so called, (TA,) is an appellation of the sons of Kaab Ibn-Málik Ibn-Handhalah; (M, Ḳ;) because of their bad character; (M;) for the wolf that frequents those trees is the worst of wolves. (TA.)

daMCu Alc-iYobi [The wolf's disease] means † hunger; for they assert that the wolf has no other disease than hunger; (Ḳ, TA;) and they say OajowaEu mino ciYobK [More hungry than a wolf]; because he is always hungry: or † death; because [it is said that] the wolf has no other sickness than that of death; and hence they say OaSaH-u mina Alc-iYobi [More sound than the wolf]. (TA.) [Hence the prov., ramaAhu Qll-ehu bidaMCi Alc-iYobi: see 1 in art. rmI.]

Alc-iYobaAni, in the dual form, [The two wolves,] is the name of † two white stars [app. ζ and η of Draco] between those called AlEawaAYicu and those called AlfaroqadaAni: and OaZofaAru Alc-iYobi [The claws of the wolf] is the name of † certain small stars before those called Alc-iYobaAni. (Ḳ.)
Einabu Alc-iYobi: see vaEolabN.
See also the next paragraph.

hom.sense: ciYobapN fem. of ciYobN. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

Also † The [angular] intervening space between the daf-ataAni [or two boards] of the [kinds of saddle called] saroj and raHol (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and gabiyT, (TA,) beneath the place of juncture of the two curved pieces of wood; (Ṣ;) [or] what is beneath the fore part of the place of juncture of the two curved pieces of wood (M, Ḳ) of the [kinds of saddle called] raHol and qatab and UikaAf and the like; (M;) which falls, or lies, upon, (Ṣ,) or bites, or compresses, (M, Ḳ,) the part called the manosij (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) of the beast. (M, Ḳ.) A poet says,
waqatabN ciYobatuhu kaQlominojali
[And a qtb of which the cYbp is like the reapinghook]. (M.) [See qarabuwsN.] Accord. to IAạr, the ciYob↓ [a coll. gen. n. of which ciYobapN is the n. un.] of the [saddle called] raHol are The curved pieces of wood in the fore part thereof. (TA.)

Also † A certain disease of horses (T, M, Mgh, Ḳ) or similar beasts, that attacks them in their fauces; (M, Ḳ;) for which the root of the beast's ear is perforated with an iron instrument, and there are extracted from it small, white, hard nodous substances, (T, Mgh, Ḳ,*) like the grains of the [species of millet called] jaAwaros, (Ḳ,) or smaller than those grains. (T, Mgh.)
ciYobaAnN a pl. of ciYbN. (TA.)

Also, accord. to AA, (Ṣ,) The hair upon the neck and lip of the camel: (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and accord. to Fr, who says that it is a sing. [in this sense], (Ṣ,) the remains of the [fur, or soft hair, called] wabar [after the greater part has fallen off or been shorn]. (Ṣ, Ḳ. [See also cuwbaAnN in art. cwbo, and ciybaAnN in art. cyb.])

entry.sense: cuWaAbN: see the next paragraph.

cuWaAbapN (also pronounced cuwaAbapN, T and Ḳ in art. cwb,) A portion [or lock] of hair, (Ṣ, A,) hanging down loosely from the middle of the head to the back: (A:) or the hair of the fore part of the head; the hair over the forehead; syn. naASiyapN; (M, Ḳ;) so called because, hanging down, it moves to and fro, or from side to side: (M:) or the place whence that hair grows: (M, Ḳ:) or the hair that surrounds the duw-aArap [or round part] of the head: (AZ, T:) or plaited hair of the head: and the part of the head which is the place thereof: (Lth, T:) or a plait of hair hanging down: if twisted, it is called EaqiySapN: (Mṣb:) and [a horse's forelock; or] hair (M, Ḳ) of the head, (M,) in the upper part of the naASiyap, of the horse: (M, Ḳ:) pl. (in all its senses, M, TA) cawaAYibu, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) originally, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or regularly, (T,) caMYibu, changed to render it more easy of pronunciation, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and cuWaAbaAtN also. (Mṣb.) Hence, futila cawaAYibuhu [His pendent locks of hair were twisted;] meaning ‡ he was made to abandon, or relinquish, his opinion or idea or judgment. (A.)

† Anything that hangs down loosely. (TA.) ‡ The end of a turban, (A, Mṣb,) that hangs down between the shoulders. (A.) † The end of a whip. (Mṣb.) ‡ Of a sandal. The thing, or portion, that hangs down from, or of, [the upper part of] the qibaAl [or thong that passes, from the sole, between two of the toes; it is generally a prolongation of the qibaAl]: (T:) or the part that touches the ground, of the thing that is made to fall down upon the foot, (M, A, Ḳ,) attached to the XiraAk [or thong extending from the qibaAl above mentioned towards the ankle]; (A;) so called because of its waggling. (M.) ‡ Of a sword, The thong [or cord] which is attached to the hilt, (T, A,) and which [is sometimes also made fast to the guard, and at other times] hangs loose and dangles. (A.) † A skin, or piece of skin, that is hung upon the Mxirap [or hinder part] of the [camel's saddle called] raHol; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) also termed EacabapN. (TA.) A poet speaks, metaphorically, of the cawaAYib of palmtrees [app. meaning ‡ Hanging clusters of dates]. (M.) And one says naArN saATiEapN Alc-awaAYibi ‡ [A fire of which the flames rise and spread]. (A.)

Also † The higher, or highest, part of anything: (M, Ḳ:) and cuWaAbN↓ is used as its pl., or [as a coll. gen. n., i. e.] as bearing the same relation to cuWaAbapN that sal-N does to sal-apN. (M.) You say, EalawotN cuWaAbapa Aljabali ‡ [I ascended upon the summit of the mountain]. (A.) And cuWaAbapu AlEiz-i waAlX-arafi ‡ The highest degree of might and of nobility. (T,* M.) And huwa fiI cuWaAbapi qawomihi † He is among the highest of his people; taken from the cWAbp of the head. (M.) And humo cuWaAbapu qawomihimo (T, A) and cawaAYibuhumo (A) ‡ They are the nobles of their people: (A, T:) and mino cawaAYibi qurayoXK ‡ of the nobles of Kureysh. (TA.) And fulaAnN mina Alc-anaAYibi laA mina Alc-awaAYibi ‡ [Such a one is of the lowest of the people, not of the highest]. (A.)
cawaAYibu AljawozaMCu is a name of † Nine stars disposed in a bowed, or curved, form, in the sleeve of Orion; also called taAju AljawozaMCi. (Ḳzw in his description of Orion.)
cawAYibu layolapK † The last, or latter, parts, or portions, of a night. (Ḥar p. 58.)
OaroDN macoOabapN A land containing, (Ṣ,) or abounding with, (M, Ḳ,) wolves: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) in the dial. of some of the tribe of Keys, macayobapN, agreeing with ciybN. (M.)
mucaO-abN A boy having a cuWaAbap. (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
And † A [camel's saddle such as is called] gabiyT [&c.] having [a cuWaAbap, i. e.] a skin, or piece of skin, hung upon its Mxirap [or hinder part]: (Ṣ:) or having a ciYobap [q. v.]. (TA.)

hom.sense: macoWuwbN A man frightened by wolves: (A, TA:) or whose sheep, or goats, have been fallen upon by the wolf. (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ.)
[And hence,] ‡ Frightened [as though by a wolf]. (T, TA.)

Also A horse, (Mgh,) or such as is called birocawonN, (Lth, T, M, Ḳ,) and, accord. to the Tekmileh, an ass, and so macobuwbN, as though from ciybapN for ciYobapN, (Mgh,) Affected with the disease termed ciYobapN. (Lth, T, M, Mgh, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: mutacaAYibN † A man in a state of commotion, or fluctuation; from tacaMCabati Alr-iyHu. (TA from a trad.)
caAtiI-N and caAtiy-apN: see art. cw.

hom.sense: 1. caYira Ealayohi, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA,) aor. _a {yacoOaru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. caOarN, (M,) He was angry with him: (M,* Ḳ,* TA:) he was enraged against him, namely his enemy, and prepared to spring upon him. (Lth.)
He became emboldened against him. (Ṣ * Ḳ,* TA.)
caYira, aor. _a {yacoOaru}, He became contracted in his bosom, and evil in his disposition. (Ibn-Es-Seed.)
He was frightened, or terrified; he feared, or was afraid. (M, Ḳ.)

He was disdainful, or averse [from a person or thing]; or he disdained, or scorned: (Ḳ:) he became affected with aversion and disapprobation: ʼObeyd Ibn-El-Abras says,
caYiruwA liqatolaI EaAmirK watagaD-abuwA
meaning They became affected with aversion and disapprobation on account of the slain of 'Ámir [and became angry]: (T, Ṣ:) or, as some say, were disdainful, or averse, thereat. (T.)
caYirahu, (aor. _a {yacoOaru} TA,) He disliked, or hated, it, and turned away, or back, from it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

caYirato EalaIzawojihaA, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and caMCarato↓, (Ḳ,) contracted by El-Hoteiäh into caArato, (TA,) [see also art. cr,] She was disobedient to her husband, and hated him; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) was averse from him; and became emboldened against him. (Aṣ, Ṣ.)
caYira biAlX-aIoCi He became accustomed, or habituated, to the thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
cOara Aln-aAqapa He smeared the she-camels' teats with ciYaAr, that her young one might not such her. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. caMCarato: see 1.
Also She (a camel) was averse from her young one when she brought it forth. (TA.)
4. OacoOarahu Ealayohi He made him angry with him. (M, Ḳ.*) AʼObeyd has transposed, and then changed, one of its letters, saying OacoraAniI, which is a mistake. (M.)
AcOrhu, (inf. n. UicoMrN, AZ, Ṣ,) He excited him to animosity; (AZ, T, Ṣ;) incited him; (AZ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) emboldened him; (Ḳ;) biSaAHibihi [against his companion]. (AZ, Ṣ, M.)
AcOrhu UilaI XaIoCK, (M, Ḳ,*) and AcOrhu XayoYFA, (TA,) He constrained or compelled or necessitated him to have recourse to, or to do, a thing. (M, Ḳ,* TA.)
caYirN: see caAYirN, in two places.
Uin-a XuWuwnaka lacaYirapN (Ṣ, Ḳ *) Verily thy tears are accompanied by a breathing, or sighing, (tanaf-us,) like that of the angry. (Ḳ.)
ciYaArN Fresh camels' or similar dung, (baEar,) mixed with dust, or earth, with which a she-camel's teats are smeared, that she may not be sucked. (M,* Ḳ,* TA.) [See also art. cyr.]
caAYirN Angry; (IAạr, T, Ḳ;) as also caYirN↓. (Ḳ.)
Contracted in the bosom, and evil in disposition. (Ibn-Es-Seed.)
Disdaining, or averse [from a person or thing]: disdainful; scornful. (IAạr, T.)

A woman disobedient to her husband, and hating him; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) averse from him; and emboldened against him; (Ṣ;) as also caYirN↓, and mucaAYirN↓: (Ḳ:) [all without caAYirN:] and in a similar sense caAYirN is applied to a man. (Ṣ,* TA.)
mucaAYirN: see caAYirN.

Also, [without p,] A she-camel averse from her young one when she has just brought it forth: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or that makes a show of affection with her nose [by smelling her young one] (taroOamu biOanofihaA), and has not true love: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or evil in disposition. (M.)

hom.sense: 1. caOafa, aor. _a {yacoOafu}, inf. n. caOafaAnN, [in the CK caOofAn,] He died: (Moḥeeṭ, Ḳ, TA:) [or he died quickly: see caOofN, which is app. an inf. n, as also, perhaps, cuWaAfN.]
caOofahu, and caOafa Ealayohi, inf. n. caOofN and caOafN, He despatched him; namely, a wounded man; or hastened and completed his slaughter. (M.)
And yacoOafu is also said of poison [app. as meaning It kills quickly]. (Lth, T.)
mar-a yacoOafuhumo He passed by driving them away, or pursuing them, or destroying them. (M.)

entry.sense: 7. AncOf His heart broke (AinoqaTaEa fuWaAduhu). (Ḳ.) [See its syn. AncEf.]
caOofN Quickness of death; (Lth, T, M, Ḳ;) as also cuWaAfN↓. (Ḳ.) [See 1, first sentence.]
Also an inf. n. of caOafahu. (M.)
caOofaAnN: see ciYofaAnN.
Accord. to the Ḳ, it signifies also Death: but the correct word seems to be caOafaAnN, [see 1, first sentence,] as in the Tekmileh. (TA.)
cuWofaAnN: see what next follows.

ciYofaAnN (Lth, T, M, Ḳ) Poison that kills quickly (yacoOafu): (Lth, T:) or simply poison; (M, Ḳ;) as also cuWofaAnN↓ and caOofaAnN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) all with C (TA,) and ciyfaAnN (AʼObeyd, T, M, Ḳ) and cayofaAnN (AʼObeyd, T, Ḳ) and cayafaAnN and cuwfaAnN, (IDrd, Ḳ,) and cuWaAfN↓. (T, Ḳ: the last, in the TA, without C.)

hom.sense: cuWaAfN Death that despatches quickly; (T, M, Ḳ;) as also cuEaAfN; thought by Yaạḳoob to be an instance of permutation. (M.)
See also ciYofaAnN.
And see caOofN.

entry.sense: 1. caOala, (T, Ḳ,) or caOalato, (Ṣ,) aor. _a {yacoOalu}, inf. n. caOalaAnN (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) and caOolN or caOalN, (accord. to different copies of the Ṣ and Ḳ, the latter accord. to the TA,) He, (T, Ḳ,) or she, i. e. a camel, (Ṣ,) walked, or went, lightly: (AZ, T, Ṣ:) or quickly: (Ḳ:) or lightly, (Ḳ,) or quickly, (IF,) and proudly, with an inclining of the body from side to side. (IF, Ḳ.) [See also daOala: and see caOalaAnN, below.]
6. tcMCl He became vile, base, ignominious, abject, or contemptible; syn. tSAgr. (Ḳ.)

caOolaAnN, (Ḳ,) or caOalaAnN↓, (ISk, Ṣ, M,) and cuOolaAnN↓, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,) The jackal (Aibonu MwaI): or the wolf: (Ḳ:) or the second word has the latter signification: (ISk, Ṣ, M:) and the last word, the former signification: (M:) the pl. of the second word, having the latter signification, is caMliylu, with l. (ISk, Ṣ.) [See also daOolaAnN and daOalaAnN: and see cuWaAlapN, below.]
cuwolaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: caOalaAnN The walk, or manner of going, of the wolf: pl. caMliylu, with l: (M, Ḳ:) [but ISd says,] I know not how this is. (M. [See also daMliylu.]) Also [as an inf. n. of 1, q. v.,] A quick walk or manner of going: (M:) or, as some say, a moderate running: or an extraordinary manner, or rate, of going, by reason of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness. (T.)
See also caOolaAnN.

entry.sense: caWuwlN Anything [or any animal] Quick, or swift. (T.) [See also daWuwlN.]

cuWaAlapu The wolf: (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) so called because of his light walk or manner of going; (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ;) or because of a lightness in his running: (M:) it is determinate, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) and imperfectly decl., being a proper name and [grammatically] of the fem. gender: (TA:) pl. ciYolaAnN and cuWolaAnN. (M, Ḳ.) One says, xaX-i cuWaAlapa baAlHibaAlapi [Frighten thou the wolf with the snare]: (Ṣ, Meyd, TA:) a prov., applied to him whose threatening is not regarded: meaning threaten thou other than me; for I know thee: (Meyd, TA:)
or, accord. to AʼObeyd, said by him who orders one to menace and threaten. (Meyd.) [See also caOolaAnN.]
micoOalN Light and quick. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)

1. caOamahu, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yacoOamu}, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. caOomN, (Ṣ,* M,) He blamed, or found fault with, him, or it; (T, Ṣ, Mṣb;) namely, a man, (T, [in which it is said that caOamotuhu in the sense of Eibotuhu is more common than camamotuhu,” though the contr. seems to be manifestly the case,]) or a commodity; (Mṣb;) and he despised him; like caOabahu: (Ṣ:) and he despised him and beat him: (T:) and he despised him and blamed him: (T, M, Ḳ:) or he despised him and drove him away; like caOabahu: (M:) and simply he drove him away: (M, Ḳ:) or he drove him away and beat him; like caOabahu: (M and TA in art. cOb:) and he repaid him, or requited him; syn. jazaAhu: (T and M:) or he overcame him in abasing; syn. xazaAhu. (Ḳ and TA. [So in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ and in the CK: but I doubt not that jazaAhu is the right reading.])
4. AcOmhu, (TA,) inf. n. UicoMmN, (Ḳ, TA,) He frightened him, or terrified him; syn. of the inf. n. ruEobN. (Ḳ, TA.)
OacoOamotaniI EalaI kacaA Thou compelledst me against my will to do such a thing. (Fr, Ṣ.)
caOomN i. q. EayobN [as a subst., meaning A vice, fault, defect, or the like; like caAmN, without C, and cayomN; as well as an inf. n. of 1, q. v.]: with and without C (Ṣ.)
caOomapN A word: so in the saying, maA samiEotu lahu caOomapF [I heard not a word that he had to utter]. (Ḳ.)
macoWuwmN pass. part. n. of 1. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) macoWuwmFA in the Ḳur [vii. 17] means Blamed: (TA:) or driven away: (M, TA:) or, accord. to Lḥ and Mujáhid, banished. (T, TA.*)
1. caOanahu, [aor. _a {yacoOanu},] inf. n. caOonN, [app. from cuWonuwnN, q. v.,] He held his state, or condition, to be contemptible and weak. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. caOonanati AlOaroDu The land produced the kind of plant called cuWonuwn. (IAạr, M.)

R. Q. 2. xarajuwA yatadaOonanuwna (Ṣ, so in both of my copies, and Ḳ and TḲ, but [erroneously] written in the TT as from the M ytcOonwn, and in some copies of the Ḳ yatacaMYanuwna, or yatacaMCanuwna, [the verb being evidently a denominative from cuWonuwnN like tajalobaba from jilobaAbN,]) They went forth (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) to take, (Ṣ,) or to seek and take, (M,) or to gather, (Ḳ,) the kind of plant called cuWonuwn (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

cuWonuwnN [A kind, or species, of fungus; perhaps a species of phallus;] a certain plant, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the same kind as the Eurojuwn and the Turovuwvi, which grows in the winter, and, when the day becomes hot, rots, and goes away; (IAạr, T;) said by Abu-l-ʼOmeythil to be, in form, like the hiloyawon [or asparagus]: (T:) pl. caMniynu: (T, Ṣ:) and some pronounce the sing. cuwnuwnN, without C; and make the pl. cawaAniynu: (T, TA:) a certain plant that grows at the roots of the OaroTaI and rimov and OalaMC; the ground cleaving, and disclosing it, it comes forth like the sawaAEid [app. here meaning the upper arms, above the elbows,] of men; has no leaves; is black (OasoHamu), and dustcoloured; is pointed [and roundish] in its extremity, like the glans of the penis in form; has envelopes (OakomaAmu) like those of the [bean called] baAqil-aI; and has a yellow fruit at its upper part: some say that it is a plant that grows like the [fungi called] EaraAjiyn, of the plants termed fuTor: AḤn says that what are termed caMniyn are things of the [fungi called] fuquwE, that come forth from beneath the ground like thick Eumud [or poles]; nothing eats them, except that camels feed upon them in the year of drought, and goats eat them and fatten upon them; they have a root-stock (Oaruwmap); and are used as medicines; and none but the hungry will eat them, because of their bitterness: he also says in one place, they grow at the roots of trees, most like to the asparagus (hiloyawon), except that they are larger and thicker; and have no leaves; but they have a buroEuwmap [app. here meaning a head, such as is termed a pileus, or cap], which assumes a roseate colour, and then changes to yellow: the cWnwn is all [full of] water [or juice]; and is white, except what appears thereof, of that buroEuwmap; and nothing eats it, except when men are afflicted with drought and have nothing [else] to eat: the n. un. is with p {cuWonuwnapN}: (M:) ISh says that it is of a tawny colour, smooth and round, having leaves that stick to it, tall like the Turovuwv, not eaten save by sheep or goats, [and grows] in plain, or soft, tracts: IB says that it is the wild hiloyawon. (TA.) One says of a people who were characterized by courage and excellence, and who have perished, their state having changed, caMniynu laA rimova lahaA waTaraAviyvu laA OaroTaI [Dhu-noonehs having no rimthehs, and turthoothehs having no artáhs]: meaning that they have been extirpated, and that none of them remains: (TA:) or cMnyn lA rmv lhA is a prov. applied to him who is ruined, and has nothing remaining, after having had a family and dignity and wealth. (TA voce TurovuwvN.)

hom.sense: 1. cab-a Eanohu, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. _u {yacobubu}, (T, M, Mṣb,) inf. n. cab-N, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) He repelled from him: he defended him. (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, yacub-u Eano Hariymihi He repels from, or defends, his wife, or wives, or the like. (T, Mṣb.) [See also R. Q. 1.]

And cab-N signifies also The act of driving away. (T, TA.) You say, cab-a Alc-ubaAba, and cb-bhu↓, He drove away the fly, or flies. (M, TA.) And AlwaHoXu tacub-u Albaq-a biOaconaAbihaA [The wild animals drive away the gnats with their tails]. (A.)
And [hence,] OataAhumo xaATibN facab-uwhu ‡ One demanding a woman in marriage came to them, and they rejected him, or turned him back. (A, TA.)
cub-a † He (a man, TA) was, or became, possessed; or mad, or insane. (Ḳ, TA.)

cab-a, (M, Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yacobubu}, [irreg., (the verb being intrans.,) unless the first pers. be cabubotu, like labubotu, &c.,] inf. n. cab-N, (M,) He (a man, Ḳ) went hither and thither, not remaining in one place. (M, Ḳ.*)

cab-a, [aor. _i {yacobibu},] It dried; dried up; or became dry. (T.) You say, cab-ato Xafatuhu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yacobibu}, inf. n. cab-N and cababN and cubuwbN, (M, Ḳ,) His lip became dry, (M, Ḳ,) or lost its moisture, (Ṣ,) by reason of thirst, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or by reason of vehement thirst, (M,), &c.; (M, Ḳ;) as also cab-abato↓. (M, Ḳ.) And cab-a lisaAnuhu (Ṣ, M) in like manner [His tongue became dry, &c.]. (M.) And cab-a said of a plant, It withered, or lost its moisture. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And said of a pool of water left by a torrent, It dried up in the end of the hot season. (IAạr, M, Ḳ.) And cab-a jisomuhu His body became lean, or emaciated, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and lost its moisture. (TA.) And cab-a, (T, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yacobibu}, inf. n. cab-N, (T,) His colour, or complexion, became altered, by reason of emaciation or hunger or travel, &c. (T, Ḳ.)
See also 2.
2. cb-b Eanohu He repelled from him, or defended him, much, or often. (Ṣ.)
cb-b Alc-ubaAba: see 1.
cab-abato Xafatuhu: see 1.

[cab-aba, inf. n. tacobiybN, also signifies It left a cubaAbap, i. e. somewhat remaining. Hence,] cb-b Aln-ahaAru (Ṣ, A, TA,) or cab-a↓, (so in the Ḳ, but corrected in the TA,) ‡ The day passed so as to leave thereof only a cubaAbap; (A, TA;*) i. e. (TA) the day had only a [small] remainder of it left. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) And TaEonN waramoIN gayoru tacobiybK ‡ A thrusting, or piercing, and a shooting, or casting, with energy [so as not to leave any force unexerted]. (Ṣ,* A, TA.)

[Also It left not a cubaAbap, i.e. anything remaining: thus bearing two contr. significations. Hence,] cb-b fiI Als-ayori ‡ He strove, laboured, toiled, or exerted himself, in going, or journeying, so that he left not a cubaAbap [or any part of his journey remaining unaccomplished]: (A, TA:) [or] cb-b signifies † he hastened, made haste, or sped; syn. OasoraEa: (M:) [and, accord. to Et-Tebreezee, this is the primary signification: for he says,] Alt-acobiybN is like AlT-iraAdu [app. as meaning † the act of charging, by a horse or a horseman]: but the primary meaning is AlUisoraAEu. (Ḥam p. 207.) And cab-abonaA layolatanaA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tacobiybN, (Ḳ,) † Our beasts became fatigued, or jaded, by journeying [during that our night]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
R. Q. 1. cabocabN, (T,) inf. n. cabocabapN, (Ḳ,) He defended his neighbours and family. (T, Ḳ.) [See also 1.]
And He annoyed, molested, harmed, or hurt, (T, Ḳ,) people. (Ḳ.)

And He made a thing to dangle, or move to and fro; (L;)
and made it to be in a state of motion, commotion, or agitation. (L, Ḳ.*)
[Hence,] cabocabahu, inf. n. as above, † He left him, or made him to be, confounded, or perplexed, not knowing his right course; wavering, vacillating, or going to and fro. (Mṣb.)

cabocabapN also signifies The dangling, or moving to and fro, of a thing suspended in the air: (Ṣ, M:) and tacabocubN↓ the being in a state of motion or commotion: (Ṣ, L:) [or the latter has both these meanings; for] you say, tacabocaba↓ AlX-aIoCu the thing dangled, or moved to and fro, (M, A, L,) in the air; (A;) and was in a state of commotion or agitation. (M, L.) It is said in a trad., fakaOan-iI OanoZuru UilaI yadayohi tucabocibaAni, meaning And it was as though I looked at his two sleeves in a state of commotion, or shaking. (TA.) And you say, tcabocaba↓ bayona Oamorayoni † He wavered, or vacillated, between two affairs. (MA.) And tacabocaba↓ Oamoruhumo † [Their state of affairs was, or became, fluctuating, or unsteady]. (Lḥ, T in art. dl.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 2. tacabocaba, inf. n. tacabocubN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

hom.sense: cab-N Repelling: fem. with p {cab-apN}: hence cab-aAtu Als-abiybi, a phrase used by Dhu-r-Rummeh, meaning repelling with their tails: or this may be from the signification next following. (Ḥam p. 510.)

Much in motion. (Ḥam ubi suprà.) cab-N, (M, L,) or caAb-N↓, (Ḳ,) [the former correct, and perhaps the latter also,] applied to a camel, That does not, or will not, remain still, or motionless, in a place. (M, L, Ḳ.) A poet says,
fakaOan-anaA fiyhimo jimaAlN cab-apN
[And it was as though we were, among them, camels that would not remain still in a place]: which shows that cab-N is not an inf. n. used as an epithet; for, were it so, he had said jimaAlN cab-N. (M, L.)

Alc-ab-u ‡ The wild bull; [a species of bovine antelope;] also called cab-u Alr-iyaAdi; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) so called because he goes to and fro, not remaining in one place; (M;) or because he pastures going to and fro; (T, Ṣ,* M;) or because his females pasture with him, going to and fro: (T:) and called also AlOacab-u↓, (T, Ḳ,) by poetic license, for Alc-ab-u; (T;) and Alc-unobubu↓. (Ḳ.)
cab-u Alr-iyaAdi is also applied to ‡ A man who goes and comes. (Kr, M, TA.) And ‡ A man who is in the habit of visiting women. (AA, T, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: cubaAbN [The common fly;] the black thing that is in houses, that falls into the vessel and into food; (M;) well known: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so called, accord. to Ed-Demeeree, because of its fluttering about, or because it returns as often as it is driven away: (TA:) and likewise applied to the bee; (M, Ḳ;) which is also called cubaAbu Algayovi [the fly of the rain], (IAth, TA,) or cubaAbu gayovK [the fly of rain]; because the rain is the means of producing herbage, and by herbage it is fed; (Mgh;) or because it accompanies rain, and lives upon that which the rain causes to grow: (IAth, TA:) [accord. to some, it is a coll. gen. n.; and] the n. un. is cubaAbapN↓: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) one should not say cib-aAnapN [as the vulgar do in the present day]: (Ṣ:) or one should not say cubaAbapN↓, though El-Aḥmar and Ks are related to have used this word [as meaning a kind of fly]; for cubaAbN is a sing. [properly speaking], and is used as such in the Ḳur xxii. 72: (M:) the pl. (of pauc., Ṣ, Mṣb) is Oacib-ahN and (of mult., Ṣ, Mṣb) cib-aAnN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and cub-N, (M, Ḳ,) the last mentioned by Sb, accord. to the dial. of Temeem. (M.) One says, Uin-ahu laOawohaI mina Alc-ubaAbi [Verily he is more frail than the fly]. (A.) And huwa Oahowanu EalaI-a mino Taniyni Alc-ubaAbi [He is more contemptible to me than the buzzing of the fly]. (A.) manojaI Alc-ubaAbi [The refuge of the fly] is a prov., applied to him who is protected by his ignobleness. (Ḥar p. 332: there written manojaA; and in two places, mnjO.) And Oabuw Alc-ubaAbi [The father of the fly] is an appellation used as meaning † He who has stinking breath; and some say Oabuw Alc-ib-aAni [the father of the flies]: (M, TA:) and is especially applied to ʼAbd-El-Melik Ibn-Marwán: (M, A, TA:) whence the saying, Oaboxaru mino OabiI Alc-ubaAbi (A, TA) and OabiI Alc-ib-aAni (TA) [More stinking in breath than Abu-dh-Dhubáb and Abu-dh-Dhibbán].

[Hence,] ‡ Evil, or mischief; (A, Ḳ;) and annoyance, or harm; as in the saying, OaSaAbaniI cubaAbN ‡ [Evil, &c., befell me]; (A;) and OaSaAba fulaAnFA mino fulaAnK cubaAbN laAciEN † Evil, or mischief, [lit. a hurting fly] fell upon such a one from such a one: (T:) or ‡ continual evil, as in the saying, OaSaAbaka cubaAbN mino hecaA AlOamori ‡ [Continual evil hath befallen thee from this thing, or event]; and Xar-uhaA cubaAbN ‡ [Her, or its, or their, evil is a continual evil]. (TA.)
† Ill luck. (T, Ḳ.) Fr relates that the Prophet saw a man with long hair; and said cubaAbN, meaning † This is ill luck: and hence, rajulN cubaAbiI-N↓ † [An unlucky man]. (T.)
† Plague, or pestilence. (TA.)
† Diabolical possession; or madness, or insanity. (Ḳ.)
† Ignorance: so in the phrase rajulN maHoXiI-N Alc-ubaAbi † [A man stuffed with ignorance]. (M.)

‡ The UinosaAn [as meaning the pupil, or apple,] of the eye: (AZ, T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) so in the saying, huwa OaEaz-u EalaI-a mino cubaAbi AlEayoni ‡ [He is dearer to me than the apple of the eye]: (A:) [ISd says,] I think it to be so termed as being likened to the cubaAb [properly so called; i.e. the fly]. (M.) And Alc-ubaAbu also signifies † A black speck, or spot, in the interior of the Hadaqap [or dark part] of the eye of the horse. (M, Ḳ.) The pl. is as above. (M.)

cubaAbu Als-ayofi (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and cubaAbapN↓ Als-ayofi (TA) ‡ The Had-, (M, Ḳ,) or Taraf, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) [each app. here meaning the point, or extremity, though the former also means the edge,] of the sword, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is the part wherewith one strikes: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or its extremity with which one is pierced, or transpierced; and the Had- [here meaning edge] with which one strikes is called its giraAr: (En-Naḍr, T:) or its tapering, or pointed, extremity; expl. by Tarafuhu AlmutaTar-ifu: (M, Ḳ:) or the point (Had-) of its extremity (M, A) which is between its XaforataAni: (M:) the parts of its two edges that are on either side of it are its ZubataAni: the ridge in the middle of it, on the inner and outer sides, is called the Eayor; and each has what are termed giraAraAni, which are the part between the Eayor and each one of the ZubataAni on the outer side of the sword and the corresponding portion of the inner side, each of the giraAraAni being on the inner side of the sword and its outer side. (AZ, T, TA.) [The swords of the Arabs, in the older times, were generally straight, twoedged, and tapering to a point; and so are many of them in the present day; a little wider towards the point than towards the hilt.] Hence the saying, vamarapu Als-awoTi yatobaEuhaA cubaAbu Als-ayofi ‡ [The knot, or tail, at the end of the whip is followed by the point of the sword; i. e., whipping (if it effect not the desired correction) is followed by slaughter]. (A.)
[Hence,] cubaAbN signifies likewise † The Had- [or point, or extremity, or edge,] of anything. (AʼObeyd, T.)
‡ The pointed, or sharp, part of the extremity of the ear (AʼObeyd, M, Ḳ) of a horse (AʼObeyd, M) and of a man. (M.)
† The sharp edge of the teeth of camels. (Ṣ, TA.)
And † The part that first comes forth of the flower of the Hin-aMC (M, Ḳ.)
cubaAbapN: see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence, in two places:
and see another sentence, in the latter half of the same paragraph.

‡ A remainder, or remains, (T, Ṣ, M, A,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a thing, (T, Mṣb,) of the waters of wells, (T,) or of thirst, (M, A,) and of hunger, (A,) and of a debt, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and the like, (Ṣ,) and of the day, (A,) or, as some say, of anything; (M;) or of a thing that is sound, or valid, or substantial; distinguished from dunaAnapN, which signifies a remainder, or remains, of a thing that is weak, or frail, and perishing, and particularly of a debt, or of a promise: (Ṣ and L in art. cn:) pl. cubaAbaAtN. (T, Ṣ, Mṣb.) You say, Sadarati AlUibilu wabihaA cubaAbapN, (M,) or bihaA cubaAbapN mino ZamaOK (A,) i. e. ‡ [The camels returned from water having in them] somewhat remaining of thirst. (M.)
And the pl. cubaAbaAtN also signifies † Small mountains: so says El-Andalusee. (MF.)
cubaAbiI-N: see cubaAbN.

hom.sense: cab-aAbN A man who repels from, or defends, with energy, his wife, or wives, or the like; as also micab-N↓. (M, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] yiwomN cab-aAbN ‡ A sultry day in which the wild animals are infested by numerous gnats, and drive them away with their tails: the act being thus attributed to the day. (A.)
See also what next follows.

entry.sense: XafapN cab-aAnapN, the latter word of the measure faEolaAnapN, in some of the copies of the Ḳ erroneously written cab-aAbapN↓, (TA,) [and so in the TT as from the M,] A lip that has become dry, or has lost its moisture. (M, Ḳ, TA.)

cabocabN The penis, (T,* Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) as some say; (M;) as also cabocabapN↓ and cabaAcibu↓, which last is not a pl., (Ḳ,) though of a pl. measure; (TA;)
so called because of the motion thereof, to and fro: (TA:) and the tongue: (M, A:) or cabocabapN↓ has this latter meaning: (Ḳ:) and cabaAcibu↓ signifies the genitals; or, as some say, the testicles; (M;) one of which is termed cabocabapN↓. (M, Ḳ.)
cubocubN: see cabaAcibu.
cibocibN: see cabaAcibu, in two places.
cabocabapN: see cabocabN, in three places:
and see also cabaAcibu.

cabaAcibu Certain things that are hung to the [women's camel-vehicle called] hawodaj, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or to the head of a camel, (M,) for ornament; [i. e. tassels, or pendant tufts of wool, or shreds of woollen cloth, of various colours; (see raEavN;)] as also cabocabapN↓: (M, Ḳ:) the sing. of the former is cibocibN↓, (T,) or cubocubN↓, with damm. (TA.)
And The fringes, and edges, of a [garment of the kind called] burodap; because of their motion upon the wearer when he walks: sing. cibocibN↓. (TA from a trad.)
See also cabocabN, in two places.
caAb-N: see cab-N.
Alc-unobubu: see cab-N.

hom.sense: Oacab-u: see macobuwbN:
and cab-N.
Also The tush, or canine tooth, of the camel. (T, Ḳ.)
And Tall, or long; syn. TawiylN. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: micab-N: see cab-aAbN.
OaroDN macab-apN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and macobuwbapN↓ (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ) A land containing, (Ṣ,) or abounding with, (M, Ḳ,) flies. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

micab-apN A thing with which one drives away flies; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;*) a fly-whisk made of horse-hairs: (T:) [pl. macaAbN whence,] one says of wild-animals, OaconaAbuhaA macaAb-uhaA ‡ [Their tails are their fly-whisks]. (A.)

mucab-ibN ‡ A rider hastening, or making haste, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) apart from others: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or striving, labouring, toiling, or exerting himself, in going, or journeying, so as to leave not a cubaAbap [or any part of his journey remaining unaccomplished]. (A.) And it is also applied to a [wild] bull. (A.) In the following saying,
masiyrapNXahorK lilobaEiyri Almucabocibi↓
† [A month's journey to the hastening camel], (M,) or lilobariydi Almucabocibi [to the hastening messenger], (TA,) by Almcbcb is meant Almucab-ib. (M, TA.)

[† A quick journey: or one in which is no flagging, or langour.] You say, laA yanaAluwna AlmaMCi Uil-aA biqarabK mucab-ibK, i. e. † [They will not reach the water but by a] quick [night-journey thereto]. (Ṣ.) And ximosN mucab-ibN † [A journey in which the camels are watered only on the first and fifth days] in which is no flagging, or langour. (T.)
ZimoCN mucab-ibN † [An interval between two water-ings] of long duration, in which one journeys from afar (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and with haste. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

macobuwbN A camel attacked by flies, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, M,) that enter his nostrils, (Ṣ,) so that his neck becomes twisted, and he dies; as also Oacab-u↓: or both signify one that, coming to a cultivated region, finds it unwholesome to him, and dies there: (M:) and the former, a horse into whose nostril the fly has entered. (A.)
See also OaroDN macab-apN, above.
Also † Possessed; or mad, or insane. (Ḳ.)
And, accord. to the Abridgment of the ʼEyn, [in a copy of the Ṣ written cabuwbN, and in other copies thereof omitted,] † Foolish; stupid; or unsound, dull, or deficient, in intellect. (TA.)

mucabocabN Driven away: (TA:) or driven away, or repelled, much. (T, TA.) It is said in a trad., tazaw-ajo waUil-aA faOanota mina Almucabocabiyna, i. e. [Marry, or thou wilt be of] those driven away from the believers because thou hast not imitated them, and from the monks because thou hast forsaken their institutes: from Alc-ab-u “the act of driving away:” or, accord. to IAth, it may be from the signification of “motion and agitation.” (TA.) And it is said in the Ḳur [iv. 142], mucabocabiyna bayona celika, meaning Much driven away, or much repelled, from these and from those: (T, TA:) or this is an ex. of the meaning next following. (Ṣ, M.)

A man (M, Ḳ) wavering, or vacillating, between two things, or affairs; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) or between two men, not attaching himself steadily to either; (T;) and mucabocibN↓ signifies the same; (Ḳ;) as also mutacabocibN↓. (M.)
mucabocibN: see what next precedes:
and see also mucab-ibN.
mutacabocibN: see mucabocabN, last sentence.

1. cubaHa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _a {yacobaHu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. caboHN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and cubaAHN, (Ḳ,) He cut, or divided, lengthwise; clave; split; slit; rent, or rent open; ripped, or ripped open. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [Accord. to Fei,] this is the primary signification. (Mṣb.) [But see what follows.] You say, cabaHa faOorapa Almisoka † He (a perfumer, A) ripped open the follicle, or vesicle, of mush, (A, TA,) and took forth the mush that was in it. (TA.) [In the A and TA this is said to be tropical; the authors evidently holding it to be from cabaHa in the sense here next following.]

He slaughtered [for food, or sacrificed,] (L, TA) and animal, (Mṣb,) or a sheep or goat, (Ṣ, TA,) or an ox or a cow, and a sheep or goat, and the like, (Mgh,) [in the manner prescribed by the law, i. e.,] by cutting the wadajaAni [or two external jugular veins], (Mgh,) or by cutting the throat, from beneath, at the part next the head: (L, TA:) accord. to the Ḳ, i. q. naHara: but correctly, Alc-aboHu is in the throat; and Aln-aHoru is in the pit above the breast, between the collar-bones, where camels are stabbed: the latter word is used in relation to camels and bulls and cows; and the former, in relation to other animals: or, not improbably, both may have originally signified the causing the soul to depart by wounding the throat, or the pit above the breast, which is the stabbing-place in the camel; and may then have been applied in peculiar [and different] senses by the lawyers. (MF. [See also cakaApN, in art. ckw.]) Also † He slaughtered, or slew, in any manner. (L.) [You say, cabaHa Eanohu He slaughtered, or sacrificed, for him, by way of expiation.] And cabaHa baEoDuhumo baEoDFA † [They slaughtered, or slew, one another]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And Oaxacahumo banuw fulaAnK biAlc-ubaAHi † The sons of such a one slaughtered, or slew, them. (TA.) And cb-H↓ (inf. n. tacobiyHN, KL) signifies the same as cabaHa, except that it applies [only] to many objects; whereas the latter applies to few and to many: thus it is said in the Ḳur [ii. 46, and in like manner in xiv. 6], yucab-iHuwna OabonaMCakumo † [They slaughtering, or slaying, your sons], accord. to the reading commonly obtaining. (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, TA.)

Hence, ‡ He killed; because Alc-aboHu [in its proper sense, when the object is an animal,] is one of the quickest modes of killing. (TA.) It is said in a trad., (Mgh, TA,) cautioning against accepting the office of a Kádee, (Mgh,) mano juEila qaADiyFA bayona Aln-aAsi fakaOan-amaA cubiHa bigayori sik-iynK ‡ [Whoso is made a Kádee among the people, he is as though he were slaughtered without a knife]: (Mgh, TA:*) expl. by some as meaning, ‡ he is as though he were killed [&c.]. (TA.)

[Hence, also, because Alc-aboHu renders the flesh of an animal allowable, or lawful, as food,] ‡ It rendered allowable, or lawful: as salt and the sun and the fishes called niynaAn ( pl. of nuwnN) do wine, by changing its quality, as is said in a trad. (TA.)
Also ‡ He broached, or pierced, a dan- [or wine-jar, making a hole in the mouth, or removing the clay that closed the mouth], so as to draw forth the contents. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
And ‡ He, or it, choked. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, cabaHatohu AlEaborapu ‡ Weeping choked him. (A, TA.)
And, said of thirst, ‡ It affected him severely, or distressed him. (A, TA.)

cabaHati All-iHoyapu fulaAnFA ‡ The beard flowed down beneath the chin of such a one so that the anterior portion of the part beneath his lower jaw was apparent: in which case, the man is said to be macobuwHN↓ biliHoyatihi. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 2: see 1.

tacobiyHN is [said to be] syn. with tacobiyHN, (Ḳ, TA,) in prayer: accord. to Hr, cb-H raOosahu signifies He lowered his head, in inclining his body in prayer; like db-H: and accord. to Lth, cb-H signifies he lowered his head, in inclining his body in prayer, so that it became lower than his back: but Az says that this is a mistake, and that the correct word is db-H, with the unpointed d. (TA.)

entry.sense: 6. tcAbHwA † They slaughtered, or slew, one another. (Ṣ, MA, Ḳ.) One says, Alt-amaAduHu Alt-acaAbuHu ‡ [Mutual praising is mutual slaughtering]. (Ṣ, A.)
8. Aic-abaHa He took, or prepared, for himself a slaughtered [or sacrificed] animal. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: ciboHN An animal prepared for slaughter [or sacrifice; i. e. an intended victim]: (T, A, Mṣb, TA:) [see also cabiyHN, which occurs in this sense in a trad. as applied to a human being:] or an animal that is slaughtered [or sacrificed]; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, TA;) and so cabiyHapN↓; (Mgh, Mṣb;) or this signifies a slaughtered [or sacrificed] sheep or goat; (TA;) and is [nominally] fem. of cabiyHN, but the p is affixed only because the quality of a subst. is predominant in it: (Ṣ:) or the cabiyHN is added to denote that the word is applied to a sheep, or goat, [to be slaughtered or sacrificed,] not yet slaughtered [or sacrificed]; and when the act has been executed upon it, it is [said to be] cabiyHN: (M, voce ramiy-apN:) ciboHN is applied to an animal that is slaughtered either as a sacrifice on the occasion of the pilgrimage or otherwise; and is like TiHonN in the sense of maToHuwnN, and EiTofN in the sense of maEoTuwfN, &c.: (TA:) the pl. of cabiyHapN↓ is cabaAYiHu. (Mgh, Mṣb.) It is said in the Ḳur [xxxvii. 107], wafadayonaAhu bidiboHK EaZiymK [And we ransomed him with a great victim]. (Ṣ, A.) cabaAYiHu↓ Aljin-i means Animals sacrificed to the Jinn, or Genii: for it was customary for a man, when he bought a house, or drew forth [for the first time] the water of a spring, and the like, to sacrifice an animal to the Jinn with the view of avoiding ill luck, (A, TA,) lest some disagreeable accident should happen to him from the Jinn thereof: (A:) and the doing this is forbidden. (A, TA.)
See also cubaHapN.

entry.sense: cubaHN A certain plant which ostriches eat: (Ṣ:) this word and cibaHN↓ signify the plant called Aljazaru Alb-arI-u, (Ḳ, TA,) which is of a red colour: and, accord. to the Ḳ, another plant: but correctly a red plant (nabotN OaHomaru, not nbt Mxaru,) having a stem, or root, (OaSolN) from which is peeled off a black peel, whereupon there is taken forth a white substance, resembling a white xzrp [or bead, but perhaps this is a mistranscription for jazarap, i. e. a carrot], which is sweet and good, and is eaten: [each word is a coll. gen. n.;] and the n. un. is cubaHapN and cibaHapN: so says AḤn, on the authority of Fr: and he says also, on the authority of AA, that the cubaHap is a tree that grows upon a stem, and in a manner resembling the krAv [app. karaAv, not kur-aAv], and then has a yellow flower; its root is like a jzrp [i. e. jazarap, or carrot], and it is sweet, and of a red colour: (TA:) or the cubaH is a plant having a stem, or root, (OaSolN,) which is peeled, and there comes forth what resembles the jizr [i. e. jizar or jazar, meaning carrot]; and a black skin is peeled from it; and it is sweet, and is eaten; and has a red flower. (Ḥam p. 777.)
Also, and cibaHN↓, (Ḳ,) the former the more common, (Th, TA,) A species of the kamoOapN [or truffle], (Ḳ,) of a white colour. (TA.)
See also cubaAHN.
cibaHN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
cuboHapN: see cubaHapN.

hom.sense: ciboHapN A mode, or manner, of caboH [i. e. slaughter, such as is described in the first paragraph of this art.]. (Mgh.)
See also what here next follows.

cubaHapN (AZ, Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and cuboHahN↓, (Aṣ, A, Ḳ,) but this latter, which is used by the vulgar, was unknown to AZ, (Ṣ,) and cubaAHN↓ (A, Ḳ) and cibaHapN↓ and ciboHapN↓ and cibaAHN↓ (Ḳ) and ciboHN↓, (TA,) A disease, (T, A,) or pain, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) in the Haloq [or fauces], (AZ, T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) which sometimes kills: (T:) or blood which chokes and kills: (Ḳ:) or an ulcer that comes forth in the Haloq [or fauces] of a man, like the ciYobap that attacks the ass: (ISh, TA:) or an ulcer that appears in that part, obstructing it, and stopping the breath, and killing. (TA.) One says, Oaxacatohu Alc-ubaHapu [The cbHp attacked him]. (Ṣ.) And AlT-amaEu cubaAHN↓ ‡ Covetousness is [like] a disease in the fauces: or a poisonous plant. (A.) And kaAna celika mivola Alc-ubaHapi EalaI Aln-aHori [That was like the disease called cbHp in the uppermost part of the breast]: a prov., applied to the case of a man whom one imagines to be a sincere friend, and who proves to be an evident enemy: (TA:) or kaAna mivola Alc-ubaHapi Alx He was like the cbHp, &c., a disease in the Haloq, which does not quit the patient externally, and hurts him internally: said by him to whom you complain of one whom you imagined to be a sincere friend, and whose affection was outward, when his deceit has become manifest. (Meyd.)
dubaHapN is also the n. un. of cubaHN [q. v.]. (Fr, AḤn.)
cibaHapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
It is also the n. un. of cibaHN [q. v. voce cubaHN]. (Fr, AḤn.)
cubaAHN A certain poisonous plant, (A, Ḳ, TA,) that kills the eater of it; as also cubaHN↓. (TA.) One says, AlT-amaEu cubaAHN: see cubaHapN, in two places.
[Hence,] mawotN cubaAHN † A quick, or sudden, death. (L.)
See also cub-aAHN.

entry.sense: cibaAHN: see cubaHapN.

cabiyHN and macobuwHN↓ signify the same [i. e. Cut, or divided, lengthwise;, &c.: see 1]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) You say misokN cabiyHN [for cabiyHN faOoratuhu], meaning † [Musk of which the follicle, or vesicle, is] ripped open. (A. [It is there said to be tropical: but see 1.])

Both are [also] applied to an animal, (Mṣb,) or a sheep or goat, (TA,) [or an animal of the ox-kind, and a sheep or goat, and the like, (see 1,)] as meaning Slaughtered, in the manner described in the first paragraph of this art.: (TA:) the fem. of cabiyHN is with p {cabiyHapN}: (Ṣ, TA: [see cabiyHapN below:]) but cabiyHN is used as a fem. epithet without the addition of p: you say XaApN cabiyHN as well as kaboXN cabiyHN, because cabiyHN is an instance of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; though you say XAp cabiyHapN also; and in like manner naAqapN: the pl. [of cabiyHN] is caboHaI and cabaAHaI and [that of cabiyHapN is] cabaAYiHu. (TA.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says, describing wine,
yuqaAlu lahaA damu Alwadaji Alc-abiyHu
meaning AlmacobuwHu Eanohu, i. e. [One would call it the blood of the external jugular vein,] for which it had been slit [to let it flow]. (AAF, TA.) And again he says,
wasirobK taTal-aI biAlEabiyri kaOan-ahu
dimaMCu ZibaMCu biAln-uHuwri cabiyHu [app. meaning And many a bevy of women rubbed over with perfume compounded with saffron, as though it were the blood of gazelles, the gazelles whereof had been slaughtered in the upper parts of the breasts]: he applies cbyH as an epithet to dmMC, meaning cabiyHN ZibaAWuhu; and he applies it as an epithet to a pl. n. because it is of the measure faEiylN [in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN], for such an epithet is applicable to masc. and fem. and sing. and pl. nouns. (TA.)

cabiyHN also signifies An animal that is fit, or proper, to be slaughtered as a sacrifice: (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ:) [or that is destined, or prepared, for sacrifice; i. e., an intended victim; like ciboHN; as appears from the fact that] Alc-abiyHu is † a surname of Ismá'eel, or Ishmael; (Ḳ,* TA;) for, accord. to some [or rather the generality] of the Muslims, he was the son whom Abraham designed to sacrifice, though others say it was Isaac: (TA:) and OanaA Qbonu Alc-abiyHayoni occurs in a trad. [as said by Moḥammad, meaning † I am the son of the two intended victims; namely, Ismá'eel and ʼAbd-Allah]; for ʼAbd-El-Muttalib incurred the obligation to sacrifice his son ʼAbd-Allah, the father of the Prophet, by reason of a vow, and ransomed him with a hundred camels. (Ḳ,* TA.)
Also ‡ A slain man. (A.)
cabiyHapN, and its pl. cabaAYiHu: see ciboHN, in three places.
[cab-aAHN One whose occupation, or habit, is that of slaughtering sheep or the like.]
[And, in the present day, † An executioner.]

cub-aAHN (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) and sometimes cubaAHN↓, without teshdeed, (T, Ḳ,) the former the more common, (T, Ḳ,) but disallowed by AHeyth, who holds it to be one of the words of the measure fuEaAlN denoting diseases, (TA,) ‡ Cracks in the inner [i. e. lower] sides of the toes, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) next the fore part of the foot: (TA:) or a cut across the inner sides of the toes: (Ibn-Buzurj, T:) or a crack in the inner side, or sole, of the foot: (IAạr, TA voce nakobapN:) pl. cabaAbiyHu. (TA.) Hence the saying, maA duwnahu XawokapN walaA cub-aAHN ‡ [There is not in the way of its attainment a thorn nor are there any cracks in the inner sides of the toes,, &c.: see also nakobapN]. (Ṣ, TA.)

caAbiHN [act. part. n. of 1]. saEodu Alc-aAbiHi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or saEodN Alc-aAbiHu, (so in one copy of the Ṣ,) † Two bright stars, between which is the space of a cubit (ciraAE), over against one of which (fiInaHori waAHidK minohumaA) is a small star that, by reason of its nearness, is as though it [app. meaning the bright star, or the pair of bright stars,] were about to slaughter it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) whence the appellation of Alc-aAbiH: (Ṣ:) the two stars [alpha and beta] which are in one of the horns of Capricornus; so called because of the small adjacent star, which is said to be the sheep or goat (XAp) of AlcAbH, which he is about to slaughter: (Ḳzw:) it is one of the Mansions of the Moon; (Ṣ, Ḳzw;) [namely, the Twenty-second Mansion: see also art. sEd: some give this appellation to the Twenty-third Mansion: and some, to the Twenty-fifth; but the two stars above mentioned are clearly the Twenty-second, with the place of which they agree accord. to those who make Aln-awCu to signify “the auroral rising” and those who make it to signify “the auroral setting:” see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.] The Arabs [used to] say, UicaA TalaEa Alc-aAbiHu QnojaHara Aln-aAbiHu † [When AlcAbH rises aurorally, the barker enters, or betakes itself to, its hole: the period of its auroral rising, in Central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, being the 16th of January, O. Ṣ.]. (TA.)
† A mark made with a hot iron across the throat: or † the instrument with which it is made. (L, Ḳ.)
† Hair growing between the part immediately beneath the lower jaw and the part [of the throat] in which an animal is slaughtered. (Ḳ.)

caAbiHapN, of the measure faAEilapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN, [with p affixed because the quality of a subst. is predominant in it,] Any animal which it is allowable to slaughter, of camels, and bulls or cows, and sheep or goats, &c. (TA.)

macobaHN The place of [the slaughter termed] Alc-aboH: (Ḳ:) i. e. the place, or spot of ground, where AlcbH is performed: and the part of the throat which is the place of AlcbH, which is that below the part beneath the lower jaw; (MF, TA;) or the Huloquwm [i. e. windpipe]. (Mṣb.)

‡ The chancel of a church; i. e. the part of a church that is like the miHoraAb of a mosque: (A,* Ḳ,* Mṣb:) pl. macaAbiHu: (A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the macaAbiH are the maHaAriyb (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) of the Christians; (A;) so called because of the oblations (qaraAbiyn) there offered; (Ṣ, TA;) the maqaASiyr (Ḳ, TA) in churches, pl. of maqoSuwrapN; said to be the same as the mHAryb: (TA:) and the places, (A,) or chambers, (Ḳ,) of the books of the Christians. (A, Ḳ.)

‡ A trench (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) in the earth, measuring a span or the like [in width], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) such as is made by a torrent: (Ṣ, A:) the channel of a torrent in the lower part of the face of a mountain, or in a plain depressed tract, in width equal to the space measured by the extension of the thumb and first finger or little finger; and sometimes it is a natural trench in a plain tract of land, like a river, in which flows the water of that land: it is in all descriptions of land; in valleys, &c., and in depressed tracts: (L:) and a kind of river; as though it clave [the earth] or were cleft: (TA:) pl. macaAbiHu. (Ṣ, A, L.) You say, gaAdara Als-ayolu fiI AlOaroDi macaAbiHa † [The torrent left in the ground trenches about a span wide]. (Ṣ.)

micobaHN A knife with which [the slaughter termed] Alc-aboH is performed: (Mṣb:) or a thing with which an animal is slaughtered in the manner termed caboH, (T, Ḳ,*) whether it be a knife or some other thing. (T.)
macobuwHN: see cabiyHN.
[Hence,] † Clean, or pure; not requiring to be slaughtered; [as though it had been already slaughtered;] an epithet applied in a trad. to everything in the sea. (TA.)
See also 1, last sentence.

hom.sense: 1. cabara, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yacoburu} (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and _i {yacobiru}, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. caborN; (M, A, Ḳ;) and cb-r↓, (M, A,) inf. n. tacobiyrN; (Ḳ;) He wrote (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) a writing, or a book; (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, A;) like zabara: (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ:) or both signify, (M,) or the former signifies also, (Ḳ,) he pointed, or dotted, (M, Ḳ,) it: (M:) or (M, but in the Ḳ “and,”) he read it, or recited it, (IAạr, T, M, Ḳ,*) with a low, or faint, voice; (M, Ḳ;) or easily; (M, A, each in relation to both verbs;) or quickly: (Ḳ:) all of the dial. of Hudheyl. (M.) You say, maA OaHosana maA yacoburu AlX-iEora How well he recites poetry, or the poetry, (Ḳ, TA,) without halting, or hesitating, therein! (TA.) And maA OaHosana maA yucab-iru↓ AlkitaAba How well he reads, or recites, the book, or the writing, without pausing therein! (A.)

And cabara, (IAạr, Th, T, M, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yacoburu}, inf. n. caborN and cibaArapN, He knew, or learned, a tradition, well, soundly, or thoroughly; Eanohu from him: (IAạr, Th, T:) or he understood it: (M, Ḳ:) and he understood, and knew, or learned, well, soundly, or thoroughly, a writing, or a book. (TA.) [See 2 in art. dbr, last sentence.] Accord. to some, caborN signifies Understanding, and knowledge; (T;) knowledge of a thing, and understanding thereof; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also cubuwrN [another inf. n.]: (TA:) or cubuwrN signifies understanding with knowledge of a thing. (M.) It is said in a trad., of the people of Paradise, minohumo Al-aciI laA cabora lahu, (T, TA,) i. e. Of them is he who has no understanding: (TA:) or, accord. to IAạr, it means he who has no tongue with which to speak, by reason of his weakness. (T.)
And cabara, aor. _i {yacobiru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. cibaArapN, (so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or cabaArapN, (so in other copies of the Ḳ, and accord. to the TA,) He looked, and did so well. (Ḳ,* TA.)
cabira He was angry: (T, Ḳ:) so accord. to IAạr: (T, TA:) [but SM says,] were it not set down on his authority, I should say that it is a mistranscription for caYira. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in two places.

hom.sense: caborN A writing, (Aṣ, T, Ḳ,) in the dial. of Himyer, written upon Eusub [or leafless palmsticks, or the lower portions of palm-sticks, upon which no leaves have grown]: (Ḳ:) and i. q. SaHiyfapN [a piece of paper, or skin, upon which something is written; or a writing, or book]: (Ḳ:) pl. cibaArN (Aṣ, T, Ḳ.)

kitaAbN caborN, (M, A,) or cabirN↓, like katifN, (Ḳ,) A writing, or book, easy to be read: (A, Ḳ:) or caborN in this phrase is an inf. n. used in the place of the pass. part. n. macobuwrN↓ [which signifies written; or pointed; or read, or recited, with a low, or faint, voice, or easily,, &c.]. (M.)
Also A mountain; in the Abyssinian language: so accord. to one reading, but accord. to another reading daborN, in a trad. cited in art. dbr. (TA.)

entry.sense: cabirN: see the next preceding paragraph.
caAbirN Knowing, or learning, well, soundly, or thoroughly, a matter of science or knowledge. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.)
micobarN A reed-pen; like mizobarN. (TA.)
mucab-arN A garment, or piece of cloth, figured with marks resembling writing, or otherwise; syn. munamonamN: (M, Ḳ:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (M.)
macobuwrN: see caborN.
mucaAbirN, occurring in a trad., is explained by IAth as meaning Going away; if it be not a mistranscription [for mudaAbirN, which seems to be probably the case]. (TA.)

1. cabala, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yacobulu}, inf. n. cabolN and cubuwlN; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and cabula; (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ;) said of a branch, (T,) or a herb, (Ṣ,) or a plant, (M, Ḳ,) or a thing, (Mṣb,) It withered; i. e., lost its moisture; (Mṣb;) or became thin, or unsubstantial, after being succulent; (M;) i. q. cawiIa. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And in like manner it is said of a man: (M:) or cubuwlN [in relation to a human being] signifies the drying up by reason of the loss of the beauty, or goodliness, of youth. (Ḥam p. 478.) And said of a horse, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. cabolN, (TA,) He was, or became, lean, or light of flesh; slender and lean; or lean, and lank in the belly. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say also, cabala fuwhu, inf. n. cubuwlN (T, TA) and cabolN, May his mouth, and his saliva, or spittle, dry up. (TA.) And maA lahu cabala caboluhu↓, (M, Ḳ, [in the CK, erroneously, cabolapF,]) i. e. [What aileth him?] may his stock (OaSoluhu) wither: meaning his body and his flesh: or, as some say, may his marriage, or coition, be ineffectual: (M, TA:) said in reviling: (TA:) as also dabala daboluhu. (TA in art. dbl.) One says also, in reviling, (TA,) cabalatohumo cubayolapN↓ [and dubayolapF, i. e. May a calamity, or misfortune, befall them: or] may they perish. (T, TA.)
And cblt cbAYlh [app. a mistranscription for cabalatohu cabaAYilu↓ May calamities, or misfortunes, befall him]. (TA.) And cabalatohu cabuwlN↓ (T, TA) and dabuwlN (T) May a calamity, or misfortune, befall him. (TA.) [See the latter part of the first paragraph {1} of art. dbl.]
4. Acblhu It (the heat, Ṣ, TA) withered it; (namely, a herb [&c.], S;) caused it to wither, or lose its moisture; syn. OacowaAhu; (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA;) rendered it caAbil. (TA.)
And tucobilu Alr-iyHu biAlOaXoyaMCi The wind twists, wreathes, or contorts, the things. (TA.)

hom.sense: 5. tcb-l It became twisted, wreathed, or contorted. (TA.) One says, tcb-lt Aln-aAqapu bicanabihaA The she-camel twisted, or contorted, her tail. (TA.)
[It occurs in the Ḳ, in art. rOd, said of a branch, or twig, app. as meaning It inclined limberly from side to side: but in the M and L, I there find in its place tcy-l.]

tcb-lt She (a woman), being thin, or slender, walked in the manner of men: (M, Ḳ:) or she walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
Also He (a man) threw off [all] his garments, except one. (TA.)
cabolN The prime, or first part, or the briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, (mayoEap,) of youth. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)
maA lahu cabala caboluhu: see 1.

Accord. to Aṣ, one says cabolN caAbilN↓ and cibolN↓ caAbilN↓, meaning [Deep] abasement or ignominy: and accord. to IAạr, (T,) cibolN↓ cabiylN↓, meaning severe bereavement. (T, Ḳ.) cabolFA cabiylFA↓, (M, Ḳ,) or cibolFA↓ cabiylFA↓, (M,) is a form of imprecation [but app. not intended as such, lit. meaning May God send upon such a one deep abasement or ignominy, or severe bereavement]: (M, Ḳ:) and one says also cabolFA caAbilFA↓, (Ḳ,) or cibolFA↓ caAbilFA↓, (M,) meaning [likewise deep] abasement or ignominy, (TA,) or severe bereavement. (M, TA.) [See also dibolN and dabiylN.]

Also [Turtle-shell, or tortoise-shell;] the back, (IAạr, Ṣ, Mṣb,) or skin, (M, Ḳ,) [meaning shell,] of the sea-tortoise [or turtle], (IAạr, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or of the land-tortoise, (M, Ḳ,) of which are made combs, (IAạr, TA,) and, as some say, signet-rings, &c., (TA,) or of which bracelets are made: (Ṣ:) or the bones of the back of a certain marine beast, of which are made, (M, Ḳ,) by women, (M,) bracelets (M, Ḳ) and combs; and the combing wherewith removes nits and the scurf of the hair: (Ḳ:) or horns of which are made [the bracelets, or anklets, called] masaka: (En-Naḍr, TA:) or a certain thing [or substance] resembling ivory: (Mṣb:) Th cites a poet as using the phrase caAtu Alc-abalaAt, forming the pl. of cabolN with A and t; but accord. to the citation of IAạr, the word in this instance is Alr-abalaAt. (M.)

entry.sense: cibolN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.
cabolapN A piece of camels' or similar dung: (M, Ḳ:) because of its drying up. (M.)

And A withering wind. (M, Ḳ.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
diyaArN maHatohaA baEodanaA kul-u cabolapK
[Abodes of which every withering wind had effaced the traces after they had been seen by us]. (M.)
cabolaMCu A woman whose lip is dry. (O, Ḳ.*)

hom.sense: cubaAlN: see cubaAlapN.
Also Ulcers that come forth in the side and penetrate into the inside; (Ḳ;) i. q. naq-aAbaAtN; and so dubaAlN, with d. (IAạr, T.)

entry.sense: cabuwlN A calamity, or misfortune; (T, TA;) as also cabiylN↓ and ciYobilN↓: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA:) see 1. [See also cubayolapN, in the first paragraph, and below.]
cabiylN: see cabolN, in three places:
and cabuwlN.

cubaAlapN (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and cub-aAlapN↓ (T, Ḳ) A wick (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) that is lighted, (M,) or with which a lamp is lighted, or trimmed: (T:) or cub-aAlapN signifies a wick of which a portion is burnt: (Ḥam p. 81:) pl. [or coll. gen. n.] cubaAlN↓ and cub-aAlN↓. (T, Ḳ,* TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce daAHuwlN.]
cubayolapN and [its pl.] cabaAYilu [or this is pl. of cabuwlN or cabiylN]: see 1.
cub-aAlN: see cubaAlapN.
cub-aAlapN: see cubaAlapN.
caAbilN Withering, or withered; losing, or having lost, its moisture. (TA.)

Spear-shafts (qanFA) slender, and of which the liyT [or exterior part] adheres [firmly]: (M, Ḳ:* [for laASiqN biAlil-yTi, in the Ḳ, I read laASiqu All-iyTi, as in the M:]) pl. cib-alN and cubulN. (M, Ḳ.)
Lean, or emaciated: (Ḥam p. 788.)
See also cabolN, in four places.
ciYobilN: see cabuwlN.

caHolN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and caHalN↓ (Mṣb) Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; or concealment of enmity, and violent hatred, in the heart; or retention of enmity in the heart, with watchfulness for an opportunity to indulge it or exercise it; syn. HiqodN: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and [simply] enmity: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or blood-revenge; or retaliation of murder or homicide; or a seeking to revenge, or avenge, or retaliate, blood; syn. vaOorN: or a desire, or seeking, for retaliation of a crime or of enmity: (Ḳ:) pl. (of the former) cuHuwlN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and (of the latter, Mṣb) OacoHaAlN. (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) One says, Talaba bicaHolihi, meaning bivaOorihi [i. e.
