cam-a,, [aor. _i {yacomimu},] said of the nose, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) It flowed [with camiym, i. e. mucus]; (Ḳ;) like can-a. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And [the aor.] yacim-u is said of camiym; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like yacin-u; (Ṣ, TA;) meaning It flows. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first sentence.
3. fulaAnN yucaAm-u EayoXahu † Such a one passes his life contended with scantiness. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Acm- He (a man) did [or said] that for which he should be blamed, dispraised, discommended, found fault with, censured, or reprehended; (Ṣ;) contr. of OaHomada. (A in art. Hmd.) And Astcm-↓ Uilayohi, (M, Ḳ,) or UilaI Aln-aAsi, (Ṣ,) He did to him, or to the people, that for which he should be blamed,, &c. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

[Hence,] Oacam-ato raAHilatuhu ‡ His riding-camel ceased going on; as though she made the people to blame her. (TA.) And Oacam-ato rikaAbuhumo ‡ Their camels upon which they were riding became jaded, and lagged behind, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) not keeping up with the main body of camels; (Ṣ, TA;) [as though they made their riders to blame them; or] as though [the idea of] their strength in journeying were derived from cam-apN meaning “a well having little water.” (TA.) And Acm- biha baEiyruhu ‡ [His camel became jaded, and lagged behind with him]. (Ṣ, TA.) And Oacam-ato biAlr-akobi, said of a she-ass, ‡ She kept back the company of riders upon camels by her weakness and her ceasing to go on. (TA from a trad.)

Acm-hu He found him, or it, to be such as is blamed, dispraised,, &c.; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA;) contr. of OaHomadahu. (TA.) One says, Oatayotu mawoDiEa kacaA faOacomamotuhu, i. e. [I came to such a place, and] I found it to be such as is discommended. (Ṣ)

Ac-m bihi, (Ṣ,) or bihimo, (M, Ḳ,) He held him, or them, in little, or light, or mean, estimation, or in contempt: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he left [him or] them blamed, dispraised,, &c., among the people. (IAạr, M, Ḳ.)
Also, Acm-hu, He protected him; granted him protection, or refuge. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And Acm- lahu Ealayohi He took, or obtained, a promise, or an assurance, of security or safety, and a compact, or covenant, for him, or in his favour, of, or against, him [i. e. another person, making the latter responsible for his (the former's) security, or safety,, &c.]. (M,* Ḳ,* TA.)
See also the next paragraph {5}.

entry.sense: 5. tcm-m He shunned, or avoided, (T,* Mgh,) or he preserved, or guarded, himself from, (MA,) blame, dispraise,, &c.: (T,* MA, Mgh:) this is the proper meaning; and hence, (Mgh,) he felt disdain, or scorn, and shame. (Ṣ, MA, Mgh, Ḳ, KL.) One says, lawo lamo Oatoruki Alkaciba taOav-umFA latarakotuhu tacam-umaA [If I did not refrain from lying for the purpose of abstaining from sin, I would refrain from it from a feeling of disdain, or scorn, or shame]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And tcm-m minohu [He abstained, or refrained, from it to avoid blame, or through disdain, or scorn, or shame; disdained, or scorned, it; or was ashamed of it]. (Ḳ in art. HXm.) And Aboo-ʼAmr Ibn-El-ʼAlà mentions his having heard an Arab of the desert use the expression lA ycm-wn [app. laA yucim-uwna↓, for the A in the measure OafoEala sometimes has a privative property,] meaning They do not shun, or avoid, blame; (laA yatacam-amuwna;) and are not affected with shame. (TA.) It is said in a trad., mino xilaAli AlmakaArimi Alt-acam-umu lilS-aAHibi, meaning [Of the properties of generous, or honourable, practices, is] the being regardful of everything that is entitled to reverence, respect, honour, or defence, in the character and appertenances of the companion, or friend, and dispelling from oneself the blame that he would incur from men if he were not regardful thereof. (TA.) And one says, lilojaAri Einodaka tacam-umN and musotacam-N↓ [To the neighbour, with thee, is shown regard of everything that is entitled to reverence, respect, honour, or defence, in his character and appertenances: musotacam-N being app. an inf. n. of Astcm-↓, and this being syn. with tcm-m]. (TA.)
6. tcAm-wA They blamed, dispraised, discommended, found fault with, censured, or reprehended, one another. (M, Ḳ.)
10. Astcm- [He required blame,, &c.; as though he called for it; or] he was blamed, or dispraised,, &c. (KL.) See also 4, second sentence.
And see 5, last sentence.
[Astcm- bicimaAmihi is used by post-classical writers, and is perhaps a classical phrase, meaning He begged, or implored, his protection. See an instance in “Abulfedæ Annales,” vol. iii. p. 170.]
R. Q. 1. camocama He made his gift small, or scanty. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: cam-N inf. n. of cam-ahu. (T, Ṣ, M, &c.) [As a simple subst., Blame, dispraise, or censure.]
And [the pl.] cumuwmN signifies Vices, faults, defects, or the like. (M, Ḳ. [See caAm-N.])
See also camiymN.
And see cam-apN.

entry.sense: cim-N: see camiymN.
Also Excessively lean or emaciated; and perishing: (Ḳ:) or like him who is perishing. (T, TA.)
See also cim-apN.

cam-apN [as a subst.]; (T, Mgh;) and biYorN cam-apN, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) in which the latter word is an epithet, (Mgh,) and cim-apN↓ also, with kesr, (so in one of my copies of the Ṣ,) and camiymN↓, and camiymapN; (M, Ḳ;) A well containing little water; (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ;) because discommended: (M, Mgh:) and, (M, Ḳ,) as some say, (M,) containing much water: thus having two contr. significations: (M, Ḳ:) pl. cimaAmN (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and cam-N↓, (T, TA,) [or rather the latter is a coll. gen. n., of which cam-apN is the n. un.] A poet says, (Ṣ,) namely, Dhu-r-Rummeh, describing camels whose eyes were sunk in their sockets by reason of fatigue, (T,)
EalaI Himoyariy-aAtK kaOan-a EuyuwnahaA
cimaAmu Alr-akaAyaA OanokazatohaA AlmawaAtiHu
[Upon camels of Himyer that were as though their eyes were wells containing little water which the camels employed to draw it had exhausted]. (T, Ṣ.)

hom.sense:
cim-apN A compact, a covenant, a contract, a league, a treaty, an engagement, a bond, or an obligation; (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because the breaking thereof necessitates blame: (Mgh:) and a right, or due, (Haq-N,) for the neglect of which one is to be blamed: (Bḍ in ix. 8:) [an inviolable right or due:] and cimaAmN↓ and macim-apN↓ and macam-apN↓ signify in like manner a compact, a covenant,, &c. as above, for the neglect, or nonobservance, of which a man is to be blamed: (Mṣb:) or these three words [in the CK the first and last only] signify a right, or due; syn. Haq-N: (M, Ḳ:) or so the first of them: (T,* Ṣ:) and each of them, (M, Ḳ,) or the first of them, i. e. cimaAmN, (T, Ṣ, Mgh,) i. q. HuromapN [which includes all the significations of cim-apN likewise, those above and those which follow, but appears here to be used as meaning especially a thing that should be sacred, or inviolable; or which one is under an obligation to reverence, respect, or honour, and defend; everything that is entitled to reverence, respect, honour, or defence. in the character and appertenances of a person]; (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ;) every Huromap for the neglect, or non-observance, of which one is to be blamed: (T:) camaAmapN↓, also, and cimaAmapN↓, are syn. with Haq-N and HuromapN: (TA:) and cim-apN signifies also i. q. OamaAnN [as meaning security, or safety; security of life and property; protection, or safeguard; a promise, or an assurance, of security, safety, protection, or safeguard; indemnity; or quarter]; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, KL, TA;) and so cimaAmN↓: (MA, KL: [explained in both by the Pers. zinohaAro; and in the latter by HuromapN and Haq-N also:]) and responsibility [for the fulfilment of an obligation, for the payment of a sum of money, for the restitution of a thing, or for the safety, or safe-keeping, of a thing or person]; suretiship; (M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also camaAmapN↓ and cimaAmapN↓; (M, Ḳ; [in the former of which, these two words are said to be syn. with cim-apN, app. meaning, in all the senses mentioned above;]) and cim-N↓: (M, Ḳ: [said in the M to be syn. with cim-apN in the first only of the senses mentioned above in this paragraph: in the CK, wAlc-im-u is erroneously put for waAlc-im-i:]) the pl. of cim-apN is cimamN (T, Mṣb) and cimaAmN: (T:) and the pl. of cimaAmN↓ as [a sing.] syn. with [cim-apN and] macam-apN and macim-apN is Oacim-apN. (M, Ḳ.) Hence, i. e. from cim-apN in the first of the senses explained above, Oahlu Alc-im-api, (Ṣ, Mgh, TA.) and Alc-im-ipu, (T, M,* Mgh, Ḳ, TA,) with the prefixed noun Ahl suppressed, (TA,) The people with whom a compact, or covenant,, &c., has been made; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA;) [and particularly] those, of the believers in a plurality of Gods, [by which are here meant the Christians, Jews, and Sabians, but no others,] who pay the [tax called] jizoyap; (T, TA;) [i. e. the free non-Muslim subjects of a Muslim government, who pay a poll-tax for which the Muslims are responsible for their security and freedom and toleration: see OaholN:] the appellation cim-iI-N↓, (Mgh, Mṣb,) a rel. n. from Alc-im-apu, (Mṣb;) is applied to a person of this class; (Mgh, Mṣb;) because he is rendered secure, or free from fear, for his property and his blood, by means of the jizoyap. (Mgh.) jaEala Eumaru Oahola Als-awaAdi cim-apF means ʼOmar treated [lit. made] the people of the Sawád as those who are termed Oaholu Alc-im-api. (Mgh.) And OaqobilonaA bicim-apK [or OaqolibonaA?], in the prayer of the traveller, means Restore us to our family in safety. (TA.) It is related in a trad. of ʼAlee, that he said, cim-atiI bimaA Oaquwlu rahiynapN waOanaA bihi zaEiymN, meaning My responsibility is pledged for [the truth of] what I say, and I am answerable for it; (Mgh, TA;*) i. e. this my saying is true, and I am responsible for it. (Mgh.) And it is said in another trad., faqado bariYato minohu Alc-im-ap [Then the responsibility of God is clear, or quit, of him]; i. e. there is given to every one, by God, a covenant whereby He binds Himself to preserve and protect him; and when he throws himself into destruction, or does that which is unlawful for him to do, or acts at variance with that which he is commanded to do, the covenant of God fails to aid him. (TA.) fiI cim-atiI kacaA means fI DamaAniI [virtually I am responsible for such a thing; i. e. for paying it, or restoring it, &c.; but lit. in my responsibility is such a thing; or on my responsibility rests, or lies, or be, such a thing; for fI may be here used, as it is in many other instances, in the sense of EalaI]: (Mṣb:) [or,] in the saying vabata fiI cim-atiI kacaA, [which means Such a thing became, or has become, binding, obligatory, or incumbent, on me,] the term cim-ap is applied to designate [the moral sense considered as] the seat [of the sense] of obligation to fulfil what is [properly] termed cim-ap [i. e. a compact, or covenant, or the like]. (Mgh.) maA yucohibu Ean-iI macim-apa↓ Alr-aDaAEi (T, Ṣ, Mgh,*) or macam-apa↓ Alr-aDaAEi, (T, Mgh,) meaning [What will put away from me the obligation of] the right, or due, of the woman who has suckled for the sucking? is a question occurring in a trad., (T, Ṣ, Mgh,*) as put by a man to the Prophet: (T:) and the answer was, “A slave, male or female:” (T, Ṣ, Mgh:)
En-Nakha'ee says, (Ṣ,) they liked, on the occasion of the weaning of a child, to give the woman who had suckled it something beside the hire: (Ṣ, Mgh:) macam-apN↓ in this case is a dial. var. of macim-apN↓: (Mgh:) or, as IAth says, the former is from Alc-am-u; and the latter, from Alc-im-ahu. (TA.) You say also, Oacohibo Eanoka macam-a↓ Alr-aDaAEi biX-aIoCK tuEoTiyhi AlZ-iYora and macim-a↓ Alr-aDaAEi, meaning [Put away from thee the obligation of] the right, or due, that is incumbent on thee to render her for the sucking of thy child [by something that thou shalt give to her who has suckled]. (T.) And Oacohibo Eanoka macim-atahumo↓ biXaIoCK and macam-atahumo↓, (T, and so accord. to different copies of the Ṣ and Ḳ, in which Enk is omitted,) macam-ap being a dial. var., (T,) i. e. [Put away from thee the obligation of their right, or due, by something; meaning] feed them with something, (T,) or give to them something, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) for they have a right, or due. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ.) And qaDaI macim-atahu↓ and macam-atahu↓ [He paid his right, or due;] meaning he did good to him, or conferred upon him a benefit or benefits, in order that he might not be blamed. (M, Ḳ.) And rajulN cuw macim-apK↓ and macam-apK↓ [in the CK the latter only, A man who has a right, or due,] meaning kal-N EalaI Aln-aAsi ‡ [a man who is a burden upon people, to be maintained, or supported, by them]. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
Also (i. e. cim-apN) A repast, or banquet, to which guests are invited, [simply] for food, or for a wedding. (Ḳ.)
See also cam-apN.

entry.sense: cimaAmN: see cim-apN, in three places. It is also a pl. of cim-apN [as well as syn. therewith]. (T.)

hom.sense: camiymN Blamed, dispraised, discommended, found fault with, censured, or reprehended; (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. q. macomuwmN↓; (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also cim-N↓ (T, Ḳ, TA) and cam-N↓, (M, Ḳ, TA,) which last is an inf. n. used as an epithet, and, like [its contr.] HamodN, is applied to a man and to a place of alighting or sojourning or abiding. (TA.) [See mucim-N]
See also cam-apN.
Also, applied to water, Disliked, or disapproved. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

[As a subst.,] Urine and mucus, (Ḳ,) so in the copies of the Ḳ, but correctly, (TA,) mucus, and urine (Ṣ, TA) that flows from the penis of the goat: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or a fluid that flows from the nose. (IAạr, T.)

And in like manner, Milk [that flows] from the teats of sheep or goats; (Ḳ;) or, as in some copies of the Ṣ, form the teats of the she-camel; (TA;) or from the teats of the sheep or goat: (so in one of my copies of the Ṣ: in the other of those copies omitted:) or milk that becomes sprinkled upon the udders: (Th, M:) or milk that flows upon the thighs and udders of camels and sheep or goats. (M.)
Also Dew, (M, Ḳ,) absolutely; (TA;) accord. to IDrd: (M:) or dew that falls in the night upon the trees, and upon which dust lights, so that it becomes like bits of clay or mud. (M, Ḳ.)

And A thing [meaning the sebaceous matter] that comes forth from the pores of the soft part of the nose, like the eggs of ants: (Ṣ:) or pimples, or small pustules, (bavorN, T, Ḳ,) or a thing resembling bavor, black, or red, (M,) like the eggs of ants, (T, M,) coming forth upon the nose, (T,) or arising upon the faces (M, Ḳ) and the noses, (M,) from heat (T, M, Ḳ) or from the scab: (M, Ḳ:) or the dirty matter that comes forth upon the nose: n. un. with p {camiymapN}. (TA.)
And Whiteness upon the nose of a kid. (Kr, M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: camaAmapN: see cim-apN, in two places.

Also Shame, and fear of blame: whence the saying, Oaxacatohu mino SaAHibihi camaAmapN [Shame, and fear of blame, with respect to his companion, seized him]: and OaSaAbatohu minohu camaAmapN, i. e. Shame and disgrace affected him on account of him, or it. (TA.) One says also, OaxacatoniI minohu macam-apN↓ and macim-apN↓, meaning Shame and disgrace by reason of the neglect of that which should be sacred or inviolable, or of that which was entitled to reverence, respect, honour, or defence, or of the obligation or duty, or the right or due, that should be regarded as sacred or inviolable, (mino taroki AlHuromapi,) [seized me on account of him, or it.] (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
cumaAmapN † A remain, remainder, remaining portion, remnant, or relic. (Ḳ.) [See also cam-aMC, below.]
cimaAmapN: see cim-apN, in two places.

bihi camiymapN In him is a crippleness, or a chronic disease, (Ḳ, [in the CK camAnapN is erroneously put for zamaAnapN,]) or an infirmity arising therefrom or from some evil affection, (M,) that prevents him from going forth. (M, Ḳ.)

OaboqaI cam-aMCa AlS-ub-i ‡ [He left] the last remains [of what was poured out, or forth, at once]: so in the A. (TA. [But the last word is there written without any syll. signs.]) [See also cumaAmapN.]
cim-iI-N: see cim-apN, in the former half of the paragraph.
cam-aAmN One who blames, dispraises, discommends,, &c., much, or often. (TA.)
caAm-N and caAmN, with and without teshdeed, [the latter belonging to art. cym,] A vice, fault, defect, or the like. (Aṣ, T.) [See also cam-N.]
Oacam-u A horse fatigued, and standing still. (TA.)
macam-N and macim-N: see cim-apN, in the latter part of the paragraph.
muc-im-N A thing blamed, dispraised,, &c.; [like camiymN;] or made, or caused, to be faulty, or defective, or to have a vice, fault, defect, or the like; (Ṣ. Ḳ;) as also micam-N↓. (Ḳ.)
And A man (Ṣ) in whom is no motion. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
micam-N: see the next preceding paragraph.

macam-apN, with fet-ḥ only [to the c, A cause of blame, dispraise, discommendation, censure, or reprehension; a blamable, or discommendable, quality or action;] a thing for which one is, or is to be, blamed, dispraised, discommended, found fault with, censured, or reprehended: contr. of maHomadapN: (Ṣ:) [pl. macaAm-N.] You say, Albuxolu macam-apN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. [Niggardliness is] one of the things for which one is, or is to be, blamed,, &c. (Ṣ.) And Uiy-aAka waAlmacaAm-a [Beware thou of, or avoid thou, or remove thyself far from, causes of blame,, &c.]. (TA.)
See also cim-apN, in six places.
And see camaAmapN.
macim-apN: see cim-apN, in six places.
And see also camaAmapN.
mucam-amN A man blamed, dispraised, discommended, found fault with, censured, or reprehended, much. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And A place held in reverence, respect, or honour. (TA.)
macomuwmN: see camiymN, first sentence.
musotacam-N: see 5, last sentence.

hom.sense: 1. camara, (Ṣ,) inf. n. camorN, (Ḳ,) He (a lion) roared. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

camarahu, aor. _u {yacomuru}, (Ṣ, M, A,) inf. n. camorN, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) He excited, incited, urged, or instigated, him, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,*) with chiding, or reproof, (T, M, A, Ḳ,*) and encouraged him, (L,) EalaI AlOamori to do the thing; (A;) as also cm-rhu↓: (L, TA:) and he threatened him; (L, Ḳ;*) and was angry with him. (L.)

camarahu, aor. _u {yacomuru}; and cm-rhu↓, [inf. n. tacomiyrN;] He felt his mucam-ar [q. v.]. (M.) You say also, camara Alr-aAEiI Als-aliyla The pastor felt the place where the head of the young camel just born was set upon the neck, to know if it were a male or a female: (A:) [or its inf. n., camorN, signifies the same as] tacomiyrN↓ a man's inserting the hand into the vulva of a she-camel, to discover if her fœtus be a male or a female. (Ṣ.) [See mucam-irN.]

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in three places.
tacomiyrN also signifies The determining the quantity, measure, size, or bulk, of a thing; or computing by conjecture the quantity or measure thereof. (Ḳ,* TA.)

5. tcm-r, an irreg. quasi-pass. of camarahu, (M,) [or rather a reg. quasi-pass. of cam-arahu, which is mentioned in the L, and meaning He excited, incited, urged, or instigated, himself,] as though he blamed himself for a thing that had escaped him: (Ṣ:) or he blamed himself (M, Ḳ) for a thing that had escaped him: (Ḳ:) or he blamed himself for negligence, in order to inspirit himself, that he might not be negligent a second time: (A:) or he blamed himself for the escape, or loss, of [what he was bound to preserve and defend, or] what is termed cimaArN. (TA.)
He became angry. (M, Ḳ.)
He disliked a thing, and was angry in consequence thereof. (Ḥar p. 517.)
tcm-r Ealayohi He became changed, or altered, to him, and threatened him with evil. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

But in the trad. in which it is said of Moses, kaAna yatacam-aru EalaI rab-ihi, this expression means that He emboldened himself to his Lord, and raised his voice in his expression of disapproval. (TA.)
6. tcAmrwA They excited, incited, urged, or instigated, one another, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in war, (Ṣ,) or to fight. (Ḳ.)
Also, sometimes, They blamed one another for neglecting an opportunity. (TA.)

cimorN and camirN↓ and cimir-N↓ and camiyrN↓ A courageous man: (Ṣ,* M, Ḳ:*) or who combines sagacity, or sagacity and cunning and craftiness, with courage, (M,) or with strength; (T;) and cumaAYirN↓ has also this last signification: (TA:) or the four preceding words signify, (M,) or signify also, (Ḳ,) clever, intelligent, and a good assistant: (M, Ḳ:) pl. of the first (Ṣ, M) and second and fourth, (M,) OacomaArN; (Ṣ, M;) and pl. of the third, cimir-uwna. (M.)
Alc-imoru and Alc-umaAYiru↓ are also names of Calamities, or misfortunes. (Ḳ.)
camirN: see the next preceding paragraph.
cimir-N: see the next preceding paragraph.
camaArN: see the next paragraph.

cimaArN Whatever one is obliged, or bound, to preserve and guard and defend or protect, (T, M, Ḳ,*) and for the loss or neglect of which one must be blamed: (T:) things that are sacred, or inviolable; a man's family, and property (Hawozap), and servants or dependents, and relations: (AA, T:) as also camaArN↓: (TA:) things for which, if he did not defend or protect them, a man would be blamed, and severely reproved: (A:) or what is behind a man, [as a burden upon him,] of those things which it is his duty to defend or protect; for they say HaAmiI Alc-imaAri, [see below,] like as they say HaAmiI AlHaqiyqapi; and those things are termed cmAr because anger (tacam-urN) on their account is incumbent on him to whom they pertain; and they are termed Hqyqp because it is the duty of him to whom they pertain to defend them. (Ṣ.) HaAmiI Alc-imaAri signifies The defender, or protector, of those things for which a man is to be blamed, and severely reproved, if he do not defend or protect them: (A:) [or of those things which he is bound to preserve and guard and defend,, &c.: see above:] or one who, when he is incited, or instigated, and angry, defends, or protects. (Ṣ.) One says also, fulaAnN OamonaEu cimaArFA mino fulaAnK [app., Such a one is a greater defender of those things which it is his duty to defend than such a one]. (Ṣ.)
yawomu Alc-imaAri The day of war: or of perdition: or of anger. (Et-Towsheeh.)
camiyrN: see cimorN.
Also A man goodly, or beautiful, (Ḳ, TA,) in make. (TA.)

camaArapN Courage: (M, Ḳ:) or sagacity, or sagacity and cunning and craftiness, combined with courage [or with strength: see cimorN]: or cleverness, intelligence, and the quality of rendering good assistance. (M.)
cumaAYiru: see cimorN, in two places.
cayomuriI-N, (Ḳ, TA,) with damm to the m, (TA,) [in the CK cayomariI-,] A man sharp in temper, who adheres to things and minds them pertinaciously. (Ḳ,* TA.) [And so dayomuriI-N.]

mucam-arN The back of the neck: (M, Ḳ:) or two bones in the base of the back of the neck: or the part called ciforaI [behind the ear]: or the kaAhil [or upper part of the back, next the neck]: (M:) or this last-mentioned part with the neck and what surrounds it as far as the ciforaI; which is what the mucam-ir [q. v.] feels: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or the place where the head of a camel is set upon the neck. (A.)
balaga AlOamoru Almucm-aru ‡ The affair, or case, or event, reached a distressing pitch; (A,* Ḳ;) like balaga Almuxan-aqa. (A.)

mucam-irN A man who inserts his hand into the vulva of a she-camel, to discover if her fœtus be a male or a female: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) because he feels its mucam-ar, and thus knows it: he feels its jaw-bones: if they be thick, it is a male; and if thin, a female. (M.) El-Kumeyt says,
waqaAla Almucam-iru liln-aAtijiyna
mataI cum-irato qaboliIa AlOarojulu
[And he whose business it was to feel the fœtus, for the purpose of discovering if it were male or female, said to those assisting the she-camels in bringing forth, When, before my time, were the legs felt to discover the sex of the fœtus?]: (Ṣ, M:) for it is the head that is felt, as above explained. (M.) The mucam-ir is, to camels, as the midwife to human beings. (A.)

1. camala, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or camalato, (T,) aor. _u {yacomulu} (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and _i {yacomilu}, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. camiylN (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and camolN and cumuwlN and camalaAnN, (M, Ḳ,) said of a camel, (T, Ṣ,) He, or she, went a gentle pace: (T, M, Ḳ:) or went a pace above that which is termed AlEanaqu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and above that which is termed Alt-azay-udu: [for] AʼObeyd says, when the pace rises a little above that which is termed AlEanaqu, it is termed Alt-azay-udu; and when it rises above this, it is termed Alc-amiylu; and then, Alr-asiymu: Aṣ says that no camel goes the pace termed Alc-amiyl for a day and a night except the mahoriI. (Ṣ.)
2. cam-alotuhu, inf. n. tacomiylN, I urged him, or made him, (namely, a camel, TA,) to go the pace above mentioned. (Ḳ.)
naAqapN camuwlN [A she-camel that is accustomed to go the pace above mentioned]: (M, Ḳ:) pl. cumulN, (M, and so in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,) or cumolN. (TA: in the CK cum-al.)
camiylapN Fatigued, or jaded; (IAạr, T, Ḳ;) applied to a she-camel. (IAạr, TA.)
naAqapN caAmilapN [A she-camel going the pace above mentioned]: pl. cawaAmilu. (T.)

hom.sense: 1. camiIa, (M, Ḳ, and so in some copies of the Ṣ,) aor. yacomaI; (Ḳ, and some copies of the Ṣ;) or camaI, aor. yacomiI; (T, and so in some copies of the Ṣ;) or both; (Ṣgh, TA;) inf. n. camaMCN; (T,* Ṣ, M,* Ḳ,* TA;) said of a slaughtered animal, (Ṣ, TA,) It moved. (T, Ṣ, M, Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA.) And camiIa; (M;) or camaI, aor. yacomiI; (Ḳ;) inf. n. as above; (M, Ḳ;*) He retained remains of the soul, or vital principle: or had strength of heart [remaining: app. said of one dying]. (M, Ḳ. [These meaning are there indicated, but not expressed.]) You say, mar-a yacomiI, inf. n. as above, He passed by at his last gasp of breath. (Ḥar p. 220.) And camaI, aor. yacomiI, inf. n. camoIN [and app. camaMCN also, as seems to be indicated by what here follows, or perhaps the latter only], He (a sick person) was seized by the agony of death, and was long in suffering the disquietude thereof: whence one says, maA OaTowala camaMCahu [How long is his suffering of the agong and disquietude of death!]. (Aṣ, T.) [See camMCN below.] You say also, of a man, camiIa, inf. n. camaMCN, meaning He remained long sick, or diseased. (M.)

camaI, aor, yacomiI, inf. n. camayaAnN, He hastened, made haste, sped, or went quickly: (Fr, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) some also mention camiIa, aor. yacomaI, [in this sense, and thus I find in one copy of the Ṣ,] but [ISd says,] I am not sure of this. (M.)

camiIa liI minohu XaIoCN means Somewhat thereof was, or became, prepared for me; or feasible, or practicable, to me: (M:) [and so, app., camaI lI: for] one says, xuc- mino fulaAnK maA camaI laka, meaning Take thou, from such a one, what has risen up for thee, or arisen for thee; i. e. maAQrotafaEa laka. (Ṣ.)

camatoniI Alr-iyHu signifies The odour annoyed me, or molested me; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) accord. to AḤn: (M:) and took away my breath; referring to a wind emitted from the anus; inf. n. camoIN: (M:) and killed me; (T, M;) accord. to AZ; (T;) aor. tacomiI, (M,) inf. n. camoIN: (TA:) but Aboo-Málik disallows this, and says, you say, camato fiI Oanofihi Alr-iyHu, meaning The odour flew [or rose] into his [nose and] head: and accord. to Aṣ, you say, camaI AlHabaXiI-u fiI Oanofi Alr-ajuli biSunaAnihi, aor. yacomiI, inf. n. camoIN, The Abyssinian annoyed the man in his nose by the odour of his armpits. (T.) One says also, camaI, aor. yacomiI, meaning He, or it, emitted a displeasing odour. (M.)

entry.sense: 4. AcmAhu He left him ill, or sick, (Oawoqacahu, T, or waqacahu, Ḳ, [which latter may mean thus, or he beat him, or struck him, violently, or so that he became at the point of death,, &c.,]) and left him at his last gasp. (T, Ḳ.) And AcmI ramiy-atahu He failed of hitting the animal at which he shot, or cast, in a vital part, and therefore hastened to kill it: (T.) [or] he hit the animal at which he shot, or cast, and drove it along, and it drove along with him. (M.)
10. AstcmI He sought, or demanded, a thing: (M:) or he sought, sought for, or sought after, repeatedly, or gradually, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and took, (Ṣ,) a thing that another had. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
camFI A fetid odour: (M:) an odour that is disliked, hated, or hateful. (Ḳ.)

camaMCN [an inf. n. of 1, (q. v.,) in several senses: as a simple subst., it signifies] Motion [in a slaughtered animal: see 1]: (T, M, Ḳ:) and remains of the soul, or vital principle, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, and Meyd in explanation of a prov. cited in what follows,) in a slaughtered animal: (Ṣ:) or strength of heart: (M, Ḳ:) or the state between slaughter and the exit of the soul; but there is no camaMC in the case of a human being: or strong tenaciousness of life after slaughter. (Meyd in explaining the prov. above referred to.) It is said, AlD-ab-u OaTowalu XaIoCK camaMCF [The lizard called Db- is the longest thing in retaining the remains of life,, &c.]. (T, Ṣ.) Hence the prov., OaTowalu camaMCF mina AlD-ab-i [Longer in retaining the remains of life,, &c., than the Db-]. (Meyd, TA.)
Also ‡ Sickness; as in the saying, fulaAnN baAqiI Alc-amaMCi Such a one is long suffering sickness. (MF.)
And A fracture of the head: and a spear-wound, or the like, such as is termed jaAYifN [q. v.]. (Meyd ubi suprà.)
caAmK (M, Ḳ) and mucam-aApN↓, (M,) or macomaApN, (Ḳ,) An animal shot at, or cast at, which is hit, (M, Ḳ,) and which one drives along, and which drives along with one. (M.)
mucam-aApN, or macomaApN: see what next precedes.

1. can-a, aor. yacn-u, inf. n. caniynN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and cnanu, (Ḳ, [but the latter app. belongs to the verb as said of a man,]) It (what is termed caniyn, Ṣ, or mucus, TA, or a thing, and likewise the seminal fluid, M,) flowed; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,* TA;) [like cam-a, aor. yacim-u;] as also cn-n↓, inf. n. taconiynN, (IAạr, T, Ḳ,) said of what is termed caniyn. (IAạr, T.)
And can-a said of the nose, It flowed [with what is termed caniyn]; (Lth, T;) like cam-a. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. cm.)

And can-a said of a man, (MA,) or canina, (Ḳ, [but this latter I think doubtful,]) see. pers. caninota, (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M,) aor. yacan-u, (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ,) inf. n. cananN (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and caniynN, (Ḳ, [but this latter app. belongs to the verb in the senses explained above,]) His nose flowed (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, MA, Ḳ *) with what is termed caniyn: (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:*) and both his nostrils flowed. (M.)
cananN also signifies The flowing of the eye with tears. (M.) [You say, app., can-ati AlEayonu, meaning The eye flowed with tears]

Uin-ahu layacin-u ‡ Verily he is weak and perishing, by reason of extreme old age, or of disease; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) said of a man: (Ṣ:) or yacin-u, (Ḳ,) or yacin-u fiI maXoyihi, inf. n. caniynN, (Aṣ, T,) means he walks, or goes along, in a weak manner. (Aṣ, T, Ḳ.) And can-N, as an inf. n. [of can-a], signifies † The being in a state of perishing. (KL.)

maA zaAla yacin-u fiI tiloka AlHaAjapi Hat-aI OanojaHahaA ‡ He ceased not to labour, or exert himself, (A, Ḳ, TA,) with moderation and gentleness [to attain that object of want until he accomplished it]. (A, TA.)
can-a Albarodu, inf. n. caniynN, † The cold became intense. (TA.)
2: see 1, first sentence.
3. huwa yucaAn-uhu EalaI HaAjapK † He seeks, or demands, of him an object of want. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.*)
4: see cunaAnapN, below.
cano, for UicaAno or UicFA: see UicFA, in art. AcA.

cananN [originally an inf. n.: see 1:] Dirt, or filth; and tfl [i. e. tufol or tafol, meaning saliva; or froth, or foam, or the like; or perhaps it is a mistranscription for vufol, meaning sediment, settlings, dregs, or lees,, &c.]: mentioned by Suh. (TA.)
cunaAnN: see what next follows.

caniynN (Lḥ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and cunaAnN↓ (Lḥ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) [the former originally an inf. n.: see 1:] Mucus (Lḥ, T,* Ṣ, M, Ḳ) of any sort, (Lḥ, M,) or thin mucus, (M, Ḳ,) or a thin fluid, (Ḳ,) or any fluid, (Lḥ, M, Ḳ,) that flows from the nose. (Lḥ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
And the former signifies also The seminal fluid of a stallion, and of an ass, and of a man, (M, TA,) that flows from the penis by reason of excessive appetence. (TA.)

cunaAnapN A remainder, or remains, of a thing that is weak, or frail, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and perishing; (Ṣ, L; in both of which is added, yucin-uhaA↓ XayoYFA baEoda XaIoCK [app. meaning that leaves it portion after portion, by perishing, or passing away, gradually; but this rendering is purely conjectural, for I have not found the verb here used anywhere explained, nor elsewhere even mentioned];) and particularly of a debt, or of a promise: it is distinguished from cubaAbapN, which signifies a remainder, or remains, of a thing that is sound, or valid, or substantial. (Ṣ, L.)
Also An object of want; syn. HaAjapN. (Ḳ.)

cunaAnaI The mucus of camels: (Ḳ:) or [a fluid] like mucus, that falls from the noses of camels: or, accord. to Kr, it is cunaAbaI: [but see this latter word:] or, as is said by some persons in whom confidence is placed, [in the TA, “in whom confidence is not placed,”] it is termed zunaAnaI: (M:) or it is a dial var. of zunaAnaI: or it is correctly with c. (Ḳ.)

cunayonaMCu is mentioned by AḤn as being in wheat, but not explained by him, except by his likening it to murayoraMC, which is taken forth from wheat and thrown away. (M.) [It is perhaps a mistranscription for cunayobaMCu, q. v.]

cunocunN, (Ṣ, M,) or cinocinN, (T,) The lower, or lowest, part (T, M) of a shirt, (T,) or of a long shirt; a dial. var. of culoculN (M) [or cilocilN]; mentioned by AA: pl. canaAcinu: (T:) the canaAcin of a shirt, (ISk, Ṣ,) or of a garment, (Ḳ,) are like its calaAcil: (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and some say that the n of the former is a substitute for the l of the latter. (TA.)
Oacan-N A man (Ṣ, M) whose nose flows with what is termed caniyn: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and one whose nostrils flow: (T, M:) fem. can-aMCu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) applied to a woman. (Ṣ, M.)
It is also applied to a nose; as in the prov., Oanofuka minoka waUino kaAna Oacan-a [Thy nose is a part of thee though it be flowing with caniyn]. (TA.)
Hence, (TA,) the fem. signifies also ‡ A woman whose menstrual discharge ceases not. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
And qaroHapN can-aMCu † [A wound] that will not be stanched. (TA.)

1. canabahu, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaconubu} (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and _i {yaconibu}, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. canobN; (TḲ;) and Astcnbhu↓; (M, Ḳ;) [properly signifies] He followed his tail, not quitting his track: (M:) [and hence, tropically,] † he followed him [in any case], not quitting his track. (Ḳ.) You say, canaba AlUibila and AstcnbhA↓ He followed the camels. (A: there mentioned among proper significations.) El-Kilábee says,
wajaMCati Alxayolu jamiyEaA taconubuho
[And the horses, or horsemen, came all together, following him]. (Ṣ [in which the meaning is indicated by the context; but whether it be proper or tropical in this instance is not shown].) And Ru-beh says,
mivolu AlOajiyri Qsotaconaba↓ Alr-awaAHilaA
[Like the hired man,] he was at the tails of the ridden camels. (T, Ṣ.) canabati Alqawomu, and [canabati] AlT-ariyqu, and AlOamoru [canaba], and AlsaHaAbu yaconubu baEoDuhu baEoDFA, are tropical phrases [meaning ‡ The people followed one another, and ‡ The road followed on uninterruptedly, and ‡ The affair, or case, or event, proceeded by successive steps, uninterruptedly, and ‡ The clouds follow one another]. (A.)
See also 2.

hom.sense: 2. cn-b, (T, M, A,) inf. n. taconiybN, (T, A,) said of the locust, It stuck its tail into the ground to lay its eggs: (A:) or, said of the [lizard called] Db-, (Lth, T, M,) and of the locust, (M,) and of the [locust in the stage in which it is termed] faraAX, (Lth, T, M,) and the like, (Lth, T,) it desired to copulate, (Lth, T, M,) or to lay eggs, and therefore stuck its tail into the ground: (M:) or, said of the Dab-, it signifies only it struck with its tail a hunter or serpent desiring to catch it: (T:) or, said of the Dab-, it signifies also it put forth its tail (M, A) from the nearest part of its hole, having its head within it, as it does in hot weather, (M,) or when an attempt was made to catch it: (A:) [or it put its tail foremost in coming forth from its hole; contr. of raO-asa.]

can-abati Albusorapu, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or can-aba Albusoru, (Aṣ, A, Mgh,) or Alr-uTabu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. taconiybN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) ‡ [The full-grown unripe date or dates, or the ripening dates,] began to ripen, (Mgh, and so in a copy of the Ṣ,) or showed ripening, (Mṣb, and so in a copy of the Ṣ,)
or became speckled by reason of ripening, (Aṣ, T, M, Ḳ,) or ripened, (A,) at the canab, (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) i. e. the part next the base and stalk. (Mgh.) The dates in this case are termed taconuwbN↓ (Fr, T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) in the dial. of Benoo-Asad, (Fr, T,) and tuconuwbN↓ (Fr, T, Ḳ) in the dial. of Temeem (Fr, T) and mucan-ibN↓; (A, Mgh;) and a single date is termed taconuwbapN↓ (T, M,* Ḳ) and mucan-ibapN↓. (T, Ṣ.)
cn-b AlD-ab-a, [or, probably, canaba↓, being similar to raOasa and janaba and faOada, &c., or perhaps both,] He seized the tail of the Db-; said of one endeavouring to catch it. (A.)
cn-b AlOafoEaI, said of a Dab-, It turned its tail towards the viper, or met the viper tail-foremost, in coming forth from its hole; contr. of raO-asa AlOafoEaI. (TA in art. rOs.)
cn-b EimaAmatahu ‡ [He made a tail to his turban;] (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) i. e. ‡ he made a portion of his turban to hang down like a tail: (Ṣ, TA:) you say of him who has done this, tacan-aba↓. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA.)

can-abotu kalaAmahu [and kitaAbahu ‡ I added an appendix to his discourse and his writing, or book; like cay-alotuhu]. (A, TA.) [Hence, the inf. n. taconiybN is used to signify † An appendix; like tacoyiylN.]
can-abuwA xuXobaAnahu † They made channels for water (which are termed macaAnib) in its rugged ground. (TA from a trad.)

entry.sense: 3. caAnabato, (AO, T, Ḳ,) written by Ṣgh, with his own hand, with C, but by others without, (MF,) said of a mare [in parturition], She was in such a state that her fœtus came to her quHoquH [or ischium (here described by MF as the place of meeting of the two hips)], and the siqoI [q. v. (here explained by MF as a skin containing yellow water)] was near to coming forth, (AO, T, Ḳ,) and the root of her tail rose, and the part thereof that is bare of hair, and she did not [or could not] lower it. (AO, T.) In this case, she is said to be mucaAnibN↓, (AO, T, Ḳ.)

4. Acnb He committed a sin, crime, fault, misdemeanour,, &c.; (Ṣ,* M,* A,* MA, Ḳ;*) he became chargeable with a canob [or sin,, &c.]: (Mṣb:) it is an instance, among others, of a verb of which no proper inf. n. has been heard; [canobN being used instead of such, as a quasi-inf. n.;] for UiconaAbN, like UikoraAmN, [though mentioned in the KL, as signifying the committing of a sin or the like, and also in the TḲ,] has not been heard. (MF.)

hom.sense: 5. tcn-b EalaI fulaAnK He accused such a one of a sin, crime, fault, misdemeanour, or the like, which he had not committed, or though he had not committed any. (A, TA.)
See also 2, near the end of the paragraph.

tacan-abotu AlwaAdiIa ‡ I came to the valley from the direction of its canab [q. v.]. (A.) And tcn-b AlT-ariyqa ‡ He took the road; (Ḳ, TA;) as though he took its cinaAbap, or came to it from [the direction of] its canab. (TA.)
10. Astcnbhu He found him to be committing [or to have committed] a sin, crime, fault, misdemeanour, or the like: and he attributed, or imputed, to him a sin,, &c. (Ḥar p. 450.)
See also 1, in three places.
Astcnb AlOamoru † The affair was, or became, complete, [as though it assumed a tail,] and in a right state. (Ḳ,* TA.)

entry.sense: canobN A sin, a crime, a fault, a misdemeanour, a misdeed, an unlawful deed, an offence, a transgression, or an act of disobedience; syn. UivomN, (T, M, A, Mṣb,) or juromN, (Ṣ,) or both, (TA,) and maEoSiyapN: (T, TA:) or it differs from UivomN in being either intentional or committed through inadvertence; whereas the Avm is peculiarly intentional: (Kull p. 13:) or a thing that precludes one from [the favour of] God: or a thing for which he is blamable who does it intentionally: (KT:) pl. cunuwbN (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and pl. pl. cunuwbaAtN. (M, Ḳ.) walahumo EalaI-a canobN [in the Ḳur xxvi. 13, said by Moses, meaning And they have a crime to charge against me,] refers to the speaker's slaughter of him whom he struck, who was of the family of Pharaoh. (M.)

canabN and cunaAbaI↓ (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and dinib-aI↓ and cunub-aI↓ (El-Hejeree, M, Ḳ) signify the same; (T, Ṣ, M, &c.;) i. e. The tail; syn. cayolN: (TA: [in the CK, Alc-inobiI-u is erroneously put for Alc-inobiI-a:]) but accord. to Fr, one uses the first of these words in relation to the horse, and the second in relation to the bird: (T:) or the first is used in relation to the horse (Ṣ, A) and the ass [and the like] (Ṣ) more commonly than the second; (Ṣ, A;*) and the second is used in relation to a bird (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb) more commonly than the first, (Ṣ, M,*) or more chastely: (M,* Mṣb:) or the second is [properly] of a winged creature; and the first is of any other; but the second is sometimes, metaphorically, of the horse: (Er-Riyáshee, TA:) or, as some say, the second signifies the place of growth of the canab [or tail]: (M:) the pl. of canabN is OaconaAbN. (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [Hence the following phrases, &c.]
rakiba canaba AlbaEiyri [lit. He rode on the tail of the camel, meaning] ‡ he was content with a deficient lot. (T, A, Ḳ.)

Daraba bicanibihi [lit. He smote the earth with his tail, AlOaroDa being understood, meaning] † he (a man) stayed, or abode, and remained fixed. (Ḳ.) [See also another explanation of this phrase below.] And OaqaAma biOaroDinaA wagaraza canabahu, meaning ‡ [He stayed, or abode, in our land, and remained fixed, or] did not quit it; [lit., and stuck his tail into the ground;] originally said of the locust. (A, TA. [See art. grz.])

bayoniI wabayonahu canbu AlD-ab-i [lit. Between me and him is the tail of the Db-,] means ‡ between me and him is opposition or competition [as when two persons are endeavouring to seize the tail of the Db-]. (A, TA.)
AisotaroxaI cnabu AlX-ayoxi ‡ The old man's XaIoC became lax, or languid. (Á, TA.)
rakiba canaba Alr-iyHi [lit. He rode upon the tail of the wind,] means ‡ he outwent, or outstripped, and was not reached, or overtaken. (T, A, Ḳ.)

wal-aI Alxamosiyna canabaA [lit. He turned his tail upon the fifty,] means ‡ he passed the [age of] fifty [years]: (M, TA:) and so walatohu Alxamosuwna canabahaA [lit. the fifty turned their tail upon him]: (A, TA:) the former accord. to Yaạḳoob: accord. to IAạr, El-Kilábee, being asked his age, said, qado wal-ato liIa Alxamosuwna canabahaA [lit. The fifty have turned their tail to me]. (M, TA.)
Ait-abaEa canaba OamorK mudobirK [lit. He followed the tail of an event retreating,] means ‡ he regretted an event that had passed. (T, A,* TA.*)

[The canab of a man is † The part corresponding to the tail: and hence,] rajulN waqaAHu Alc-anabi † [A man hard in the caudal extremity;] meaning † a man very patient in enduring riding. (IAạr, M, and Ḳ in art. wqH.)
[And of a garment, The skirt:] you say, taEal-aqotu biOaconaAbihi ‡ [I clung to his skirts]. (A.)
The canaba of a ship or boat is † The rudder. (Lth and Ṣ * and L in art. skn. [See also xayozuraAnN.])
canabN also signifies [† Anything resembling a tail.]
[Hence,] † The extremity of a whip. (Mgh, Mṣb.)
And, of an unripe date, (M, Mgh,) and of any date, (M,) † The kinder part; (M;) the part next the base and stalk. (Mgh.)
‡ And ‡ The outer extremity of the eye, next the temple; as also cinaAbN↓ and cinaAbapN↓ (M, A) and cunaAbapN↓ (A) [and cunaAbaI↓, as used in the Ḳ voce Aizodaj-a, in art. zj].
See also canuwbN, third sentence.

Also † The end; or last, or latter, part; of anything: pl. cinaAbN (T) [and OaconaAbN]: and cinaAbN↓ [as a sing.], (Ḳ,) or cunaAbN↓, (so in the TT as from the M,) has this meaning. (M, Ḳ.) You say, kaAna celika fiI canabi Ald-ahori † That was in the end of the time [past]. (M.) And canabu AlwaAdiI and AlcunaAbapu↓: both signify the same [i. e. † The end of the valley]: (AʼObeyd, M, TA:) or cunaAbapN↓ and cinaAbapN↓ and canabapN↓ signify the ‡ last, or latter, parts, (Ḳ, TA,) in some copies of the Ḳ, the last, or latter, part, (TA, [and so in the TT as from the M, and this meaning seems to be indicated in the A,]) of a valley, (A, Ḳ, TA,) and of a river, (A, TA,) and of time; (Ḳ, TA;) [and cinaAbN↓ app. has the former of these two significations in relation to a valley, accord. to Az; for he says,] it seems that cinaAbN and cinaAbapN↓ in relation to a valley are pls. of canabN, like as jimaAlN and jimaAlapN are pls. of jamalN: (T:) or cinaAbapN↓ and canabapN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) the former of which is more common than the latter, (Th, Ṣ, Mṣb,) signify † the place to which finally comes the torrent of a valley: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) the pl. of cinaAbapN↓ is canaAYibu: (T:) the canab of a valley and its miconaba↓ are the same; [i. e. † the lowest, or lower, part thereof;] (T;) [for the pls.] OaconaAbN (T, TA) and macaAnibu (TA) signify † the lowest, or lower, parts of valleys: (T, TA:) and OaconaAbN signifies [in like manner] † the last, or latter, parts, of [water-courses such as are termed] tilaAE. (T, TA. See also miconabN.) It is said in a trad, laA yamonaEu fulaAnN canaba taloEapK [† Such a one will not impede the last part of a water-course]; applied to the abject, weak, and contemptible. (T.) And OaconaAbu OumuwrK means ‡ The last, or latter, parts of affairs or events. (M.) You say also, HadiyvN Tawiylu Alc-anabi ‡ [A long-tailed story;] a story that hardly, or never, comes to an end. (M.)
And yawomN Tawiylu Alc-anabi † A day of which the evil does not come to an end: (TA:) and yawomN canuwbN↓ has this meaning; (T, M, TA;) as though it were long in the tail; (M;) or means † a day of long-continued evil. (Ḳ.) And Ait-abaEa cinaAbapa↓ Alqawomi, and AlUibili, ‡ He followed [the last of] the people, and the camels, not quitting their track. (A.)

Also ‡ The followers, or dependants, of a man: (T, TA:) and caAnibN↓ and cunaAbapN↓ † a [single] follower, or dependant: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and OaconaAbN (M, A, Ḳ) and cunaAbaI↓ (Ṣ) and danaAYibu [pl. of cunaAbapN↓] (A) and cunubaAtN↓, (so in the TT as from the M,) or canabaAtN↓, (Ḳ,) but some state that this last is not said of men, (Ḥam p. 249,) ‡ followers, or dependants, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) of a people or party; (M, Ḳ;) and the lower, or lowest, sort, or the rabble, or refuse, thereof; (M, A, Ḳ;) and such as are below the chiefs. (TA.) Daraba yaEosuwbu Ald-iyni bicanabihi, in a trad. of ʼAlee, means, [accord. to some, † The leader of the religion] shall go away through the land with followers, or dependants, (T,* TA,) and those holding his opinions. (T. [But see arts. Drb and Esb.]) And EuqayolN TawiylapN Alc-anabi, a phrase mentioned by IAạr, but not explained by him, app. means † [The tribe of] 'Okeyl have numerous horsemen. (M.)

[Also canabN (as will be shown by the use of its pl. in the verse here following) and] cinaAbN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or cunaAbN↓, (so in the TT as from the M,) † The sequel, consequence, or result, syn. EaqibN, of anything. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) A poet says,
taEal-aqota mino OaconaAbi law-K balayotaniI
walayota kalaw-K xayobapN layosa yanofaEu
[From considering what might be the sequels of “if,” (i. e. of the word lawo,) Thou clungest to the reflection “Would that I had done so and so:” but “would that,” like “if,” is disappointment: it does not profit]. (TA.) And one says, mano laka bicinaAbi↓ law-K i. e. [Who will be responsible to thee for] the sequel [of the word lawo]? (TA:) [or, as in the Proverbs of El-Meydánee, bicunaAbapi↓ law-K, which means the same.]
canabu Als-iroHaAni: see art. srH.

canabu Alfarasi † A certain asterism (najomN, M, Ḳ, TA) in the sky, (TA,) resembling the canab [or tail] of the horse. (M, Ḳ.) [Alc-anabu is a name applied to each of several stars or asterisms: as † The star a of Cygnus; also called canabu Ald-ajaAjapi, and Alr-idofu: and † The star beta of Leo; also called canabu AlOasadi. And Alr-aOosu waAlc-anabu signifies † The two nodes of a planet: see tin-iynN.]

canabu Alxayoli, (Ḳ,) or OaconaAbu Alxayoli, (M,) † A certain herb, (M, Ḳ,) of which the expressed juice concretes: so called by way of comparison [to horses' tails: the latter name is now applied to the equisetum, or horse-tail]. (M.) [Accord. to Forskål, (Flora Aegypt. Arab., p. cxii.,) the Portulaca oleracea (or garden-purslane) is called in some parts of El-Yemen canabu Alfarasi.] canabu Alv-aEolabi † A certain plant, resembling the canab [or tail] of the fox; (M, Ḳ;) a name applied by some of the Arabs to the canabaAn [q. v.] (T.)
[canabu Als-abuEi † Cauda leonis, i. e. circium (or cirsium): (Golius, from Diosc. iv. 119:) now applied to the common creeping way-thistle.]
[canabu AlfaOorapi † Cauda muris, i. e. plantago. (Golius, from Ibn-Beytár.)]
[canaba Alvawori † A species of aristida, supposed by Forskål (Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. civ,) to be the aristida adscensionis.]
[canabu AlEaqorabi † Scorpioides, or scorpion-grass: so called in the present day.]
canabapN, and its pl. canabaAtN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
cunubaAtN: see canabN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

canabaAnN A certain plant, (T, Ṣ,) well known, called by some of the Arabs canabu Alv-aEolabi: (T:) a certain plant having long branches, somewhat dust-coloured (M, TA) in its leaves, growing in plain, or soft, land, upon the ground, not rising high, approved as pasture, (TA,) and not growing except in fruitful years: (M, TA:) or a certain herb, or plant, like curap [or millet]; (Ḳ;) or a certain herb having ears at its extremities like the ears of curap, (M, TA,*) and having reeds, (qSb [i. e. qaSab], M,) or twigs, (qDb [i. e. quDub], TA,) and leaves, growing in every place except in unmixed sand, [for Hur-a Alr-amoli in the TA, I find in the M Haw-a Alrumli,] and growing upon one stem and two stems: (M, TA:) or, accord. to AḤn, a certain herb, having a jzrp [app. meaning rhizoma like the carrot], which is not eaten, and twigs bearing a fruit from the bottom thereof to the top thereof, having leaves like those of the Turoxuwn, agreeing well with the pasturing cattle, and having a small dust-coloured blossom upon which bees feed; (M, TA;) rising about the height of a man, (TA,) or half the height of a man; (M;) two whereof suffice to satiate a camel: (M, TA:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p {canabaAnapN}. (M, Ḳ.)
cunub-aI and cinib-aI: see canabN, first sentence.
cunaAbN: see canabN, in two places.
cinaAbN: see canabN, in five places:
and see also miconabN.
Also A small cord with which a camel's tail is tied to his hind girth, lest he should swing about his tail and so dirt his rider. (M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: canuwbN A horse (T, Ṣ, &c.) having a long tail: (T, Ṣ:) or having a full, or an ample, tail. (M, A, Ḳ.) [See also OaconabN.]
Hence applied to a day: see canabN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

Also A great dalow [or bucket]: (Fr, T, Mṣb:) or one that has a canab↓ [or tail]: (TA:) or one that is full (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) of water; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) not applied to one that is empty: (Ṣ, TA:) or one that is nearly full of water: (ISk, Ṣ:) or one containing less than fills it: or one containing water: or a dalow (M, Ḳ) in any case: (M:) or a bucketful of water: (A:) masc. and fem.; (Fr, Lḥ, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb;) sometimes the latter: (Lḥ, M:) pl. (of pauc., Ṣ) OaconibapN and (of mult., Ṣ) canaAYibu (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and cinaAbN. (M, A,* Mṣb, Ḳ.) Fr. cites as an ex.,
lanaA canuwbN walakumo canuwbu
faUino Oabayotumo falanaA Alqaliybu
[as meaning For you shall be a great bucket, and for us a great bucket: or, if ye refuse this, for us shall be the well]. (T.) [Accord. to the Ḳ, it also signifies A grave: but this is evidently a mistake, which seems to have arisen from a misunderstanding of a statement by ISd, who says,] Aboo-Dhu-eyb uses it metaphorically in relation to a grave, calling it [i. e. the grave] a well, in his saying,
fakunotu canuwba AlbiYora lam-aA tabas-alato
wasurobilotu OakofaAniI wawus-idotu saAEidiI [app. meaning ‡ And I was as though I were the corpse of the grave (lit. the bucket of the well) when she frowned, and clad with my grave-clothes, and made to recline upon my upper arm: for the corpse is laid in the grave upon its right side, or so inclined that the face is turned towards Mekkeh]. (M.) [And Umeiyeh Ibn-Abee- 'Áïdh El-Hudhalee, describing a wild he-ass and she-asses, likens to it a certain rate of running which he contrasts with another rate likened by him to a well such as is termed xasiyfN: see Kosegarten's “Carmina Hudsailitarum,” p. 189.]
Hence metaphorically applied to ‡ Rain. (Ḥam p. 410.)

[Hence, also,] ‡ A lot, share, or portion: (Fr, T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [see the former of the two verses cited in this paragraph:] in this sense masc.: (Mṣb:) and in this sense it is used in the Ḳur li. last verse but one. (Fr, T, M.)

Also ‡ The flesh of the [portion of the back next the back-bone, on either side, which is called the] maton: (M, Ḳ:) or the part where the maton ends; (M;) the flesh of the lower, or lowest, part of the maton: (Ṣ:) or the [buttocks, or parts called] Oaloyap and maOokim: (M, Ḳ:) or the flesh of the Oaloyap and maMkim: (CK:) and the canuwbaAni are the [two parts called the] matonaAni, (M, Ḳ,) on this side and on that [of the back-bone]: (M:) or canuwbu Almatoni means the flesh that is called yaraAbiyEu Almatoni [which are the portions of flesh next the back-bone, on either side thereof]. (A.)
cunayobN [dim. of canabN:]
[and] i. q. cunayobiI-N, q. v. (TA.)

entry.sense: dunaAbapN The Oalof [i. e. toe, or foremost extremity, also called the Oasalap,] of a sandal. (Ḳ.)
See also canabN, in six places.
And see miconabN.

hom.sense: cinaAbapN: see canabN, in six places:
and see miconabN, in two places.

cinaAbapN AlT-ariyqi † The point, or place, to which the way, or road, leads; syn. wajohuhu. (IAạr, M, Ḳ.) So in the saying of Abu-l-Jarráh, to a certain man, Uin-aka lamo taroXado cinaAbapa AlT-ariyqi [† Verily thou didst not follow a right course in respect of the point, or place, to which the way that thou tookest leads]. (IAạr, M.)
Also † Relationship; nearness with respect to kindred; or near relationship. (Ḳ.)
cunaAbaI: see canabN, in three places.
It is also applied to Four [feathers] in the wing of a bird, after what are called AlxawafiI. (Ṣ.)

It is said in a trad., mano maAta EalaI cunaAbaI TariyqK fahuwa mino Oaholihi, meaning [† Whosoever dies] purposing to pursue a way leading to some particular end, [he is to be reckoned as one of the people thereof.] (TA.)
Accord. to Fr and the Ṣ, it signifies also A fluid like mucus that falls from the noses of camels: but this is a mistake: the right word, as stated by IB and others, is cunaAnaI. (L, MF, TA.)

entry.sense: cunayobaMCu A certain grain that is found in wheat, whereof the latter is cleared [by winnowing or other means]. (M, Ḳ.) [See also cunayonaMCu, in art. cn.]
cunayobiI-N † A certain kind of [the striped garments called] buruwd [pl. of burodN]; (AHeyth, Ḳ;) as also cunayobN↓. (TA.)
caAnibN ‡ Following in the track of a thing. (TA.) See also canabN, in the latter half of the paragraph.
Oaconabu A [lizard of the kind called] Dab- having a long tail. (T, L.) [See also canuwbN.]
taconuwbN and tuconuwbN, and with p {taconuwbapN}: see 2.
maconabN: see the next paragraph.
miconabN A long tail. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.)
And [hence, app. for cuw miconabK], (T,) or mucan-ibN↓, (TA, [but see this latter below,]) A [lizard of the kind called] Dab-. (T, TA.)
Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or maconabN↓, like maqoEadN, (A,) and miconabapN↓, (M, TA,) † A ladle; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) because it has a tail, or what resembles a tail: (M:) pl. macaAnibu. (Ṣ, M.)

And † A water-course, or channel of a torrent, in a tract at the foot of a mountain; (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) not wide; (A;) or not very wide; (M;) or not very long and wide; (Lth, T;) as also cinaAbapN↓: (Ṣ:) the taloEap is in the lower part of a mountain (Lth, T, A) or in an acclivity: (Lth, T, Ṣ, A:) also a water-course or channel of a torrent, between what are termed taloEataAni; (TA; [see taloEapN, and see also madofaEN;]) or this is termed canabu↓ taloEapK; (T;) or it is termed cinaAbN↓, of which the pl. is canaAYibu: (M, Ḳ:) also a water-course, or channel of a torrent, [running] to a tract of land: (M, Ḳ:) and a rivulet, or streamlet, (Ḳ,) or the like thereof, (AḤn, T, M,) flowing from one rawoDap [or meadow] to another, (AḤn, T, M, Ḳ,) and separating therein; (T;) as also cunaAbapN↓ and cinaAbapN↓; (Ḳ;) and the tract over which this flows is also called miconabN. (T.) See also canabN, in the middle of the paragraph.
miconabapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

mucan-ibN [app. applied to a she-camel, accord. to the Ḳ, or perhaps to a lizard of the kind called Dab-, as seems to be indicated in the TA,] Finding difficulty in parturition, and therefore stretching out her tail: (Ḳ:) [but accord. to Az,] it is applied to a Dab- only when he is striking with his tail a hunter or a serpent desiring to catch him. (T.) See also miconabN.
See also 2, in two places.
maconuwbN ‡ A man followed [by dependants]. (A.)
mucaAnibN A camel that is at the rear of other camels; (Ḳ;) as also musotaconibN↓. (TA.)
See also 3.
saHaAbN mutacaAnibN ‡ Clouds following one another. (A.)
musotaconibN: see mucaAnibN.
Also One who is at the tails of camels, (Ṣ, TA,) not quitting their track. (TA.)
ciho and cihiI: see art. cA.

hom.sense: 1. cahaba, (Ṣ, A, &c.,) aor. _a {yacohabu}, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. cahaAbN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and cihaAbN (TA) and cuhuwbN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and macohabN, (A, Ḳ,) He (a man, Ṣ, [and a beast,]) went [in any manner, or any pace]; went, or passed, along; marched; journeyed; proceeded: went, or passed, away; departed: syn. maXaI, (A,) or saAra, (Ḳ,) or mar-: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) and said of a mark or trace or the like [as meaning it went away]. (Mṣb.) [And hence, † It wasted away; became consumed, destroyed, exhausted, spent, or expended.]

cahaba Uilayohi He went, repaired, betook himself, or had recourse, to him, or it. (TA.) And they say also, cahaba AlX-aOoma [He went to Syria]; making the verb trans. without a particle; for although AlXOm is here a special adv. n., they liken it to a vague locality. (TA.)
cahaba Eanohu He, or it, went from, quitted, relinquished, or left, him, or it. (TA.)

cahaba fiI AlOaroDi, (A, Mṣb,) inf. n. cahaAbN and cuhuwbN and macohabN, He went away [into the country, or in the land]: (Mṣb:) [but it often means † he went into the open country, or out of doors, to satisfy a want of nature: or simply] ‡ he voided his excrement, or ordure. (A.)

cahaba bihi He went, or went away, with him, or it: (A:) and he made him, or it, to go, go away, pass away, or depart; (A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Achbhu↓, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Achb↓ bihi, (Ḳ,) but this is rare; (Zj, TA;) and ch-bhu↓, inf. n. tacohiybN: (MF:) [all may likewise be rendered he removed, dispelled, put away, or banished, it; properly and tropically: and † he made it to cease; made away with it, did away with it, made an end of it; wasted, consumed, destroyed, exhausted, spent, or expended, it; and these meanings may perhaps be intended by OazaAlahu, whereby the first is explained in the A and Ḳ, as are also the second and third in the Ḳ:] or, accord. to some, when cahaba is trans. by means of bi, accompaniment is necessarily signified; but not otherwise; so that if you say cahaba bihi, the meaning is, he went away with him, or it; i. e., accompanying him, or it; [he took away, or carried off or away, him, or it;] but if you say Achbhu↓ or ch-bhu↓, the meaning is, he made him, or it, to go, go away, pass away, or depart, alone, without accompanying him, or it: this, however, is not agreeable with the phrase in the Ḳur [ii. 16], cahaba Qll-ehu binuwrihimo [though this may be well rendered God taketh away their light]. (MF, TA.) [Hence,] one says, Oayona yucohabu bika, which may mean † Where, or whither, wilt thou be taken away, and what will be done with thee and made to come to pass with thee, if this be thine intellect? or, accord. to Mṭr, it is a saying of the people of Baghdád, addressed to him whom they charge with foolish judgment or opinion, as meaning Oayona yucohabu biEaqolika † [Where, or whither, is thine intellect taken away?]. (Ḥar p. 574.) [In like manner one says, cahaba Eaqoluhu † His reason, or intellect, quitted him, or forsook him; he became bereft of his reason, or intellect. And cahaba fuWaAduhu † His heart forsook him, or failed him, by reason of fear or the like.] And cahaba laHomuhu † [His flesh wasted away]. (Ḳ in art. bHr, &c.) And cahaba Alr-ajulu fiI Alqawomi ‡ The man became lost [or he disappeared] among the people, or party. (A.) And cahaba AlmaMCa fiI All-abani ‡ The water became lost [or it disappeared] in the milk. (A.)
cahaba Ealayohi ‡ It escaped his memory; he forgot it. (A, TA.) And † It was, or became, dubious, confused, or vague, to him. (MA.)

cahaba macohabFA HasanFA (Ṣ, A, TA) ‡ He pursued a good way, course, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like. (TA.) And cahaba fiI Ald-iyni macohabFA † He formed, or held, an opinion, or a persuasion, or a belief, respecting religion: or, accord. to Es-Sarakustee, he introduced an innovation in religion. (Mṣb.) And cahaba macohaba fulaAnK † He pursued the way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, &c. of such a one. (Mṣb.) And cahaba licahobihi and limacohabihi ‡ He pursued his way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, &c. (JK, TA.) And cahaba UilaI macohabK ‡ He betook himself to [or took to or held] a belief, a creed, a persuasion, a doctrine, an opinion, a tenet, or a body of tenets or articles of belief. (Ḳ, TA.) And fulaAnN yacohabu UilaI qawoli OabiI Haniyfapa ‡ Such a one takes to, or holds, [the saying, or] the belief, creed, persuasion, doctrine,, &c., of Aboo-Ḥaneefeh. (A.) [And cahaba UilaI Oan-a AlOamora kacaA † He held, or was of opinion, that the thing, or affair, or case, was so. And cahaba bilafoZK UilaIlafoZK Mxara † He regarded a word, or an expression, in his manner of using it, as equivalent to another word, or expression; as, for instance, when one makes a fem. noun masc. because it is syn. with a noun that is masc., or makes a verb trans. by means of a certain perticle because it is syn. with a verb that is trans. by means of that same particle: and also † he regarded a word, or an expression, as etymologically relating, or traceable, to another word, or expression. And cahaba bihi UilaI maEonaI kacaA † He regarded it, or used it, (i. e. a word, or an expression,) as relating to such a meaning, or as meaning such a thing.]

cahaba fiI Talabi AlX-aIoCi kul-a macohabK † [He tried every way, or did his utmost, in seeking the thing]. (Ḳ in art. mwt.) And cahaba fiI All-iyni kul-a macohabK † [It attained the utmost degree of softness]: said of the skin. (TA in that art.)
Aicohabo Uilayoka † Betake, or apply, thyself to thine own affairs; or occupy thyself therewith. (T and Ḳ * voce UilaI.)
cahaba UilaI Oabiyhi fiI AlX-abahi i. q. nazaEa † [He inclined to his father in likeness; resembled him; or had a natural likeness to him]. (Ṣ in art. nzE.)

cahiba, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yacohabu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. cahabN; (TA;) and cihiba, with two kesrehs, (IAạr, Ḳ,) of the dial. of Temeem, held by AM to be a variation generally allowable in the case of a verb of which the medial radical letter is a faucial and with kesr; (TA;) He (a man) saw gold in the mine, (Ṣ,) or came suddenly, in the mine, upon much gold, and his reason departed in consequence thereof, (Ḳ,) and his eyes became dazzled, so as not to close, or move, the lids, or became confused, so as not to see, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) by reason of the greatness thereof in his eye: (Ṣ:) it is derived from cahabN: and the epithet applied to a man in this case is cahibN↓. (TA.)
2: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in two places:
and see also 4.
4: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in three places.
Also Achbhu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UicohaAbN; (Ṣ;) and ch-bhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tacohiybN; (Ṣ;) He gilded it; did it over with gold. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: [Q. Q. 2. tamacohaba, from macohabN, is used by late writers as meaning † He followed, or adopted, a certain religious persuasion or the like.]

hom.sense: cahobN: see macohabN:
and see also the last sentence of the paragraph here following.

cahabN [Gold;] a certain thing well known; (Ṣ, Mṣb, &c.;) accord. to several of the leading lexicologists, (TA,) i. q. tiborN; (A, L, Ḳ, &c.;) but it seems to have a more general meaning; for tiborN is specially applied to such [gold] as is in the mine, or such as is uncoined and unwrought: (TA:) [it is a coll. gen. n.; and therefore] it is masc. and fem.: (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA:) or it is fem. in the dial. of El-Ḥijáz: or, accord. to Az, it is masc., and not to be made fem. unless regarded as pl. of cahabapN↓, (Mṣb, TA,) [or rather as a coll. gen. n., for] cahabapN is the n. un., (Ḳ,) signifying a piece of cahab [or gold]: (Ṣ, A, L, TA:) or, accord. to El-Kurtubee, it is fem., and sometimes masc., but more commonly fem.: cuhayobapN↓ is the dim. of cahabN, the p being added because the latter word is fem., like as it is in quwayosapN and XumayosapN; or it is the dim. of cahabapN, and signifies a little piece of cahab [or gold]: (TA:) the pl. of cahabN is OacohaAbN [a pl. of pauc.] (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and cuhuwbN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and cuhobaAnN (Nh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and cihobaAnN. (Nh, TA.) [maMCu Alc-ahabi means Water-gold; goldpowder mixed with size, for ornamental writing, &c.]
The yolk, or the entire contents, i. e. yolk and white, (muH-, Ḳ, TA, with the unpointed H, TA, [in the CK and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ mux-,]) of an egg. (Ḳ.)

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in a copy of the T written cahobN↓, (TA,) A certain measure of capacity, for corn, used by the people of El-Yemen, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) well known: (Ṣ:) pl. cihaAbN (Ḳ) and OacohaAbN, [the latter a pl. of pauc.,] (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and pl. pl. [i. e. pl. of the latter of the pls. above] OacaAhibu, (Ṣ, and so in the Ḳ accord. to the TA,) mentioned by A' Obeyd, (Ṣ,) or OacaAhiybu. (So in the CK.)

entry.sense: cahibN: see 1, last sentence.
cihobapN A rain: (Ṣ:) or a weak rain: or a copious rain: (AʼObeyd, Ḳ:) pl. cihaAbN. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
cahabapN: see cahabN, first sentence.
cahuwbN: see caAhibN.
cahiybN: see mucohabN, first sentence.
cuhayobapN: see cahabN, first sentence.

caAhibN [part. n. of cahaba;] Going [in any manner, or any pace]; going, or passing, along; marching; journeying; proceeding: going, or passing, away; departing: [&c.:] (A, Ḳ:) and cahuwbN↓ signifies the same [in an intensive manner]. (Ḳ.)
[caAhibN fiI AlT-uwli means † Excessive in length or tallness.]
macohabN is an inf. n.: (JK, A, Ḳ:)
and also signifies A place of cahaAb [or going,, &c.]: and a time thereof. (JK.)
[Also A place to which one goes: see an ex. voce maHoDarN.]
[And hence,] ‡ A place to which one goes for the purpose of satisfying a want of nature; a privy; (TA;) i. q. mutawaD-aON; (JK, A, Ḳ, TA;) in the dial. of the people of El-Ḥijáz. (JK, A, TA.)
[Also A way by which one goes or goes away.]

[And hence, as in several exs. in the first paragraph of this art.,] ‡ A way, course, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like: (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) ‡ [a way that one pursues in respect of doctrines and practices in religion, &c.; and particularly a way of believing, opining, thinking, or judging;] a belief, a creed, a persuasion, a doctrine, an opinion, a tenet, or a body of tenets or articles of belief; (Ḳ, TA;) an opinion in, or respecting, religion; and, accord. to Es-Sarakustee, an innovation in religion: (Mṣb:) and cahobN↓ signifies the same. (JK, TA.) [The pl. is macaAhibu. Hence, cawuw macaAhibu † Persuasions, as meaning persons holding particular tenets in religion or the like.]
Also † Origin: (Ks, Lḥ, Ḳ:) so in the sayings, maA yudoraI lahu Oayona macohabahu and laA yudoraI lahu macohabN, i. e. † It is not known whence is his origin. (Ks, Lḥ, TA.)

hom.sense: mucohabN Gilt, or done over with gold; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also mucah-abN↓ (A, Ḳ) and cahiybN↓. (T, Ḳ.)

Also sing. of macaAhibu, which signifies Skins gilt, (ISk, JK, TA,) i. e. having gilt tines, or stripes, regularly, or uniformly, succeeding one another: (ISk, TA:) or gilt straps or thongs: (Ṣ, TA:) and variegated, or figured, [garments of the kind called] buruwd: (JK, TA:) [or it is applied as an epithet to such garments; for] you say burodN mucohabN. (TA.) The pl. above mentioned is also applied [as an epithet] to swords [app. meaning Adorned with gilding]. (TA.)

Applied to a horse, Of a red colour tinged over with yellow; (TA;) and so kumayotN mucohabN [i. e. of a gilded bay colour]: (Ṣ, TA:) fem. with p {mucohabapN}: the mare thus termed is of a clearer colour and thinner skin. (TA.)
Almucohabu is also a name of The Kaabeh. (Ḳ, TA.)
See also the next paragraph, in three places.

entry.sense: mucohibN A gilder. (Ṣ.)

Almucohabu↓, explained by Lth as the name of † A certain devil, said to be of the offspring of Iblees, who tempts reciters of the Ḳur-án in the performance of [the ablution termed] AlwuDuwoC, (Ḳ,* TA,) and on other occasions, (TA,) is [said to be] correctly [Almucohibu,] with kesr to the h: (Ḳ:) applied to the devil, (TA in art. XyT,) as meaning † he who embellishes, or renders goodly in appearance, acts of disobedience [to God], as also Almuhac-ibu, (Fr, TA in art. hcb,) IDrd thinks that it is not [genuine] Arabic. (TA.) And accord. to the Ṣ and El-Kurtubee and many others, bihi mucohabN↓ means † [In him is] a vain suggestion [of the devil] respecting the water, and [respecting] the using much thereof in the wuDuwoC: [i. e. a vain suggestion that may induce him to think that the water is unfit, or deficient in quantity, or the like:] but accord. to the Ḳ, it is correctly Almucohibu. (TA.) Az says that the people of Baghdád apply the appellation mucohibN to † A man who inspires vain suggestions; and that the vulgar among them pronounce it mucohabN↓. (TA.)

macohabapN [A cause, or means, of doing away with, removing, dispelling, or banishing]. Fasting is said, in a trad., to be macohabapN liloOaXari [i. e. † A cause, or means, of dispelling exultation, or excessive exultation, and resting the mind upon things agreeable with natural desire]. (T and Ṣ voce maHosamapN, q. v.)
mucah-abN: see mucohabN.

hom.sense: See also what next follows {4}.

entry.sense: 4. OacohalaniI Eanohu, (JK,* Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. UicohaAlN, (TA,) It (a thing, JK, Ṣ, TA,) or he, (a man, Mṣb,) caused me to forget it, or neglect it; (Ṣ;) or to be unmindful of it; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) or to neglect it intentionally: (JK:) [like OacahananiI Enh:] and sometimes one says cahalaniI↓; (Mṣb, TA;) [like cahananI;] but this is rare; or, rather, unknown. (TA.)
caholN: see what next follows.

hom.sense: jaMCa baEoda cuholK mina All-ayoli, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) and caholK↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He came after a short portion, or a period, (saAEap, Ḳ, or hadoC, Ṣ,) of the night: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so called because sleep causes men to forget (yucohilu Aln-aAsa) therein: (Ḥam p. 4:) or a large portion; such as the third, or the half: so says IDrd; but he doubts its correctness; and ISd holds it to be preferably with d. (TA.)
cuholN also signifies The tree [or plant] baXaAm [q. v.]. (JK, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: cuholuwlN A horse fleet, or swift: (Ḳ:) or light, or active: and so a man: pl. cahaAliylu. (JK.)
caAhilN [act. part. n. of 1.]
[And] A man who cares not for ornament and the anointing of himself. (JK.)

hom.sense: 1. cahina, (MA, TA,) aor. _a {yacohanu}, (TA,) inf. n. cihonN and cahanN, (MA, KL,) He was, or became, intelligent, possessed of understanding, sagacious, acute, skilful, knowing, (MA, KL, PṢ, TA,) and endowed with a retentive mind. (KL, PṢ.) You say, Aicohano UilaI maA Oaquwlu Understand thou what I say. (TA.) And huwa laA yacohanu XayoYFA He does not understand anything. (TA.) And cahinotu kacaA wakacaA I understood such and such things. (TA) And cahinotu Eano kacaA I understood from such a thing. (TA.)
caAhananiI facahanotuhu: see 3.

cahananiI Eanohu, and OacohananiI↓, and AisotacohananiI↓, He, or it, made me to forget it; diverted me from remembering it: (Ḳ,* TA:) [like cahalaniI Eanohu, and OacohalaniI.] And cuhina Memory, or understanding, escaped him, or left him. (JK.)

entry.sense: 3. caAhananiI facahanotuhu↓ He vied with me, or contended with me for superiority, in intelligence, understanding, sagacity, acuteness, skill, or knowledge, and I surpassed him [therein, i. e.,] in cihon. (Ḳ.)
4: see 1.
You say also, Aisotacohanaka Hub-u Ald-unoyaA The love of the present world took away, or has taken away, thy cihon [i. e. intelligence, understanding,, &c.]. (TA.)
And Aisotacohanati Als-anapu AlqaSaba † The year of drought took away the cihon, i. e. pith (niqoI), of the canes, or reeds. (TA.)

hom.sense: cihonN (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and cahanN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) Intellect, intelligence, understanding, sagacity, acuteness, skill, or knowledge; syn. EaqolN, (JK, Ḳ,) and fahomN, (Ḳ,) and fiTonapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and cakaMCN; (Mṣb;) and retentiveness of mind, or memory: (JK,* Ṣ,* Ḳ:) or, as some say, a faculty of the soul, provided for the acquisition of the several species of knowledge, including the external and internal senses: strength thereof is termed cakaMCN: and a good quality thereof for the forming ideas of the things that present themselves to it is termed fiTonapN: (TA:) pl. OacohaAnN. (Mṣb, Ḳ.*) One says, AijoEalo cihonaka UilaI kacaA wakacaA [Apply thine intellect,, &c., to such and such things]. (TA.) [Both are also inf. ns.: see 1, first sentence.]

Also, the former, † Strength: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and fat: (JK, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.) One says, maA birijolaI-a cihonN There is not in my legs any strength to walk. (TA.) And huwa mino Oaholi Alc-ihoni and AlOacohaAni ‡ He is of those endowed with strength [of body: and also, of those endowed with intelligence,, &c., and intelligent faculties]. (TA.) And maA raOayotu biAlUibili cihonFA † I saw not, in the camels, fat and strength. (JK.)
Also † The pith (niqoI) of canes, or reeds. (TA.)
See also cahinN.

entry.sense: cahanN: see the next preceding paragraph.

cahinN and cihonN↓ Intelligent, possessed of understanding, sagacious, acute, skilful, or knowing, [and endowed with a retentive mind;] each [said to be] a possessive epithet, [signifying possessing cihon, though the former is agreeable with a general rule as part. n. of cahina,] applied to a man; the latter app. changed [or contracted] from the former. (TA.)

[cihoniI-N Of, or relating to, the cihon, or intellect,, &c.; intellectual; subjective; ideal. Hence, AlOamuwru Alc-ihoniy-apu Intellectual things; the things that are conceived in the mind, or considered subjectively; opposed to AlOamuwru AlxaArijiy-apu.]

cuw meaning SaAHib [i. e. A possessor, an owner, a lord, or a master, but often better rendered having, possessing, possessed of, or endowed with], (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, but omitted in the CK,) used as a prefixed noun, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, &c.,) is originally cawFA, like EaSFA, the A being changed from w; (Ṣ;) or it is originally caw-aI; and if one used it as a proper name, he would say, hecaA caw-aIqado jaMCa [This is Dhawà, he has come]; (M;) [not cawFA, as in copies of the Ṣ; i. e.,] its third radical letter is I, not, as J says, w; this I being afterwards suppressed; (IB;) [so that the word becomes cawN, and then, by reason of its being prefixed to another noun, cuw, like as OabawN, the original form of OabN, becomes Oabuw:] it is declined [like Oabuw] with w and | and Ii; (Mṣb;) [i. e.,] the nom. case is cuw, accus. caA, and gen. ciI: (Mgh:) the fem. is caAtu; (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ; in a copy of the M, cAp, and the CK, caApN [as though it were not a prefixed noun];) and in the case of a pause, some say caAto, and others say caAho: (Lth, T: the latter usage, only, is mentioned in the Ṣ:) dual. masc., cawaA, (Ṣ,* M,) [accus and gen. cawaIo;] fem. cawaAtaA, (T, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) for which caAtaA is allowable in poetry, but cawaAtaA is better, (T,) [accus, and gen. cawaAtaIo:] pl., masc., cawuw, (T,*, Ṣ,* M, Mṣb, Ḳ, but omitted in the CK,) [accus, and gen. cawiI;] fem. cawaAtu, (T, Ṣ,* M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) accus. and gen. cawaAti; (Ṣ;) and Ouwluw and OuwlaAt are like cawuw and cawaAt [in signification]. (T. [See art. Alw.]) In this sense it is not used otherwise than as a prefixed noun: when used to characterize an indeterminate noun, prefixed to an indeterminate noun; and when used to characterize a determinate noun, prefixed to [a noun rendered determinate by] the article Al. (Ṣ.) [Thus you say rajulN cuw maAlK A man a possessor of wealth; and Alr-ajulu cuw AlmaAli The man the possessor of wealth.] In the phrase gayora caAti AlXawokapi [Not those possessed of weapons,, &c.], in the Ḳur [viii. 7], the fem. form is used as meaning the TaAYifap [or party]. (T.) SaAra caA canobK [He became one having a sin, or crime,, &c., attributable to him, i. e. he had a sin,, &c., attributable to him,] means taHam-ala canobFA [he became chargeable with a sin,, &c.]. (Mṣb in art. cnb.)

Accord. to the Ṣ, it is not prefixed to a pronoun (muDomar); nor to a proper name, such as zayod and Eamorw and the like: but there are several instances of its being prefixed, in its pl. form, to a pronoun; among which is the saying of a poet,
Uin-amaA yaSoTaniEu AlmaEoruwfu fiI Aln-aAsi cawuwhu
[Only they who are possessors thereof do that which is good among men]: (TA:) [this usage, however, is perhaps only allowable by poetic license: see another ex. (also here cited in the TA) in the Ḥam p. 442, and the remarks there appended to it:] and it is also prefixed to proper names, as is shown by the phrase, (TA,) hecaA cuw zayodK (M, Ḳ, TA,) mentioned, as heard from the Arabs, by Aḥmad Ibn-Ibráheem, the preceptor of Th, meaning This is Zeyd, (M, TA,) i. e., this is the owner of the name Zeyd; (M, Ḳ, TA;) and [perhaps] by the name cuw AlxalaSapi, for AlxlSp is [said by some to be] the name of a certain idol, and cw is a metonymical appellation of its bayot; and by the proper names cuw ruEayonK and cuw yazana and [accord. to some] cuw jadonK [and the like, of which several are mentioned in the Ṣ, as well as in the M, &c.]. (IB, TA.) [But see a later portion of this paragraph, where, prefixed to a proper name, it is said to be redundant.]

cawuw AlOaroHaAm, [or, as in the Ḳur viii. last verse, and xxxiii. 6, Ouwluw AlOaroHaAmi, pls. of cuw Alr-aHimi,] in the classical language, means [The possessors of relationship; i. e.] any relations:
and in law, any relations that have no portion [of the inheritances termed faraAYiD] and are not [such heirs as are designated by the appellation] EaSabap [q. v.: they are so called because they are relations by the women's side: see raHimN]. (KT, TA.)

If you form a pl. from cuwmaAlK, you say, heWulaMCi cawuwna [These are possessors of wealth]; because in this case the pl. is not a prefixed noun. (Ṣ.) Accord. to Lth, Alc-awuwna signifies The former, or first, [of persons,] and the more, or most, distinguished. (T, TA.*) Also, (Ṣ, M,) and AlOacowaMCu, [which is another pl. of cuw,] (Ṣ,) The kings (Ṣ, M) of El-Yemen, of the tribe of Ḳuḍáʼah, (Ṣ,) whose surnames commenced with cuw, (M,) [i. e.] who were named [or rather surnamed] (Ṣ) cuw yazana (Ṣ, M) and cuw jadanK and cuw nuwaAsK (Ṣ) and the like. (Ṣ, M.) quraXiI-N layosa mino ciI walaA cuw, occurring in a trad., means A Kurashee in respect of lineage, not of the OacowaMC [above mentioned]. (TA.)

[cuw and caAt and caA and ciI are also used as prefixed nouns in various expressions here following, in several thereof as meaning Something in possession, or the like; not a possessor: or, in these instances, as is said in explanation of the first of the following phrases, and also of the phrase caAtu Alyadi (mentioned below) in Ḥar p. 93, that which is contained is made to be as though it were the possessor (SaAHib) of that which contains.]

maw-ata caAbaTonihaA [He killed what was in her belly]. (Ḥar ubi suprá.) And waDaEati AlmaroOapu caA baTonihaA, (T,) or caAta baTonihaA, (TA,) The woman brought forth [her child]. (T, TA.) And navarato caA baTonihaA She brought forth many children. (T in art. nvr; and Mgh there and in the present art., in the latter of which it is added that the usual phrase is navarato baTonahaA.) And Oaloqati Ald-ajaAjapu caA baTonihaA The hen laid her egg, or eggs: or muted. (Mgh.) And OaloqaI Alr-ajulu caA baTonihi The man ejected his excrement, or ordure. (T.) And Alc-iYobu magobuwTN biciI baTonihi The wolf is envied [for what is in his belly, or] for his distention of the belly [with food]. (TA.)
