[In like manner,] caAtu Alyadi means ‡ Wealth; as though it were the possessor of that which contains it: (Ḥar ubi suprá:) [or what is in the possession of the hand:] or what one possesses, of wealth; because gained by the hand and disposed of by the hand. (Ḥar p. 66.) You say, qal-ato caAtu yadihi † What his hand possessed became little in quantity; (Lth, T;) or the possessions accompanying his hand; (Mgh;) app. meaning his riches. (Lth, T.)
caAtu Alr-iYapi and caAtu Aljanobi are Two well-known diseases. (TA. [See arts. rOI and jnb.])

EaliymN bicaAti AlS-uduwri, in the Ḳur iii. 115, means [Acquainted, or well acquainted,] with what is in the minds: (Ksh, Bḍ, Jel: [and the like is indicated in the Mgh:]) or with the true, or real, nature of the notions that are concealed in the minds: (IAmb, T:) or with the hidden things of the minds: or with the minds themselves. (Mṣb. [If the last meaning be correct, the phrase should be mentioned with others later in this paragraph.]) [And similar to this is the saying,] Earafahu mino caAti nafosihi He knew it from what he conceived in his mind [without his being informed thereof; i. e. he knew it of himself]. (Lth, T.) And jaMCa mino ciInafosihi and mino caAti nafosihi (M, Ḳ) He came [from a motive in his own mind; of himself;] of his own accord; or willingly; syn. Tay-iEFA: (M, TA:) in the copies of the Ḳ, TaboEFA; but the former is the right explanation. (TA.) And maA kal-amotu fulaAnFA caAta XafapK and caAta famK I spoke not to such a one a word. (AZ, T.)

caAta Alyamiyni and caAta AlX-imaAli [are adverbial expressions, and] mean In the direction of the right hand and of the left: properly in the direction that has the name of the right hand [and that has the name of the left hand]. (Bḍ in xviii. 16.) And OatayonaA caA yamiynK means We came on the right hand. (TA.)

caAta mar-apK and caA SabaAHK [also, and the like,] are adverbial expressions, which may not be used otherwise than as such: (Ṣ:) you say, laqiytuhu caAta mar-apK [I met him once, or once upon a time], (Ṣ,) and caAta AlmiraAri many times, (M and Ḳ in art. mr,) or sometimes, (Ṣ in that art.,) and caAta yawomK (Fr, T, Ṣ) i. e. mar-apF fiI yawomK [once upon a day, or one day], therefore you use the fem. form, (T,) and caAta layolapK [one night], (Fr, T, Ṣ,) and caAta gadaApK [one morning, or one morning between daybreak and sunrise], and caAta AlEiXaMCi [once in the evening at nightfall], (Ṣ,) meaning, accord. to Th, in the hour, or time, in which is nightfall, (T,) and caAta Alz-umayoni (Fr, T, Ṣ) [some time ago, or] three [or more, to ten,] seasons ago, (muco valaAvapu OazomaAnK, T, [by AzmAn being app. meant periods of two, or three, or six, months,]) and caAta AlEuwayomi (Fr, T, Ṣ) [some years ago, or] three years ago (T,) or three years ago or more, to ten; (Az on the authority of AZ, TA in art. Ewm;) and caA SabaAHK [one morning], and caA masaMCK [one evening], (T, Ṣ,) and caA SabuwHK [lit, at a time of drinking the morning-draught], and caA gabuwqK [lit. at a time of drinking the evening-draught]; in these four instances without p: and this mode of expression has been heard only in the cases of the times here mentioned: they did not say caAta XahorK nor caAta sanapK: (Ṣ:) or one may also well say caAta SabaAHK, like caAta yawomK; for cA and cAt both mean the time: and accord. to IAạr, one says, Oatayotuhu caAta AlS-abuwHi and caAta Algabuwqi, as meaning I came to him in the morning, or in the morning between daybreak and sunrise, and in the evening, or in the evening between sunset and nightfall. (T.)

You say also, laqiytuhu caAta yadayoni, (TA,) or laqiytuhu Oaw-ala ciI yadayoni (M) and caAti yadayoni, (AZ, M, Mṣb, [whence it seems to be not improbable that the phrase in the TA is imperfectly transcribed,]) meaning I met him the first thing, (M,) or first of everything. (AZ, Mṣb, TA.) And OafoEaluhu Oaw-ala ciI yadayoni and caAti yadayoni [I will do it the first thing, or first of everything]. (M.) And Oam-aA Oaw-ala caAti yadayoni faUin-aniI OaHomadu Qll-eha, (AZ, M, Mṣb,) i. e. [Whatever be the case, the first thing, or] first of everything, I praise God. (AZ, Mṣb.)

[Respecting the phrase caAtu Albayoni, which has two contr. meanings, see art. byn. It is inadequately explained in this art. in the T and M and Ḳ, as follows.] waOaSoliHuwA caAta bayonikumo, (T, M, Ḳ,*) in the Ḳur [viii. 1], accord. to Aḥmad Ibn-Yaḥyà, means [And do ye rightly dispose, or arrange, or order,] the case that is between you: (T:) or, accord. to Zj, (M,) that wherein consists your union; (Haqiyqapa waSolikumo, M, Ḳ;) i. e. be ye of one accord, or in unison, respecting that which God and his Apostle have commanded: (M:) or caAtu Albayoni means the state of circumstances whereby the Muslims become of one accord, or in unison: (Ḳ:) this is the meaning in the saying, Aall-ehum-a OaSoliHo caAta Albayoni [O God, do Thou rightly dispose, &c.]. (M.)

caAtN is sometimes used as a noun independent in its meaning, (Mgh, Mṣb,) so as to denote material [or real] things; (Mṣb;) and is described by the epithets mutamay-izapN [or “distinct”] (Mgh, Mṣb) and qadiymapN [as meaning “that has existed from eternity”] (Mgh) and muHodavapN [as meaning “that has been brought into existence”]. (Mgh, Mṣb.) Thus used, (Mṣb,) it signifies The essence of a thing, meaning that by being which a thing is what it is, or that in being which a thing consists; or the ultimate and radical constituent of a thing: and the essence as meaning the peculiar nature of a thing: syn. HaqiyqapN, (T, IB, Mṣb, TA,) and maAhiy-apN, (Mṣb,) and xaAS-apN: (T, IB, TA:) it is also used as meaning a thing's self: (Mgh,* Mṣb:) [a man's self, or person: (see XaxoSN:)] and a thing; a being; anything, whatever it be; every XaIoC being a caAt, and every cAt being a XIC: (Aboo-Saʼeed, Mgh, Mṣb:) and particularly a substance, or thing that subsists by itself: [hence Aisomu caAtK meaning a real substantive; also termed Aisomu EayonK: opposed to Aisomu maEonFI, i. e. an ideal substantive:] and [hence] it signifies also a word that is independent in its meaning; [i. e. caAtN (alone), though oftener used in the sense assigned above to Aisomu caAtK, signifies also, absolutely, a substantive;] opposed to SifapN as signifying a word that is not independent in its meaning. (Kull p. 187.) Its application to God, in the sense of HaqiyqapN and xaAS-apN, is forbidden by most persons: (TA:) [for] caAtu Qll-ehi [as meaning The essence of God], used by the scholastic theologians, is said to be an ignorant expression, because the names of God do not admit the fem. affix p; so that one does not apply to Him the epithet Eal-aAmapN, though He is the all-surpassing in knowledge. (Mṣb.) The phrase fiI caAti Qll-ehi is like fiI janobi Qll-ehi [In, or in respect of, that which is the right, or due, of God; or in, or in respect of, obedience to God, or the means of obtaining nearness to God, or the way of God]: and like liwajohi Qll-ehi [for the sake of God; or to obtain the countenance, or favour, or approbation, or recompense, of God]: (Mṣb:) or it means in obedience to God; and in the way of God or his religion: (TA:) [or it may be rendered for the sake of God Himself;]
and so liwajohi Qll-ehi: it is said to have been used by the Arabs [of the classical age], as well as by Aboo-Temmám, [who was a Muwelled;] (Mgh, Mṣb,*) but some deny that it occurs in the old language. (Mṣb. [See, however, an ex. from a trad. voce OuxayoXinu.]) [It is said that] the phrase majal-atuhumo caAtu AlUilehi, used by En-Nábighah, (Mṣb,) i. e. EdhDhubyánee, (TA in art. jl,) means Their book is the service of God Himself: (Mṣb:) [but it seems more reasonable to render this phrase agreeably with the primary signification of cAt as meaning their book is that of God, in a sense like that in which a house of worship is said to be a house of God; for,] as some relate it, the phrase used by En-Nábighah is maHal-atuhumo caAtu AlUilehi, with HAC, [i. e. their abode is in a peculiar manner that of God,] meaning, their abode is one of pilgrimage and of sacred sites. (Ṣ and TA in art. jl.)

cuw is sometimes redundant [in respect of meaning, though governing as a prefixed n.]; and so is its pl. (T,* TA.) Az says, (TA,) I have heard more than one of the Arabs say, kun-aA bimawoDiEi kacaA maEa ciI EamorKw, i. e. We were in such a place with Amr: (T, TA:) and kaAna maEanaA cuw EamorKw, i. e. ʼAmr was with us: and OatayonaA caA yamanK, meaning OatayonaA Alyamana [We came to El-Yemen]. (T.) [See an ex. similar to this last, and evidently belonging to the present art., in the latter half of art. cA. And see laA caA jarama and laA Oano caA jarama and laA Eano caA jarama and laA caA jara (in which cA is in like manner redundant, as are also Oano and Eano, the latter of which is a dial. var. of the former of them,) in art. jrm: perhaps belonging to the present art., like OatayonaA caAyamanK; or perhaps to art. cA. See also what is said respecting cuw prefixed to a proper name in an early portion of this paragraph.]

It is also used in the sense of Aal-aciI, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) in the dial. of Teiyi, (T, Ṣ, TA,) for the purpose of qualifying a determinate noun (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) by means of a proposition which it connects with that noun: (M, Ḳ:) and when thus used, it [generally] retains the same form when it denotes a dual and a pl. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and a fem., (Ṣ,) and exhibits no sign of case: (M, Ḳ:) you say, OanaA cuw Earafotu [I who knew], and cuw samiEotu [who heard]; and hecihi AlmaroOapu cuw qaAlato kacaA [This is the woman who said such a thing:] (Ṣ:) and OataAniI cuw qaAla celika [He who said that came to me]; and OataAniI cuw qaAlaA celika [They two who said that came to me]; and OataAni cuw qaAluwA celika [They who said that came to me]. (M.) But Fr says, I heard an Arab of the desert say, biAlfaDoli cuw faD-alakumo Qll-ehu bihi waAlkaraAmapi caAtu Oakoramakumu Qll-ehu bihaA [By the excellence wherewith God hath made you to excel, and the honour wherewith God hath honoured you]; thus they use caAtu in the place of Aal-atiI, and they make it to be with refa in every case: and they confuse [numbers and genders] in speaking of a dual number and a pl. number [and a fem.]; they sometimes say, [for ex.,] in the case of the dual, hecaAni cuw taEorifu and haAtaAni cuw taEorifu [These two whom, or which, thou knowest]; and a poet says, [namely, Sinán Ibn-El-Fahl, of the tribe of Teiyi, (Ḥam p. 292,)]
faUin-a AlmaMCa OabiI wajad-iI
wabiYoriI cuw Hafarotu wacuw Tawayotu
[For verily the water is the water of my father and my grandfather, and my well which I dug and which I cased; making cw to relate to a fem. noun]: and some, he adds, use the dual and pl. and fem. forms; thus they say, hecaAna cawaA qaAlaA caAka [These two who said that], and heWulaMCi cawuwA qaAluwA [These who said], and hecihi caAtu qaAlato [This female who said]; and he cites the saying of a poet,
jamaEotuhaA mino OayonuqK sawaAbiqo
cawaAtu yanohaDona bigayori saAYiqo
[I collected them from outstripping she-camels, that rise and hasten in their pace without a driver]; and the prov., OataI Ealayohi cuw OataI EalaI Aln-aAsi, meaning Al-aciI OataI [i. e. What has come upon men in general has come, or came, upon him]. (T.) Accord. to the usage most in repute, cuw in this sense is indecl., and has no variation of gender or number; but some decline it, like cw in the sense of SaAHib, except that they make caAt and cawaAt indecl., with damm for the termination, saying caAtu and cawaAtu in every case, if they adopt the chaste mode; otherwise, in the accus. and gen. cases, saying caAti, and in like manner cawaAti (I’Aḳ pp. 40 and 41.)

They said also, laAOafoEalu celika biciI tasolamu (M, Ḳ) and bcI tasolamiyna, (M,) and bcI tasolamaAni, (M, Ḳ,) and bcI tasolamuwna and bcItasolamona, (M,) meaning I will not do that by thy, and by your, safety: (M, Ḳ:) or by God who, (M,) or by Him who, (Ḳ,) maketh thee, and you, to be in safety. (M, Ḳ.) [See also art. slm.]
caAtN fem. of cuw [q. v. passim]. (T, Ṣ, M, &c.)
caAtiI-N: see cawawiI-N, below, in three places.

caAtiy-apN [a post-classical word, used in philosophy, The essential property or quality, or the aggregate of the essential properties or qualities, of a thing]. The caAtiy-ap of a human being is [the essential property or quality of] rational animality; and is also termed maAhiy-apN. (Kull p. 148.)

cawawiI-N the rel. n. of cuw; (Ṣ, TA;) and of caAtN also, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, TA,) the p of the original being rejected in forming the rel. n.: (Ṣ, Mṣb,* TA:) caAtiI-N↓, as rel. n. of caAtN, is not allowable: (M:) [but it is much used, mostly in philosophical and religious writings, as meaning Essential,, &c.:] they say AlS-ifaAtu Alc-aAtiy-apu↓ [meaning The essential attributes]; (Mgh, Mṣb;) but this is a wrong expression: and EayobN caAtiI-N↓ [An essential, or] a natural, an innate, an original, or a constitutional, fault or imperfection, &c. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 1. caAba, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. yacuwbu, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. cawobN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and cawabaAnN, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) It melted, dissolved, or became fluid or liquid; contr. of jamada: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) it flowed. (T, Mṣb.)
[Hence,] cAb damoEuhu ‡ [His tears flowed]. (A.) And caAbato Hadaqatuhu ‡ [His eye] shed tears; (A;) or flowed [with tears]. (T.)
cAb jisomuhu ‡ His body became lean, or emaciated: one says, vaAba baEodamaA caAba ‡ [He became fat after he had been lean]. (A.)
And caAba [alone] † He became foolish, or stupid, after having been intelligent. (T, Ḳ.)

naHonu laA najomudu fiI AlHaq-i walaA nacuwbu fiI AlbaATili ‡ [We will not be hard, or niggardly, in the case of truth, or right, nor will we be soft, or easily yielding, in the case of falsity, or wrong]. (A.)
hecaA AlkalaAmu fiyhi cawobu Alr-uwHi ‡ [This speech, or discourse, contains that which melts the soul]. (A.)
caAbati AlX-amosu [and AstcAbt↓ (as is shown by a phrase mentioned in the L in art. Sxd)] ‡ The sun became intensely hot. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

Oacuwbu All-ayaAliI Oawoyujiybu SadaAkumaA
occurring in a trad. of Kuss, means † I will wait in expectation during the lapse of the nights [or the echo of you two shall answer]; from AlUicaAbapu, which signifies “spoil, booty, or plunder.” (TA.)

maA caAba fiI yadiI XaIoCN † There remained not in my hand anything. (AHeyth, TA.) And maA caAba fiI yadayohi minohu xayorN, (M,) or fiI yadiI, (Ḳ,) † There came not [into his hands, or into my hands, from him, or it, any good]. (M, Ḳ.)

cAb Ealayohi AlmaAlu † The property became, or proved to be, binding, obligatory, or incumbent, on him to render as a debt. (T.) And cAb liI Ealayohi Haq-N ‡ A right, or due, was, or became, incumbent, or obligatory, on him to render to me, and established against him. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ.*) And cAb Ealayohi mina AlOamori kacaA, inf. n. cawobN, † Such a part of the thing, or affair, was, or became, incumbent, or obligatory, on him; like jamada and barada. (M.)
cAb also signifies He continued in the eating of cawob i. e. honey. (T, L, Ḳ.*)
2. cw-bhu: see 4.

Also, inf. n. tacowiybN, He made [or disposed] for him a cuwaAbap [or cuWaAbap]: irreg.; being originally with C [i. e. caO-abahu]. (T, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad. of Ibn-El-Hanafeeyeh, kaAna yucaw-ibu Oum-ahu, meaning He used to plait the cwAbp of his mother. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. AcAbhu and cw-bhu↓ He melted it, dissolved it, rendered it fluid or liquid, liquified it; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) or made it to flow. (Mṣb.) It is said in a prov., (Ṣ, TA,) respecting butter, (Ṣ,) maA yadoriI Oayuxoviru Oamo yuciybu [expl. in art. xvr]. (Ṣ, M, TA.) [See also a verse of Bishr cited below in this paragraph.]
[Hence,] the former [as meaning ‡ It dissolved him, or emaciated him,] is said of anxiety, (A, TA,) and grief. (TA.)

[Hence also,] AcAb HaAjatahu, and AstcAbhA↓, ‡ He matured, and fully accomplished, the object of his want. (A, TA.)
And AcAbwA Oamorahumo † They put their affair into a good, sound, or right, state. (Ḳ.)

AcAbwA EalayonaA, (Ṣ, M,) or Ealayohimo, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. UicaAbapN, (Ṣ,) ‡ They made an inroad or incursion, or a sudden attack, urging their horses, upon us, or upon them, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) and took spoil [from us, or them, or made, or left, our property, or theirs, to be taken as spoil]. (A.) Hence the saying of Bishr (Ṣ) Ibn-Abee-Kházim, (TA,)
fakaAnuw kacaAti Alqidori lamo tadori Uico galato
OatatorukuhaA macomuwmapF Oamo tuciybuhaA , (Ṣ,) or wakunotumo, (M, TA,) and OatunoziluhaA, (so in some copies of the Ṣ and M,) meaning † [And they were, or and ye were, like her having the cookingpot, not knowing, when it boiled, whether she should leave it, or put it down from the fire, disapproved, or] whether she should let it be taken as spoil: (Ṣ, TA:) so accord. to AZ: (Ṣ:) or the meaning is, [whether she should put it down from the fire,] or make it to remain; i. e. tuvobituhaA, (Ṣ, TA,) or tuboqiyhaA; (AHeyth, TA;) from caAba liI Ealayohi Haq-N, expl. above, (Ṣ, TA,) or from maA caAba fiI yadiI XaIoCN, also expl. above: (AHeyth, TA:) or, accord. to Aṣ, the meaning is, or whether she should melt it; from the prov. mentioned above in this paragraph: (Ṣ, TA:) i. e., whether she should leave it in a thick state, [disapproved,] or should melt it; fearing that the butter [in the cooking-pot] would spoil. (TA.) [In the TT, for macomuwmapF, I find madomuwmapF, which, applied to a cooking-pot, means smeared, or done over, with spleen,, &c. See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 626 et seq.]

10. Aisotacabotuhu signifies Talabotu minohu Alc-awoba [which may be rendered I asked, or desired, of him honey,, &c.]: (Ḳ:) [but accord. to ISd,] it signifies, agreeably with other verbs of this form, I asked, or desired, of him that he would melt or dissolve [butter, &c.]. (M.)
[Hence, perhaps,] AstcAbt AlX-amosu: see 1.
AstcAb HaAjatahu: see 4.
AstcAb cawobapF † He preserved a residue of his wealth, or property. (TA.)
caAbN A vice, fault, defect, or the like; (Ḳ;) like [cayobN and] caAmN and cayomN. (TA.)

hom.sense: cawobN [What is fluid, or liquid, of water, &c.; contr. of jamodN: see jaAmidN: and see also caAYibN.]

Honey, (T, M, Ḳ,) in a general sense: (M:) or honey cleared from its wax: (T, M, Ḳ:) or honey in the bees' cells: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and melted, or liquefied, honey: (M:) or melted, or liquefied, honey, cleared from its wax: so in the saying, huwa OaHolaImina Alc-awobi biAlUicowaAbapi↓ ‡ [He, or it, is sweeter than honey melted and cleared of its wax, with fresh butter melted in a cooking-pot to clarify it]. (A.)
Gum flowing upon the ground. (TA voce migofarN.)
cawobu Alc-ahabi Watergold: or, accord. to Er-Rázee, fluid, or liquid, gold; the inf. n. cawob being used in this instance in the sense of caAYib. (Ḥar p. 448.)
† Foolishness, or stupidity. (TA.) [But see the next paragraph.]
cawobapN † A residue of wealth, or property: so in the saying Oasolama EalaI cawobapK † He became a Muslim on the condition of his preserving a residue of his wealth, or property. (TA from a trad.)

† Manifest foolishness or stupidity: so in the phrase fiI fulaAnK cawobapN † In such a one is manifest foolishness or stupidity. (TA in art. Xwb.) You say also, Zaharato fiyhi cawobapN, meaning † Foolishness, or stupidity, appeared in him. (T.)

cuwbaAnN and ciybaAnN [like ciYobaAnN] The remains of the [fur, or soft hair, called] wabar [after the greater part has fallen off or been shorn]: or the hair (AlX-aEaru [for which AlX-Eri is erroneously put in the CK]) on the neck (M, Ḳ) and lip (M) of the camel (M, Ḳ) or horse. (Ḳ.)
Also the former, Paupers and thieves; for cuWabaAnN [a pl. of ciYobN, q. v.], the C being changed into w. (TA.)

entry.sense: caWuwbN [originally cawuwbN] A fat she-camel: (A, Ḳ:) because what is melted (maA yucaAbu) is collected from her. (A, TA.)
cuwaAbapN for cuWaAbapN [expl. in art. cOb]: pl. cawaAYibu. (T, Ḳ.)
haAjirapN caw-aAbapN ‡ A midday, or summer-midday, intensely hot. (T, A, TA.)
caAYibN part. n. of 1, [Melting or dissolving, fluid or liquid; or] flowing; contr. of jaAmidN. (Mṣb.)
lahu dumuwEN cawaAYibu ‡ [He has flowing tears]. (A, TA.)

caAYibu AlmaAli, as opposed to jaAmid [q. v.], ‡ Such property as consists in what is fluid, or liquid: (L in art. jmd:) or such as consists in live stock: (L and Ḳ in that art.:) or such as consists in trees. (L in that art.)
caAYibu Aln-afosi ‡ Heavy, slow, indolent, or dull, of soul; syn. vaqiylN. (A.)
UicaAbapN Spoil; booty; plunder: [in this sense] a subst. [in the proper meaning of the term]; not an inf. n. (M, TA.)

UicowaAbN and UicowaAbapN, [the latter, only, mentioned in the A, app. as being the more common,] Fresh butter when it is put into the cooking-pot to be cooked so as to become samon [i. e. clarified butter]: (AZ in explanation of the latter word, T, Ṣ:) or fresh butter which is melted in the cooking-pot to make samon: this name continues to be applied to it until it is put into the skin. (M, Ḳ.) See cawobN.
mucaAbN and mucaw-abN↓ Melted, or dissolved, fat [&c.]. (A.)
micowabN A vessel in which a thing is melted, or dissolved. (M, Ḳ.)
micowabapN A ladle. (Lḥ, M, Ḳ.)
mucaw-abN: see mucaAbN.
cuwbaAjN: see jwcAb, in art. jcb.

1. caAda, (M, A,) first pers. cudotu, (T, Ṣ,) aor. yacuwdu, (T, A,) inf. n. cawodN, (T,) or ciyaAdN, (Ṣ,) or both, (M, A, Ḳ,) He drove: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) he drove away: (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) and he repelled. (M, Ḳ.) You say, cadotu AlUibila I drove the camels: (Ṣ:) and I drove them away: (T, Ṣ:) and [so caw-adotuhaA↓, for] tacowiydN signifies the same as ciyaAdN. (Ṣ.) And cAd AlUibali Eani AlmaMCi, (A, Mṣb,) aor. yacuwdu, inf. n. cawodN and ciyaAdN, He (the pastor) [drove away, or repelled, or] kept back, or debarred, the camels from the water; or prevented them from coming to it. (Mṣb.) And cAdhu Eano kacaA, (A,) and cudotuhu, (Ṣ,) He, and I, drove him away from such a thing. (Ṣ, A. [And the like is said in the M.]) And cAd Eani AlHarami He repelled from, or defended, the sacred territory. (L.) And Alv-aworu yacuwdu Eano nafosihi bimicowadihi, i. e. ‡ [The bull repels from, or defends, himself] with his horn: and AlfaArisu bimicowadihi, i. e. ‡ [the horseman] with his spear, or short spear. (A.) And cAd Eano EiroDihi † He defended his honour. (L.) And cAd Ean-iI Alham-a ‡ [He dispelled from me anxiety.] (A.)
2: see above {1}.

4. AcAdhu He aided, or assisted, him to drive, or drive away, (T, Ṣ, M, A,) his camels. (T, Ṣ, A.) [In the Ḳ, Oacadotuhu is said to signify OaEanotuhu EalaI ciyaAdi Oaholihi: but Ahlh is app. a mistake for Uibilihi: or Eano is omitted before Ahlh; and if so, the meaning is I aided, or assisted, him to defend his family; but in this latter case, we should read ciyaAdK, which would be less chaste than Alc-iyaAdi.]

cawodN A number of camels, from three to ten: (Lth, AZ, Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) this is the meaning that is of best repute: (TA:) [in this explanation in the T from AZ, and in the Ḳ, the nouns of number are masc.; and so in the next here following: in the rest, fem.:] or from three to ten: and a little more: (IAạr, M:) or from three to nine: (M, L:) or from three to fifteen: or from three to twenty; (M, L, Ḳ;) and a little more: (L:) or from three to thirty: (M, L, Ḳ:) or from two to nine: (M, Mgh, L, Ḳ:) [said to be] applied only to females: (Lth, AʼObeyd, T, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) so in the Bári': (Mṣb:) and it is of the fem. gender; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e., the word is fem.: (MF:) but its dim. is [cuwayodN↓,] without p; contr. to analogy: (M:) the word cawodN is a pl., (M, Ḳ,) meaning a quasi-pl. n., (MF,) having no sing. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) of the same root: (Ṣ:) or a sing.; (Ḳ;) and its pl. is OacowaAdN: (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or a sing. and pl.: (M, Ḳ:) the Arabs said valaAvu OacowaAdK and valaAvu cawodK and so with all the inferior ns. of number, making cawod a substitute for OacowaAd: and they also said valaAvu cawodK meaning thereby three she-camels. (M, L.) It is said in a trad., layosa fiymaA duwna xamosi cawodK mina AlUibili SadaqapN, (T, L,) or layosa fiI Oaqal-a mino xamosK cawodK SadaqapN, (T, Mṣb,) meaning [There is not in the case of less than five] camels [any poorrate]: for the poor-rate is incumbent on him who possesses five camels whether they be males or females. (L.)
And in another trad. it is said, fiI xamosi cawodK XaApN [In the case of five camels, a sheep or goat shall be given]. (Mgh.) And it is said in a prov., Alc-awodu UilaI Alc-awodi UibilN [A few she-camels with a few she-camels are a herd of camels]; (T, Ṣ, M, A;) meaning that a little with a little is much; AlI being here used in the sense of maEa: (Ṣ, A:) or AlI is here used in its proper sense; a word signifying “joined” or the like being understood; (TA;) i. e. a few joined to a few becomes much: (M:) [or,] accord. to the Ḳ [and the T], this prov. shows that cwd is here used in the place of AivonataAni [i. e. two she-camels]; for two added to two are a pl.; but this requires consideration. (MF.)
cuwayodN: see the next preceding paragraph.
caw-aAdN: see the next preceding paragraph.
caAYidN Driving: driving away: and repelling: pl. cuw-adN and cuw-aAdN and caAdapN. (M, Ḳ.)

Also, and caw-aAdN↓, [but the latter has an intensive meaning,] † A man who is a defender, or protector, of that which, or those whom, it is necessary to defend, or protect: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) who is wont to repel attacks upon his honour. (Ṣ,* TA.)
macaAdN A place where beasts pasture at pleasure, where they eat and drink what they please, amid abundance of herbage. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
micowadN [An instrument for driving, driving away, or repelling.]
‡ A spear, or short spear, with which one repels from, or defends, himself. (A.)
‡ The horn of a bull, (T, A, Ḳ,) with which he repels from, or defends, himself. (A.)

‡ The tongue: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) because with it a man defends his honour. (M.) Hassán Ibn-Thábit says,
lisaAniI wasayofiI SaArimaAni kilaAhumaA
wayabolugu maA laA yabolugu Als-ayofu micowadiI
‡ [My tongue and my sword are sharp, both of them; and my tongue reacheth what my sword will not reach]. (Ṣ, TA.)
The manger (miEolaf, T, Ḳ, TA, in some copies of the Ḳ mEtlf, TA) of a horse or similar beast. (T, Ḳ. [A manger is thus called in the present day.])
micowaAdN: see the next preceding paragraph.
caArato for caAr-ato or caMCarato: see 3 in art. cr.

hom.sense: 1. caAfa, (M, Ḳ,) aor. yacuwfu, (M,) inf. n. cawofN, He walked with short steps, and in a straddling manner. (M, Ḳ.)
And cufotu is a dial. var. of cufotu, signifying I mixed [medicine, &c.] (M.)

entry.sense: cuwfaAnN [like cuWofaAnN, &c.] Poison: (Ḳ:) or poison made into a confection: or deadly poison: like ciyfaAnN [&c.]. (M.)

1. caAqahu, (Ḳ,) first pers. cuqotuhu, aor. Oacuwqohu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. cawoqN and cawaAqN and macaAqN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and macaAqapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He tasted it; i. e., perceived its taste, by means of the moisture of the tongue: (Mṣb:) or he tried, or knew, its taste: (Ḳ:) it is originally said of that of which little is taken: when much is taken, the term OakolN is used [and one says Oakalahu]: and tcAwqhu↓ signifies the same as caAqahu. (TA.) You say, cuqotu AlX-aIoCa [I tasted the thing], (Ṣ,) or AlT-aEaAma [the food]. (Mṣb.) And yawomN maA cuqotuhu TaEaAmFA, meaning maA cuqotu fiyhi [i. e. A day in which I tasted not food]. (TA.)

By amplification, Alc-awoqu is used to signify † The perceiving, beside tastes, all other objects of the senses, and states or conditions: (Bḍ in iii. 177:) it is not restricted to the sense of the mouth [or tongue] in the language of the Ḳur-án nor in the [genuine or classical] language of the [Pagan] Arabs. (TA.) Hence, in the Ḳur iii. 177, cuwquwA EacaAba AlHariyqi † [Taste ye the punishment of burning]: (Bḍ, TA:) for, although, in the common conventional acceptation, the verb relates to what is little in quantity, it is regarded as suitable to be used in relation to what is much. (TA.) One says also, fulaAnN caAqa kacaA waOanaA Oakalotuhu [lit. Such a one tasted such a thing, and I ate it;] meaning † such a one knew, or tried or tested, such a thing, and I knew it, or tried it or tested it, more. (TA.) cuqotu AlX-aIoCa means † I tried, or tested, the thing. (Mṣb.) And hence one says, cAq fulaAnN AlbaOosa † Such a one experienced harm,, &c.; i. e., knew it by its befalling him. (Mṣb.) And cuqotu maA Einoda fulaAnK † I knew, or tried or tested, what [qualities, &c.] such a one possessed; (Ṣ, TA;) and so cuqotu fulaAnFA. (TA.) And caAqa Alr-ajulu Eusayolapa AlmaroOapi wacaAqato Eusayolatahu † The man [tasted or] experienced the sweetness of the carnal enjoyment of the woman, and she in like manner. (Mṣb.) And cAq TaEoma AlUiymaAni † He tasted, or experienced, the savour of faith with his heart, like as the mouth tastes, or experiences, the savour of food and drink. (TA from a trad.) And cuqotu kacibahu waxabarotu HaAlahu ‡ [I experienced his lying, and knew his condition]. (TA.) And caAqatohaA yadiI, and caAqato fulaAnapa, ‡ My hand felt her, and felt such a female. (TA.)

cAq Alqawosa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. cawoqN; (TA;) [and caw-aqahaA↓; (so in Freytag's Lex. from the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen;)] ‡ He pulled the string of the bow (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) for the purpose of trial, (Ḳ, TA,) that he might see what was its strength. (Ṣ, TA.)

Alc-awoqu↓ is also employed to signify † [Taste, as meaning intellectual discernment and relish; i. e.] the faculty that is adapted to the acquisition of matters of knowledge, considered as being, in its perfection of perception, like sensation, regarded as a natural property; and particularly that [faculty] which concerns the niceties of language; because it [i. e. nice language] is, to the soul of man, like delicious intellectual food. (Kull. [When used as a subst in this sense, its pl. is OacowaAqN.]) One says, huwaHasanu Alc-awoqi lilX-iEori, meaning ‡ He has a good [taste or] natural faculty for poetry. (TA.)
[Also † Voluptuousness; sensuality: see caw-aAqN.]
2. cw-qhu [He gave him something to taste]: it is like lam-ajahu. (M and TA in art. lmZ.)
See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

4. Oacaqotuhu AlT-aEaAma, (Mṣb, Ḳ,*) inf. n. UicaAqapN, (TA,) I made him to taste the food; i. e., to perceive its taste by means of the moisture of the tongue: (Mṣb:) or I made him to try, or know, the taste [of the food]. (Ḳ.)

[Hence,] OacaAqahu Qll-ehu wabaAla Oamorihi † [God made him to taste, or experience, the evil result of his affair]. (Ṣ.) It is said in the Ḳur [xvi. 113], faOacaAqahaAQll-ehu libaAsa AljuwoEi waAlxawofi † [So God made her to taste, or experience, the utmost degree of hunger and of fear]: the verb is here used with libaAs because meant to convey the meaning of experiencing: or the sentence is elliptical, and means, made them to taste, or experience, hunger and fear, and clad them with the clothing thereof. (TA.) And in the same [xlii. 47], UicaA OacaqonaA AlUinosaAnu min-aA raHomapF † [When we make man to taste, or experience, mercy from us]; where, afterwards, AlUiSaAbapN is opposed to AlUicaAqapN, in the words waUino tuSibohumo say-iYapN. (TA.)

OacaAqa zayodN baEodaka karamFA means ‡ Zeyd became generous [after thee, i. e. after thou knewest him, or sawest him, or wast with him]: (Aboo-Hamzeh, Ḳ, TA:) [lit., made people to taste generosity:] and AcAq Alfarasu baEodaka EadowFA ‡ The horse became a good runner [after thee, i. e. after thou knewest him,, &c.] (Aboo-Hamzeh, TA.)
5. tcw-qhu He tasted it (caAqahu, Ṣ, Ḳ) by degrees, (Ṣ,) or repeatedly. (Ḳ.)

[Hence,] daEoniI Oatacaw-aqu TaEoma fulaAnK ‡ [Let me try, or test, the character of such a one]. (TA.) And tacaw-aqotu TaEoma firaAqihi ‡ [I tasted, or experienced, the savour of his separation]. (TA.)
6: see 1, first sentence. [The primary signification of tacaAwuqN seems to be The tasting a thing one with another.]

[And hence,] tcAwqwA Alr-imaAHa i. q. tanaAwaluwhaA ‡ [They took the spears, one from another, app. to test their qualities: see caAqa Alqawosa, above]. (Ḳ, TA.) Ibn-Mukbil says,
Oawo kaQhotizaAzi rudayoniI-K tacaAwaqahu
OayodiI AltijaAri fazaAduwA matonahu liynaA
‡ [Or like the quivering of a well-straightened spear (lit. a spear of Rudeyneh, a woman famous for the straightening of spear-shafts, accord. to the explanation commonly received,) which the hands of the dealers have taken, one from another, to test its quality, so that they have made the middle of it to increase in suppleness]. (TA.)

10. AisotacaAqa fulaAnFA xuborahu falamo yaHomado maxobaratahu ‡ [app. He endeavoured to test such a one, to ascertain the knowledge of his internal state, and did not approve his internal state: see the pass, part. n. below]. (TA, in which xbrh is without any syllabical signs.)

AstcAq AlOamoru lifulaAnK ‡ The affair was, or became, easy, or feasible, to such a one. (JK, TA.) You say, laA yasotaciyqu liIa AlX-iEoru Uil-a fiI fulaAni ‡ [Poetry, or versification, will not be easy, or feasible, to me, except in relation to such a one]. (TA.)
cawoqN an inf. n. used as a simple subst.; pl. OacowaAqN: see 1, in the latter part of the paragraph.

cawaAqN an inf. n.: and also a subst. signifying A thing that is tasted; (JM, TA;*) of the measure faEaAlN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN. (TA.) It is said of Moḥammad, lamo yakuno yacum-u cawaAqFA walaA yamodaHuhu, i. e. [He used not to praise] what was tasted [by him nor to dispraise it]. (JM.) And one says, maA cuqotu cawaAqFA, meaning I tasted not anything. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

Hence it is said in a trad., kaAnuwA UicaA xarajuwA mino Einodihi laA yatafar-aquwna Uil-aA Eano cawaAqK, i. e. † [They used, when they went forth from his (Moḥammad's) presence, not to disperse themselves save after receiving] knowledge and discipline that were, to their minds and souls, as food and drink to their bodies. (JM.)

caw-aAqN † That contracts new marriages time after time: (JM:) quick in marrying and quick in divorcing: (TA:) that conceives frequent disgust (maluwlN, Ṣ, JM, and Ḥar p. 569), not remaining [long] in one state with respect to marriage, &c.: fem. with p {caw-aAqapN}. (Ḥar ubi suprà.) Hence the saying, in a trad., Uin-a Qll-eha laA yuHib-u Alc-aw-aAqiyna walaA Alc-aw-aqaAti † [Verily God will not love those men who frequently contract new marriages, nor those women who do so]. (JM, and Ḥar ubi suprà.)
macaAqN an inf. n.: and also a subst. (TA) signifying A place, or time, of tasting. (KL.)
OamorN musotacaAqN † A thing, or an affair, tried, or tested, and known: (Ṣ:) and in like manner rajulN [a man]. (JK.)
2. caw-alotu caAlFA I wrote a c; (Az, Ṣgh, Ḳ;) or caAlFA HasanapN [a beautiful c]. (B, TA.) [See also 2 in art. cyl.]

hom.sense: caAlN A certain letter of the alphabet, (Lth, ISd, Ḳ,) [c,] pronounced with the voice, [not with the breath only,] and always a radical, not a substitute for another letter, nor augmentative; (ISd, TA;) its place of utterance is at the roots of the teeth, near the place of utterance of t [or v]; and it may be masc. and fem.; (B, TA;) [but generally it is fem.; and therefore] the dim. is cuwayolapN↓: (Ḳ:) the pl. is OacowaAlN and caAlaAtN. (TA.)
Also The comb of a cock. (Kh, TA.)

entry.sense: cawiylN, explained by IDrd as signifying What is dry, of plants, &c., and so in the Ḳ, is said by ISd to be correctly dawiylN [q. v.]. (TA.)
cuwayolapN: see caAlN, above.

5. tcw-n He was, or became, in a state of richness, wealth, or competence, and ease and plenty. (IAạr, Ḳ. [In the CK, Aln-Eomapu is here, as in many other instances, erroneously put for Aln-aEomapu.]) [See also tdw-n. Perhaps both are correct, as dial. vars.]

caAnN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and cayonN, (TA,) [the latter belonging to art. cyn,] A vice, fault, defect, or the like; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) syn. with caAbN [and cayobN] and caAmN and cayomN; (Ṣ, TA;) as heard by ISk from AA. (Ṣ.)
cuwnuwnN A certain plant: a dial. var. of cuWonuwnN, with C: [see the latter in art. cOn:] pl. cawaAniynu: mentioned by Az, on the authority of Ks. (TA.)

1. cawaI, (ISk, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yacowiI, (ISk, Ṣ, &c.,) inf. n. caI-N, (T,) or cuwiI-N, (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or both; (M, Mṣb;) and cawiIa, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) used by some of the Arabs, but bad, (T,) disallowed by ISk, but said by AO on the authority of Yoo to be a dial. var., (Ṣ,) aor. yacowaI; (T, Ḳ;) said of a branch, or twig, (T, M, Mṣb,) or of a herb, or leguminous plant, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) It withered; lost its moisture; or became thin, or unsubstantial, after being succulent; syn. cabala: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) it dried up: (T, A:) it obtained not moisture sufficient for it, or was marred by the heat, and in consequence withered, and became weak: (T:) in the dial. of the people of Beesheh, caOaI. (Lth, T.)
[Hence,] cawato sakiynatuhu † [His calmness, or gravity,] ceased. (Ḥar p. 109.)

4. AcwAhu, said of heat, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or of want of irrigation, (M,) It withered it; caused it to wither, or lose its moisture; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, a herb, or leguminous plant, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or a branch, or twig. (M, Mṣb.)

hom.sense: cawFI The skins of grapes: (IAạr, T:) a pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.] of which the sing. [or rather the n. un.] is cawaApN: (Kr, M:) [or] this latter signifies the skin, or husk, or rind, of the grape, (AA, T, Kr, M, Ḳ,) and of wheat (AlHinoTap), (AA, T, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or of the colocynth (AlHanoZalap), (Kr, M, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) and of the melon: (AA, T, Kr, M, Ḳ:) and so [dawaApN] with the unpointed d. (TA.)
Also cawFI, (IAạr, T,) or ciwFI↓, (Ḳ,) Weak, (IAạr, T,) or small, or young, (Ḳ,) ewes. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: ciwFI: see what next precedes.

sense.ref: sing. [or rather n. un.] of cawFI [q. v.]

entry.sense: cawaAtN pl. of caAtN, fem. of cuw, q. v.
caAwK Withering, or withered; losing, or having lost, its moisture. (Ṣ, TA.)
caAYika i. q. celika: so in the phrase caAYika Alr-ajulu [That man]: (Ḳ, TA:) a dial. var., or a mispronunciation. (TA.)
cI fem. of caA: see art. cA.
cay-apa wacay-apa: see art. cyt.
cay-aA, and cay-aAka, and cay-aAlika: see the two sentences next before the last in art. cA.
cay-aMCa wacay-aMCa: see art. cyt.
2. cy-O, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tacoyiIoCN, (Ḳ,) He cooked flesh-meat thoroughly, so that it fell off from the bone. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

5. tcy-O, said of flesh, or flesh-meat, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) It became separated from the bone by reason of corruption, (T, M, Ḳ,) or in consequence of cooking, (T,) or by slaughter, (M, Ḳ,) or from some other cause: (TA:) or became thoroughly cooked, so that it fell off from the bone. (Ṣ.) It (a wound, Aṣ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) became dissundered, or ragged, and corrupt, or putrid: (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and so said of other things: (Ḳ:) thus tacay-aOato said of a qirobap [or water-skin], (M,* TA,) and of a mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag]. (TA.)
It (the face) became swollen. (Ḳ.)
cayobN, (Ḳ,) like caAbN, mentioned in art. cwb, [and cayomN] and caAmN, (TA,) A vice, fault, defect, or the like. (Ḳ.)
ciybN: see ciYobN, in art. cOb.
ciybaAnN: see cuwbaAnN, in art. cwb.
Oacayobu, [like Oazayobu,] Much water. (Ḳ.)

Fright, or fear. (Ḳ.) Aṣ mentions the saying, mar-a fulaAnN walahu Oacayobu [as though meaning Such a one passed having fright, or fear]: and he says, I think that one says Oazayobu, with zAI having the meaning here following. (TA.)
Briskness, liveliness, sprightliness, or agility. (Ḳ.)
OaroDN macoyabapN: see macoOabapN, in art. cOb.
macoyuwbN: see macoWuwbN, in art. cOb.

cayota wacayota (AO, Ṣ, M voce caA, Mṣb,* Ḳ) and cayoti wacayoti and cayotu wacaytu, (Ḳ,) the last of which is unknown, except as mentioned by IḲṭṭ, (TA,) and cay-apa wacay-apa (M, Ḳ) and cay-aMCa wacay-aMCa, (Ḳ,) i. q. kayota wakayota: (AO, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,* Ḳ:) so in the saying, kaAna mina AlOamori cayota wacayota [&c., Some of the circumstances of the case were thus and thus, or so and so, or such and such things]. (AO, Ṣ, M.) It is plainly implied in the Ḳ [and the Ṣ] that the t in cyt is a radical letter, the last radical letter of the word: but AḤei says that the t in cyt and kyt is substituted for I; that they are originally cay-apa and kay-apa; and that the p is elided, and the I which is the last radical letter is changed into t: [in like manner also says ISd in the M, voce caA:] and most of the leading authorities on inflection assert the same: therefore, [though most persons would look for them among words of which the last radical letter is t,] they are incorrectly placed in the Ḳ [and in the Ṣ]. (MF.)
Or cayota is formed from cayowN, by eliding the w and doubling the I and then substituting for the teshdeed t; and if you elide the t and replace it by h, you must restore the teshdeed, and say, kaAna cay-aho wacay-aho. (Ṣ at the end of art. cw.)
2. cy-r, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tacoyiyrN, (Ṣ,) He smeared a she-camel's teats with ciyaAr, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in order that the young one might not suck her. (Ṣ.)

And cy-r Aln-aAqapa He bound the she-camel's udder with a SiraAr [q. v.], in order that the pieces of wood bound upon her udder to prevent her young one from sucking her might not make any impression upon her. (Ḳ,* TA.) [But see ciyaArN, which indicates that the true meaning is, He smeared the she-camel's teats with ciyaAr in order that the pieces of wood above mentioned might not make any impression upon them.]
cuy-ira fuwhu, inf. n. tacoyiyrN, His (a man's, Ṣ) teeth became black. (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
ciyrapN: see ciyaArN.

ciyaArN Fresh camels' or similar dung (baEara), [mixed with dust, or earth,] with which a she-camel's teats are smeared, (T, Ṣ, M,*) in order that the young one may not such her, (Ṣ, M,) and that the pieces of wood which are bound upon her udder to prevent her young one from sucking may not make any impression upon her; (T, M;) i. q. ciYaArN: or dung (siroqiyn) before mixed with dust or earth is called xuv-apN: and when mixed, ciyrapN↓: and when the teats are smeared with it, ciyaArN. (Lth, Ḳ.)

1. caAEa, aor. yaciyEu, inf. n. cayoEN and cuyuwEN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and cayoEuwEapN and cayaEaAnN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) It (information, news, or tidings, Ṣ, Ḳ, or discourse, Mṣb, and a thing, TA) became spread, published, or divulged; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) became revealed, made known, or disclosed. (Mṣb.)
You say also, caAEa Aljaworu † Injustice, or tyranny, spread. (TA.)
And caAEa Aljarabu fiI Aljilodi ‡ The mange, or scab, became general, and spread, in the skin. (TA.)

4. AcAEhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AcAE bihi, (Zj, Ḳ,) as in the Ḳur iv. 85, (Zj,) inf. n. UicaAEapN, (TA in art. cwE,) He spread, published, divulged, revealed, made known, or disclosed, it; (Zj, Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) and (so Zj, but in the Ḳ, “or,”) proclaimed it among the people; (Zj, Ḳ;) namely, information, news, or tidings, (Ṣ,) or discourse, (Mṣb,) or a secret. (Ḳ.)

Hence, app., (TA in art. cwE,) AcAE Alqawomu (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AcAEt AlUibilu, (Ḳ,) maA fiI AlHwD, (Ṣ,) or bimaA fI AlHwD, (Ḳ,) ‡ The people, or company of men, and the camels, drank what was in the watering-trough, or tank, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) all of it. (Ṣ.)
And hence, app., (TA,) AcAE bihi signifies also ‡ He took it away; namely, another's property, (Ḳ,) and anything. (TA.)
Accord. to the Ḳ, the medial radical letter is both w and I; but correctly it is I: (TA in the present art. and in art. cwE:) so accord. to AZ and J and Z. (TA in art. cwE.)

micoyaAEN [A babbler of secrets, &c.;] one who will not keep, or conceal, a secret: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or one who is unable to conceal his information, news, or tidings: an epithet of an intensive form: (TA:) pl. macaAyiyEu. (Ṣ.)

ciyfaAnN and cayofaAnN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and cayafaAnN (M, Ḳ) Deadly poison: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or poison that takes effect; or that remains fixed, and collects: (M:) a dial. var. of ciYofaAnN, &c., (Ḳ,) and cuwfaAnN. (M.) And the second of these words, Death: so in the saying, saqaAhu Qll-ehu kaOosa Alc-ayofaAni [May God give him to drink the cup of death]; as mentioned by Lḥ. (M.)
1. caAla, aor. yaciylu, inf. n. cayolN, It (a garment) was long, so that it touched the ground. (Mṣb.)

He, or it, had a cayol; [app. said of a horse, &c., as meaning he had a long tail, or a pendent portion to his tail; and probably of a garment, as meaning it had a skirt, or lower extremity, reaching nearly, or quite, to the ground, or dragged upon the ground, when made to hang down; and perhaps of a man, as meaning he had a cyl to his garment;] as also Oacoyala↓. (M, Ḳ.)

And, said of a man, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (M, Mṣb,) and so the inf. n., (M,) He walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, dragging his cayol [or skirt, or the lower extremity of his garment]; (M, Ḳ;) and in like manner caAlato is said of a she-camel: (M:) or he dragged his OacoyaAl [or skirts, or the lower extremities of his garment or garments], by reason of pride and self-conceit: (Mṣb:) or caAlato, (T, Ṣ,) fiI miXoyatihaA, said of a girl, or young woman, (T,) or of a woman, (Ṣ,) aor. taciylu, (T, Ṣ,) inf. n. as above, (T,) she dragged her OacoyaAl, (T,) or her cayol, (Ṣ,) upon the ground, walking with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait. (T, Ṣ.) [See also 5.]
cAl bicanabihi He raised his tail; (M, Ḳ;) said of a horse, and of a mountaingoat. (M.) And cAlt bicanabihaA She (a camel) spread her tail upon her thighs. (T.)
cAl Uilayohi i. q. AinobasaTa [app. as meaning He acted towards him, or behaved to him, with boldness, forwardness, presumptuousness, or arrogance]; as also tcy-l↓. (Ḳ.)
cAlt said of a woman, (M, Ḳ,) and of a she-camel, (M,) She was, or became, lean, or emaciated, (M, Ḳ,) and in a bad condition. (M.)

hom.sense: 2. cy-l vawobahu, inf. n. tacoyiylN, [He made his garment to have a cayol, i. e. shirt, or lower extremity, reaching nearly, or quite, to the ground, or such as to be dragged upon the ground; or] he made his garment long: (T:) and AcAl↓ vawobahu he made his garment to have a long cayol. (T, TA.)
[Hence, cay-alotu kitaAbahu † I added an appendix to his writing, or book; like can-abotuhu. And hence, the inf. n. tacoyiylN is used to signify † An appendix; like taconiybN; as also cayolN↓.]
cay-alotu caAlFA [I wrote a c]. (IB, TA on the letter A.) [See also 2 in art. cwl.]
4. Oacoyala: see 1, second sentence.
AcAl vawobahu: see 2.
AcAlt qinaAEahaA She (a woman) let down her head-covering. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

AcAlhu, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UicaAlapN, (Ṣ,* M, Mṣb,) He lowered him; abased him; rendered him vile, mean, contemptible, or ignominious; or held him in low, or mean, estimation; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and did not tend him, or take care of him, well; (M, Ḳ;) namely, his horse, (T, Ṣ, M,) and his young man, or slave; (Ṣ;) or it is said of the owner of a thing. (Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., (Ṣ, M,) of the Prophet, (M,) nahaI Eano UicaAlapi Alxayoli, (Ṣ, M,) i. e. [He forbade] the using of horses for mean work, and burdens. (Ṣ, TA.)
And OacalotuhaA I rendered her lean; or emaciated her; namely, a woman, and a camel. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tcy-lt Ald-aAb-apu The beast moved about its tail. (M.)
And hence, (M,) tcy-l He (a man, TA) walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, (M, Ḳ,) [app., dragging his cayol (or skirt), like caAla.]
[It occurs in the M and L, in art. rOd: said of a branch, or twig, app. as meaning It inclined limberly from side to side: but in the Ḳ, I there find in its place tcb-l.]
See also 1.
6: see 1, last sentence but one.

hom.sense: cayolN The latter, or kinder, or the last, or kindmost, part of anything. (M, Ḳ.) Accord. to MF, this is the proper signification, and the other significations here following are tropical. (TA.) [But in my opinion, the word in each of the next two senses, or at least in the former of them; if not strictly proper, is what is termed HaqiyqapN Eurofiy-apN, i. e. a word so much used in a tropical sense as to be, in that sense, conventionally regarded as proper.]

[A skirt, or lower extremity, of a garment, reaching nearly, or quite, to the ground, or that is dragged upon the ground, when made to hang down:] the extremity, of a garment, that is next the ground, and so if not touching it [as well as if touching it]; an inf. n. used in this sense: (Mṣb:) or the part of a waist-wrapper (UizaAr), and of a garment [of any kind], that is dragged [upon the ground], (M, Ḳ,) when it is made to hang down: (M:) or the part, of an UizaAr, and of a [garment of the kind called] ridaMC, that is made to hang down, and touches the ground: and the part, of any kind of garment worn by a woman, that the wearer drags upon the ground behind her: (Lth, T:) or the parts, all round, of a woman's garment, that fall upon the ground:
and the portion that is made to hang down, of a woman's shift and of her qinaAE [or head-covering]: you do not [properly] say of a man that he has a cayol [but only when you liken the lower part of his garment to the similar part of a woman's garment]: a man's having a long garment, such as a shirt and a jub-ap, [or his dragging the skirt thereof,] is termed UirofaAlN: (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, T:) the pl. of cayolN (in this sense, T, Mṣb, as relating to a shirt [&c.], S, and in all its senses, T, M) is OacoyaAlN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OacoyulN (El-Hejeree, M, Ḳ) [both pls. of pauc.] and cuyuwlN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) which is a pl. of mult. (M.) Hence Tuwlu Alc-ayoli is a metonymical expression meaning ‡ Richness, or competency; because long OacoyaAl generally pertain to the rich and the prodigal and the proud and self-conceited: (Er-Rázee, Ḥar p. 493:) and you say, TaAla cayolu fulaAnK, meaning ‡ The state, or condition, of such a one became good, and his wealth became abundant: and huwa Tawiylu Alc-ayoli, meaning ‡ He is rich. (Ḥar p. 319.)
Of a horse (T, Ḳ), &c., (Ḳ,) [i. e.] of a horse and a camel and the like, (M,) The tail: (T, M, Ḳ:) or the tail when long: (TA:) or the part, of the tail, that is made to hang down. (M, Ḳ.)
[† Of a cloud, The skirt; or lower, pendent, part: used in this sense in the Ḳ voce hayodabN.]

cayolu Alr-iyHi † What is dragged along, (T, Ṣ, O,) or drawn together, (M,) by the wind, upon the ground, (T, Ṣ, O, M,) of dust (T, M, O) and rubbish: (T, O:) or what the wind leaves upon the sand, (M, Ḳ,) in the form of a rope, (M,) resembling the track of a cayol [or skirt] dragged along: (M, Ḳ:) or, as some say, OacoyaAluAlr-iyHi means † the after-parts of the wind, with which it sweeps what is light to it. (M.)
cayolu jabalK † The foot, bottom, base, or lowest part, of a mountain. (A and TA voce jar-N.)
OacoyaAlu Aln-aAsi † The hindmost of the people. (Ḳ.) You say, jaMCa OacoyaAlN mina Aln-aAsi † Some few of the hindmost of the people came. (Ṣ, Ṣgh.)
See also 2.
And see caAYilN.

entry.sense: cay-aAlN: see caAYilN, in three places.

Also That behaves proudly, conceitedly, or vainly, and walks with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait. (TA.) Applied to a horse, That carries himself in an elegant and a proud and self-conceited manner, in his step, and in curvetting, or raising his fore legs together and putting them down together, and kneading with his hind legs, or in prancing, as though he dragged along the cayol [or pendent portion] of his tail. (M.)

hom.sense: caAYilN, applied to a horse, Having a cayol, (T, Ḳ,) i. e. tail: (T:) and cay-aAlN↓ having a long cayol: (T, Ḳ:) or the former word has the latter signification; (IḲt, T, M;) it means having a long tail: (Ṣ:) and ↓the latter word, tall, and having a long cayol, (M, Ḳ,) and that carries himself in an elegant and a proud and self-conceited manner, in his step; (Ḳ;) and is applied in the same sense to a wild bull: (M:) or the former word signifies short, and having a long tail; and its fem. is with p {caAYilapN}: (T:) or when a horse is of this description, they say cay-aAlu↓ Alc-anabi, mentioning the canab. (T, Ṣ.)

Also, applied to a diroE, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) [i. e. a coat of mail, as is shown in the Ṣ and TA,] Long (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) in the cayol [or shirt]; (Ṣ;) and so caAYilapN and mucaAlapN↓. (M, Ḳ. [In the CK, the last word is erroneously written macaAlapN.])
And HaloqapN caAYilapN and mucaAlapN↓ A ring [app. of a coat of mail] that is slender (M, Ḳ *) and elongated. (M.)
cayolN↓ caAYilN [an expression like cul-N caliylN, the former word an inf. n.,] means [Exceeding] lowness, baseness, vileness, meanness, contemptibleness, or ignominiousness. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: The fem. also means † A female slave: (T, Ṣ, M:) because she is held in low, or mean, estimation, while she carries herself in an elegant and a proud and selfconceited manner: so in the prov., Oaxiylu mino mucaAlapK [More proud and self-conceited than a female slave]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

mucoyilN [so in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, as in the M, but in other copies of the Ḳ mucay-alN,] and mutacay-ilN↓ [in the CK mutacay-alN] i. q. mutabac-ilN [One who performs his own work; or who is careless of himself or his honour or reputation]. (M, Ḳ.)

mucay-alN A garment, (T,) of the kind called mulaMC, (T, Ṣ,) or ridaMC, (Ḳ,) Long (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) in the cayol [or skirt]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) So in a verse of Imra-el-Ḳeys, of which the latter hemistich is cited voce duwaArN. (T, TA.)
OaroDN mutacay-alapN A land upon which has fallen a weak and small quantity (laToxN DaEiyfN) of rain. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
mutacay-ilN: see muciylN.

1. caAmahu, (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) first pers. cimotuhu, (Ṣ,) aor. yaciymu, (T, &c.,) inf. n. cayomN and caAmN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He blamed, or found fault with, him, or it, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) namely, a commodity; like caOamahu: (Mṣb:) accord. to Akh, cimotuhu and caOamotuhu and camamotuhu all signify the same. (Ṣ.)
caAmN: see what next follows, in two places.

cayomN and caAmN↓ are inf. ns., (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and are syn. with EayobN [as such, and also as meaning A vice, fault, defect, or the like; in the latter sense syn. with caAm-N, which belongs to art. cm]: (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,* Ḳ:) or, as some say, syn. with cam-N [blame,, &c.]. (M.) It is said in a prov., laAtaEodamu AlHasonaMCu caAmFA↓ [The beautiful female is not without a defect]. (Ṣ.)

maciymN Blamed, or found fault with; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also macoyuwmN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the former defective, and the latter complete: (Ṣ:) applied [app. to a man; (see the dial. var. macoWuwmN, as used in the Ḳur vii. 17;) and] to a commodity. (Mṣb.)
macoyuwmN: see what next precedes.
1. caAnahu, [aor. yaciynu, inf. n., app., cayonN,] He blamed, or found fault with, him, or it; like caAmahu. (IAạr, T.)
cayonN, (M, TA,) incorrectly said in the Ḳ to be ciyonN, with kesr, (TA,) A vice, fault, defect, or the like, (M, Ḳ, TA;) as also caAnN [which belongs to art. cwn]. (M.)
mucaAnN a dial. var. of mucaAlN. (M.) [See the latter in art. cyl.]
